(base) As forward was / right there he moste abyde
(base) Another / lad is on that oother syde
(base) ¶ And som tyme / dooth hem Theseus to reste
(base) Hem to refresshe / and drynken if hem leste
(base) Ful ofte a day / haue thise Thebans two
(base) Togydre ymet and wroght his felawe wo
(base) Vnhorsed hath ech oother / of hem tweye
(base) Ther nas no tygre / in the vale of Galgopheye
(base) Whan that hir whelp is stole / whan it is lyte
(base) So cruel on the hunte / as is Arcite
(base) For Ialous herte / vpon this Palamon
(base) Ne in Belmarye / ther nys so fel leoun
(base) That hunted is / or for his hunger wood
(base) Ne of his praye / desireth so the blood
(base) As Palamon / to sleen his foo Arcite
(base) The Ialous strokes / on hir helmes byte
(base) Out renneth blood / on bothe hir sydes rede
(base) ¶ Som tyme an ende ther is / of euery dede
(base) For er the sonne / vnto the reste wente
(base) The stronge kyng Emetrius / gan hente
(base) This Palamon / as he faught with Arcite
(base) And made his swerd / depe in his flessh to byte
(base) And by the force of twenty / is he take
(base) Vnyolden / and ydrawen to the stake
(base) And in the rescous / of this Palamoun
(base) The stronge kyng lygurge / is born adoun
(base) And kyng Emetrius / for al his strengthe
(base) Is born out of his Sadel / a swerdes lengthe
(base) So hitte hym Palamon / er he were take
(base) But al for noght he was broght to the stake
(base) His hardy herte / myghte hym helpe naught
(base) He moste abyde / whan that he was caught
(base) By force / and eek by composicioun
(base) ¶ Who sorweth now / but woful Palamoun
(base) That moot namoore / goon agayn to fighte
(base) And whan that Theseus / hadde seen this sighte
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Vnto the folk / that foghten thus echon
(base) He cryde / hoo namoore / for it is doon
(base) I wol be trewe Iuge / and nat partye
(base) Arcite of Thebes / shal haue Emelye
(base) That by his fortune / hath hire faire ywonne
(base) Anon ther is a noyse of peple bigonne
(base) For ioye of this / so loude and heigh with alle
(base) It semed / that the lystes sholde falle
(base) ¶ What kan now faire Venus / doon aboue
(base) What seith she now / what dooth this queene of loue
(base) But wepeth so / for wantyng of hir wille
(base) Til that hir teerys / in the lystes fille
(base) She seyde / I am ashamed doutelees
(base) ¶ Saturnus seyde / doghter hoold thy pees
(base) Mars hath his wyl / his knyght hath al his boone
(base) And by myn heed / thow shalt been esed soone
(base) ¶ The trompours / with the loude Mynstralcye
(base) The heraudes / that ful loude yelle and crye
(base) Been in hir wele / for ioye of daun Arcite
(base) But herkneth me / and stynteth noyse alite
(base) Which a myracle / ther bifel anon
(base) ¶ This fierse Arcite / hath of his helm ydon
(base) And on a Courser / for to shewe his face
(base) He priketh / endelong the large place
(base) Lookyng vpward / vpon this Emelye
(base) And she agayn / hym caste a freendly eye
(base) And she was al his cheere / as in his herte
(base) Out of the ground / a furye Infernal sterte
(base) From Pluto sent / at requeste of Saturne
(base) For which his hors / for feere gan to turne
(base) And leep asyde / and foundred as he leep
(base) And er that Arcite / may taken keep
(base) He pighte hym / on the pomel of his heed
(base) That in the place / he lay as he were deed
(base) His brest to brosten / with his Sadel bowe
(base) As blak he lay / as any col / or crowe
(base) So was the blood / yronnen in his face
(base) Anon he was yborn out of the place
(base) With herte soor / to Theseus Paleys
(base) Tho was he coruen / out of his harneys
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) And in a bed ybroght ful faire and blyue
(base) For he was yet in memorie and alyue
(base) And alwey cryinge / after Emelye
(base) ¶ Duc Theseus / withal his compaignye
(base) Is comen hoom / to Atthenes his Citee
(base) With alle blisse / and greet solempnytee
(base) Al be it that this auenture was falle
(base) He nolde noght disconforten hem alle
(base) ¶ Men seyde eek Arcite / shal nat dye
(base) He shal been heelyd / of his maladye
(base) And of another thyng they were as fayn
(base) That of hem alle / was ther noon yslayn
(base) Al were they soore yhurt and namely oon
(base) That with a Spere / was thirled the brest boon
(base) ¶ To oothere woundes / and to broken armes
(base) Somme hadden salues / and somme hadden charmes
(base) Fermacyes of herbes / and eek saue
(base) They dronken / for they wolde hir lymes haue
(base) For which this noble duc / as he wel kan
(base) Conforteth / and honoureth euery man
(base) And made reuel / al the longe nyght
(base) Vnto the straunge lordes / as was right
(base) ¶ Ne ther was holden / no disconfitynge
(base) But as a Iustes / or a tourneyinge
(base) For soothly / ther was no disconfiture
(base) For fallyng. nys nat but an auenture
(base) Ne to been had by force / vnto the stake
(base) Vnyolden / and with twenty knyghtes take
(base) O persone allone / withouten mo
(base) And haryed forth / by arm / foot / and to
(base) And eek his steede / dryuen forth with staues
(base) With footmen / bothe yemen and eek knaues
(base) It nas arretted hym / no vileynye
(base) Ther may no man / clepe it cowardye
(base) ¶ For which anoon / duc Theseus leet crye
(base) To stynten / al rancour and enuye
(base) The gre / as wel of oo syde as of oother
(base) And eyther syde ylyk as otheres brother
(base) And yaf hem yiftes / after hir degree
(base) And fully heeld a feeste / dayes three
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) And conueyed / the kynges worthily
(base) Out of his toun / a iournee largely
(base) And hoom wente euery man / the righte way
(base) Ther was namoore / but fare wel haue good day
(base) Of this bataille / I wol namoore endite
(base) But speke of Palamon / and of Arcite
(base) Swelleth the brest of Arcite / and the soore
(base) Encreeseth at his herte / moore and moore
(base) The clothered blood / for any lechecraft
(base) Corrupteth / and is in his bouk / ylaft
(base) That neyther veyne blood / ne ventusynge
(base) Ne drynke of herbes / may been his helpynge
(base) The vertu expulsyf / or animal
(base) Fro thilke vertu / clepyd natural
(base) Ne may the venym / voyden ne expelle
(base) The pipes of his longes / gan to swelle
(base) And euery lacerte / in his brest adown
(base) Is shent with venym and corrupcioun
(base) Hym gayneth neither / for to gete his lyf
(base) Vomyt vpward / ne downward laxatyf
(base) Al is to brosten / thilke regioun
(base) Nature / hath no dominacioun
(base) And certeinly / ther nature wol nat werche
(base) Fare wel Phisyk. go ber the man to cherche
(base) This al and som / that Arcita moot dye
(base) For which / he sendeth after Emelye
(base) And Palamon / that was his cosyn deere
(base) Thanne seyde he thus / as ye shal after heere
(base) ¶ Nat may the woful spirit in myn herte
(base) Declare a point of alle my sorwes smerte
(base) To yow my lady / that I loue moost
(base) But I byquethe / the seruice of my goost
(base) To yow / abouen euery creature
(base) Syn that my lyf / may no lenger dure
(base) Allas the wo / allas the peynes stronge
(base) That I for yow haue suffred / and so longe
(base) Allas the deeth / allas myn Emelye
(base) Allas / departyng of oure compaignye
(base) Allas myn hertes queene / allas my wif
(base) Myn hertes lady / endere of my lyf

div.l: (base) What is this world / what axeth men to haue
(base) Now with his loue / now in his colde graue
(base) Allone / with outen any compaignye
(base) Fare wel / my sweete foo / myn Emelye
(base) And softe taak me / in youre Armes tweye
(base) For loue of god / and herkneth what I seye
(base) ¶ I haue heer / with my cosyn Palamoun
(base) Had stryf and rancour / many a day goun
(base) For loue of yow / and for my Ialousye
(base) And Iuppiter / so wys my soule gye
(base) To speken / of a seruaunt proprely
(base) With circumstaunces alle / trewely
(base) That is to seyn / trouthe / honour / knyghthede
(base) Wisdom / humblesse / estaat / and heigh kynrede
(base) Fredom / and al / that longeth to that art
(base) So Iuppiter / haue of my soule part
(base) As in this world / right now ne knowe I non
(base) So worthy to been loued / as Palamon
(base) That serueth yow / and wol doon al his lyf
(base) And if that euere / ye shal been a wyf
(base) Foryet nat Palamon / the gentil man
(base) And with that word / his speche faille gan
(base) For from his feet vp to his brest was come
(base) The coold of deeth / that hadde hym ouercome
(base) And yet moore ouer / for in his armes two
(base) The vital strengthe / is lost and al ago
(base) Oonly the Intellect withoute moore
(base) That dwelled in his herte / syk and soore
(base) Gan faillen / whan the herte felte deeth
(base) Dusked hise eyen two / and fayled breeth
(base) But on his lady / yet caste he his eye
(base) His laste word / was mercy Emelye
(base) His spirit chaunged hous / and wente ther
(base) As I cam neuere / I kan nat tellen wher
(base) Therfore I stynte / I nam no dyuynystre
(base) Of soules / fynde I nat in this Registre
(base) Ne me ne lyst / thilke opynyons to telle
(base) Of hem / thogh that they writen wher they dwelle
(base) Arcite is coold / ther Mars his soule gye

div.l: (base) Now wol I speken / forth of Emelye
(base) ¶ Shrighte Emelye / and howleth Palamon
(base) And Theseus / his suster took anon
(base) Swownynge / and baar hire fro the corps away
(base) What helpeth it to tarien forth the day
(base) To tellen how she weep / bothe eue and morwe
(base) For in swich caas / wommen haue swich sorwe
(base) Whan that hir housbondes / been from hem ago
(base) That for the moore part they sorwen so
(base) Or ellis fallen / in swich a maladye
(base) That at the laste / certeinly they dye
(base) ¶ Infinite / been the sorwes and the teerys
(base) Of olde folk. and folk of tendre yeerys
(base) In al the town / for the deeth of this Theban
(base) For hym ther wepeth bothe child a man
(base) So greet wepyng was ther noon certayn
(base) Whan Ector was broght al fressh yslayn
(base) To Troye / allas the pitee that was ther
(base) Cracchynge of chekes / rentyng eek of heer
(base) Why woldest thow be deed / thise wommen crye
(base) And haddest gold ynow / and Emelye
(base) ¶ No man / myghte gladen Theseus
(base) Sauyng his olde fader Egeus
(base) That knew / this worldes transmutacioun
(base) As he hadde seyn it chaungen / bothe vp and down
(base) Ioye after wo / and wo after gladnesse
(base) And shewed hem / ensample and lyknesse
(base) ¶ Right as ther deyed neuere man / quod he
(base) That he ne lyued in erthe / in som degree
(base) Right so / ther lyued neuere man he seyde
(base) In al this world / that som tyme he ne deyde
(base) This world / nys but a thurghfare / ful of wo
(base) And we been pilgrymes / passynge to and fro
(base) Deeth is an ende / of euery worldly soore
(base) And oueral this / yet seyde he muchel moore
(base) To this effect ful wysly / to enhorte
(base) The peple / that they sholde hem reconforte
(base) ¶ Duc Theseus / withal his bisy cure
(base) Caste now / wher that the sepulture
(base) Of goode Arcite / may best ymaked be

div.l: (base) And eek moost honurable / in his degree
(base) And at the laste / he took conclusioun
(base) That ther / as first Arcite and Palamoun
(base) Hadden for loue / the bataille hem bitwene
(base) That in the selue groue / swoote and grene
(base) Ther as he hadde / hise amorouse desires
(base) His compleinte / and for loue his hote fyres
(base) He wolde make a fyr / in which the office
(base) Funeral / he myghte al acomplice
(base) And leet anoon comaunde / to hakke and hewe
(base) The okes olde / and leyen hem on a rewe
(base) In colpons / wel arrayed for to brenne
(base) Hise officers / with swifte feet they renne
(base) And ryde anoon / at his comandement
(base) And after this / Theseus hath ysent
(base) After a Beere / and it al ouerspradde
(base) With clooth of gold / the richeste / that he hadde
(base) And of the same suyte / he cladde Arcite
(base) Vpon his handes / his gloues white
(base) Eek on his heed / a coroune of laurer greene
(base) And in his hand / a swerd ful bright and keene
(base) He leyde hym bare the visage / on the beere
(base) Ther with he weep / that pitee was to heere
(base) And for the peple / sholde seen hym alle
(base) Whan it was day / he broghte hym to the halle
(base) That roreth / of the cryyng and the sown
(base) Tho cam / this woful Theban Palamoun
(base) With flotry berd / and ruggy asshy heerys
(base) In clothes blake / ydropped al with teerys
(base) And passyng othere / of wepyng Emelye
(base) The rufulleste / of al the compaignye
(base) In as muche / as the seruyce sholde be
(base) The moore noble / and ryche in his degree
(base) Duc Theseus / leet forth thre steedes brynge
(base) That trapped weren in steel al gliterynge
(base) And couered with the armes / of daun Arcite
(base) Vpon thise steedes / grete and whyte
(base) Ther seten folk / of which oon baar his sheeld
(base) Another his spere / vpon his hondes heeld

div.l: (base) The thridde bar with hym / his bowe Turkeys
(base) Of brend gold / was the caas / and eek the harneys
(base) And ryden forth a paas / with sorweful cheere
(base) Toward the groue / as ye shul after heere
(base) The nobleste of the Grekys / that ther were
(base) Vpon hir shuldres / carieden the beere
(base) With slak paas / and eyen rede and weete
(base) Thurgh out the Citee / by the maister streete
(base) That sprad was al with blak and wonder hye
(base) Right of the same / is the strete ywrye
(base) Vpon the right hand / wente olde Egeus
(base) And on that oother syde / duc Theseus
(base) With vessels in hir hand / of gold ful fyn
(base) Al ful of hony / melk / and blood and wyn
(base) Eek Palamon / with ful greet compaignye
(base) And after that / cam woful Emelye
(base) With fyr in hande / as was that tyme the gyse
(base) To do the office / of funeral seruyse
(base) ¶ Heigh labour / and greet apparaillynge
(base) Was at the seruyce / and the fyr makynge
(base) That with his grene top / the heuene raughte
(base) And twenty fadme of brede / the armes straughte
(base) This is to seyn / the bowes / were so brode
(base) Of stree first ther was leyd many a lode
(base) But how the fyr was maked vpon highte
(base) Ne eek the names / how the trees highte
(base) As ook / Fyrre / Birch / Asp / Alder / holm / popler
(base) Wylow / Elm / Plane / Assh / Box / Chestayn / lynde / laurer
(base) Mapul / Thorn / Beech / hasyl / Ew / whippultree
(base) How they were feld / shal nat been told for me
(base) Ne how the goddes / ronnen vp and doun
(base) Desherited / of hir habitacioun
(base) In which they woneden / in reste and pees
(base) Nymphes / Fawnes / and Amadrides
(base) Ne how the beestes / and the bryddes alle
(base) Fledden / for fered / whan the wode was falle
(base) Ne how the ground / agast was of the lyght
(base) That was nat wont to seen the sonne bright
(base) Ne how the fyr / was couched first with stree

div.l: (base) And thanne with grene wode / and spicerye
(base) And thanne with clooth of gold / and with perrye
(base) And gerlandes hangynge / ful of many a flour
(base) The Mirre / thencens / withal so greet sauour
(base) Ne how Arcite / lay among al this
(base) Ne what richesse / aboute the body is
(base) Ne how that Emelye / as was the gyse
(base) Putte in the fyr / of funeral seruyse
(base) Ne how she swowned / whan men made the fyr
(base) Ne what she spak ne what was hir desir
(base) Ne what Iuels / men in the fyr caste
(base) Whan that the fyr was greet and brente faste
(base) Ne how somme caste hir sheeld / and somme hir spere
(base) And of hir vestimentz / whiche that they were
(base) And coppes fulle of Milk and wyn and blood
(base) In to the fyr / that brente as it were wood
(base) Ne how the Grekys / with An huge route
(base) Thries ryden / al the fyr aboute
(base) Vpon the left hand / with a loud shoutynge
(base) And thries / with hir speres claterynge
(base) And thries / how the ladyes gonne crye
(base) And how that lad / was homward Emelye
(base) Ne how Arcite / is brent to Asshen colde
(base) Ne how that lychwake / was yholde
(base) Al thilke nyght ne how the grekys pleye
(base) The wake pleyes / ne kepe I noght to seye
(base) Who wrastleth best naked / with oille enoynt
(base) Ne who that baar hym best in no disioynt
(base) I wol nat tellen al / how they goon
(base) Hoom til Atthenes / whan the pleye is doon
(base) But shortly to the poynt than wol I wende
(base) And maken / of my longe tale an ende
(base) ¶ By proces / and by lengthe of certeyn yerys
(base) Al stynt is / the moornynge and the terys
(base) Of Grekys / by oon general assent
(base) Thanne semed me / ther was a parlement
(base) At Atthenes / vpon a certeyn point and caas
(base) Among the whiche pointes / yspoken was
(base) To haue / with certeyn contrees alliance

div.l: (base) And haue fully / of Thebans obeisance
(base) For which / this noble Theseus anon
(base) Leet senden / after gentil Palamon
(base) Vnwist of hym / what was the cause and why
(base) But in his blake clothes / sorwefully
(base) He cam at his comandement / in hye
(base) Tho sente Theseus / for Emelye
(base) ¶ Whan they were set and hust was al the place
(base) And Theseus / abiden hath a space
(base) Er any word / cam from his wise brest /
(base) His eyen sette he / ther as was his lest
(base) And with a sad visage / he siked stille
(base) And after that right thus he seyde his wille
(base) ¶ The firste moeuere / of the cause aboue
(base) Whan he first made / the faire cheyne of loue
(base) Greet was theffect and heigh was his entente
(base) Wel wiste he why / and what ther of he mente
(base) For with that faire cheyne of loue he boond
(base) The fyr the Eyr / the water / and the loond
(base) In certeyn boundes / that they may nat flee
(base) That same Prince / and that moeuere quod he
(base) Hath stabliced / in this wrecched world adoun
(base) Certeine dayes / and duracioun
(base) To al / that is engendred / in this place
(base) Ouer the which day / they may nat pace
(base) Al mowe they yet / tho dayes abregge
(base) Ther nedeth / noon auctoritee to allegge
(base) For it is proued / by experience
(base) But that me list declaren my sentence
(base) Thanne may men wel / by this ordre discerne
(base) That thilke moeuere / stable is and eterne
(base) Wel may men knowe / but it be a fool
(base) That euery part. is diryued from his hool
(base) For nature / hath nat taken his bigynnyng
(base) Of no partie / or of cantel of a thyng
(base) But of a thyng. that parfit is and stable
(base) Descendynge so / til it be corrumpable
(base) And therfore / for his wise purueiaunce
(base) He hath / so wel biset his ordinaunce
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) That specis of thynges / and progressions
(base) Shullen enduren / by successions
(base) And noght eterne / withouten any lye
(base) This maist thow vnderstonde / and seen at Iye
(base) ¶ Loo the ook / that hath so long a norisshynge
(base) Fro the tyme / that it first gynneth sprynge
(base) And hath so long a lyf / as ye may see
(base) Yet at the laste / wasted is the tree
(base) ¶ Considreth eek / how that the harde stoon
(base) Vnder oure foot on which we ryde and goon
(base) It wasteth / as it lyth by the weye
(base) The brode Ryuer / som tyme wexeth dreye
(base) The grete townes / se we wane and wende
(base) Thanne se ye / that al this thyng hath ende
(base) Of man and womman / se we wel also
(base) That nedeth / in oon of thise termes two
(base) This is to seyn / in youthe / or ellis age
(base) He moot be deed / the kyng as shal a page
(base) Som in his bed / som in the depe see
(base) Som in the large feeld / as ye may se
(base) Ther helpeth noght al gooth that ilke weye
(base) Thanne may I seyn / that al this thyng moot deye
(base) What maketh this but Iuppiter the kyng
(base) That is Prince / and cause of alle thyng
(base) Conuertyng al vnto his propre welle
(base) From which it is diryued sooth to telle
(base) And heer agayns / no creature on lyue
(base) Of no degree / auailleth for to stryue
(base) ¶ Thanne is it wisdom / as it thynketh me
(base) To maken vertu / of necessitee
(base) And take it wel / that we may nat eschue
(base) And nameliche / that to vs alle is due
(base) And who so gruccheth oght he dooth folye
(base) And rebel is / to hym that al may gye
(base) And certeinly / a man hath moost honour
(base) To dyen / in his excellence and flour
(base) Whan he is siker / of his goode name
(base) Thanne hath he doon / his freend ne hym no shame
(base) And gladder oghte / his freend been of his deeth
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Whan with honour / yolden is vp his breeth
(base) Than whan his name / apalled is for age
(base) For al forgeten is his vasselage
(base) Thanne is it best as for a worthy fame
(base) To dyen / whan he is best of name
(base) ¶ The contrarie of al this / is wilfulnesse
(base) Why grucchen we / why haue we heuynesse
(base) That goode Arcite / of chiualrie flour
(base) Departed is / with duetee / and with honour
(base) Out of this foule prison / of this lyf
(base) Why gruccheth heere / his cosyn and his wyf /
(base) Of his welfare / that loueth hem so weel
(base) Kan he hem thank nay god woot neuer a deel
(base) That bothe his soule / and eek hem self offende
(base) And yet they mowe / hir lustes nat amende
(base) ¶ What may I conclude / of this longe serye
(base) But after wo / I rede vs to be merye
(base) And thanken Iuppiter / of al his grace
(base) And er we / departen from this place
(base) I rede we make / of sorwes two
(base) O parfit Ioye / lastynge euere mo
(base) And loketh now / wher moost sorwe is her Inne
(base) Ther wol I first amenden and bigynne
(base) ¶ Suster quod he / this is my ful assent
(base) With al thauys / heer of my parlement
(base) That gentil Palamon / youre owene knyght
(base) That serueth yow / with wyl and herte myght
(base) And euere hath doon / syn ye first hym knewe
(base) That ye shal of youre grace vpon hym rewe
(base) And taken hym / for housbond and for lord
(base) Leen me youre hond / for this is oure acord
(base) Lat se now / of youre wommanly pitee
(base) He is / a kynges brother sone pardee
(base) And thogh he were / a poure Bachiler
(base) Syn he hath serued yow / so many a yeer
(base) And had for yow / so greet aduersitee
(base) It moste been considred / leueth me
(base) For gentil mercy / oghte to passen right
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) ¶ Thanne seyde he thus / to Palamon the knyght
(base) I trowe / ther nedeth litel sermonyng
(base) To make yow / assente to this thyng
(base) Com neer / and taketh youre lady by the hond
(base) Bitwixe hem / was maad anon the bond
(base) That highte matrymoigne / or mariage
(base) By al the conseil / and the Baronage
(base) And thus / with alle blisse / and melodye
(base) Hath Palamon / ywedded Emelye
(base) And god / that al this world hath wroght
(base) Sende hym his loue / that hath it deere aboght
(base) For now is Palamon / in alle wele
(base) Lyuynge in blisse / in richesse / and in heele
(base) And Emelye / hym loueth so tendrely
(base) And he / hir serueth so gentilly
(base) That was ther no word hem bitwene
(base) Of Ialousie / or any oother teene
(base) Thus endeth Palamon / and Emelye
(base) And god saue / al this faire compaignye Amen
(base) ¶ Here is ended / the knyghtes tale
Here bigynneth the prolog of the Millers tale
Whan that the knyght had thus his tale told
In al the compaynye nas ther yonge ne old
That he ne seyde it was a noble storie
And worthi for to be draw in to memorye
And namely the gentyles euꝰerychone
Our oost lough and seide so mote I gone
This goth aryght vnbokeled is the male
Lat see now who shal telle a nother tale
For truly the game is wel by gonne
Now telleth ye syr monke yif that ye konne
Som what to quyte wyth the knyghtes tale
¶ The Miller that for dronken was al pale
So that vnneth vpon his hors he sat
He nolde aualen neyther hood ne hat
Ne abiden no man of his curtesye
But in pilates vois he gan to crye
And swore by armes and blood and boones
I kan a noble tale for the nones
Wyth which I wol now quyte the knyght his tale
Our oost saw that he was dronke of ale
And seide Abyde Robyn leue brother
Som better man shal telle vs first another
Abyde and lat vs wyrke thriftyly
¶ By gooddes soule quod he that wil nat . I .
For I wol speke or elles go my weye
Our hoost answered telle on a deuelweye
Thow art a fool thi wit is ouꝰercome
¶ Now herkeneth quod the Miller al and some
But first I make a protestacyoun
That I am dronke I know it bi my soun
And therfore yif I mys speke or seye
Wite it the ale of Southwark I yow preye
For I wol telle a legend and a lyf
Bothe of a Carpenter and of his wyf .
How that a Clerke hath set the wryghtes cappe
The Reue answerd and seide stynt thi clappe
Lat be thi lewd dronken harlotrye
It is a synne and ek a gret folye
To appairen eny man or him defame
And eke to brynge wyues in swich name
Thow maist I nogh of othir thinges seyn
¶ This dronken Miller spak ful sone ageyn
And seide leue brother Oswald
Who hath no wyf he is no Cokewald
But that I sey for that thow art oon
There ben ful good wyues many oon
And euꝰere a thousand good ayeyns oon bad
That knowest thow wel but if that thow be madde
What art thow angry wyth my tale now
I haue a wyf ꝑperdee as wel as thow
I nolde for the oxen in my plogh
Take vp on me Moore than ynogh .
As demen of my self that thow were one
I wol beleue wel that I am none
And housbond sholde not ben inquisityf
Of goddes priuytees ne of his wyf
So he mow fynde goddes fisoun there
Of the remenaunt nedeth noght to enquere
¶ What shuld I sey but this Millere
He nolde his wordes for no man forbere
But tolde his cherles tale in his manere
Me thinketh yit that I shuld rehersen here
And therfore euꝰery gentil wyght I paray
For goddes loue demeth not that I say
Of euyl entent but for I mot reherce
Her tales al be thei bettr or werce
Or elles falsen som of my Matere
And ther fore who list it noght to here
Turne ouer the leef and chese another tale
For he shal fynde ynow grete and smale
¶ Of storial thing that toucheth gentylles
And ek Moralite and holynes
Blameth not me yif that ye chese amys
The Miller is a cherle I know wel this
So was the Reue and mony other moo
And harlotrye thei told bothe two .
Auyseth you now and put me oute of blame
And ek men shold noght make ernest of game .
Here endyth the prolog

Here endyth the prolog
Here bygynneth the Millers tale
Whilom ther was dwellyng in Oxenford
A ryche gnof that gestes held to bord
And of his crafte he was a carpentere
Wyth him ther was dwellyng a pore Scolere
Had lerned art but al his fantasye
Was torned for to lerne astrologye
And couth a certeyn of conclusiouns
To demen by interogaciouns
Yif that men asked him in certeyn houres
Whan that men shold haue droght or shoures
Or yif men asked him what shold falle
Of euꝰery thing I may noght ryken al
¶ The clerk was cleped hend nicholas
Of derne loue he couth and of Solas
And ther to he was slygh and ful piriuee
And lyke a mayden meke for to be
A chambre had he in that hostrye
Allone wyth outen any companye
Ful fetisly dyght wyth herbes sote
And he him self as is the rote
Of licoris or any setewale
His Almagest and bokes gret and smale
His Astrelabre longyng for his art
His augryme stoones leyen feire apart
On shelfes couched at his beddes hed
His pꝰersse couered wyth a mantil of red
And al aboue lay a gay sautrye .
On which he made on nyghtes melodye
So swetely that al the chambre rong
And Angelus ad virginem he song
And aftyr that he song the kynges note
Full ofte blessed was his mery throte
And thus this swete clerk his tyme spent
Aftyr his frendes fyndyng and his rent
¶ This Carpenter had wedded anew wyf
Which that he loued moore thanne his lyf
Of seuentene yer she was of Age
Gelous he was and hild hir narwe in A cage
For she was wilde and yong and he was olde
And demyd him self be lik a cokewald
He knew nat Caton for his wit was rude
That bad a man sholde wedde his Similitude
A man sholde wedden aftyr his estate
For youth and elde is often at debate
But sythen he was fallen in the snare
He moste endure as other folk his care
¶ Fair was this yonge wyf and ther wyth al
As eny wesil hir body gent and smal
A seint she wered y barred al of silk
A barme cloth as whit as any mylk .
Vp on hir lendes ful of many a gore
Whit was hir smok and brouded al bi fore
And ek by hynde on hir coler a boute
Of cole blak sylk wyth ynne and eke wtith oute
The tapes of hir whit volupere
Were of the same sute of hir colere
Hir filet brood of silke set ful hye
And sikerly she had a lykorous eye
Ful smale I pulled were hir browes two
And thei were bent as blake as eny slo
She was ful blisful more on to see
Than is the new pere Ionet tree
And softer than the wolle is of a wether
And by hir girdil hangeth a purs of leder
Tasseld wyth silk and perled wyth latoūn
In al this world to seken vp and doun
Ther nys no man that couth thenche
So gay apopelat or swich a wenche
Ful bryght was the shynyng of hir hew
Than in the tour the noble y forged new
But of hir song it was as loude and yern
As eny swalwe sittyng on the bern
And ther to she koude skippe and make game
As any kid or calf folwyng his dame
Hir mouthe was swete as bragot or meth
Hir hord of Appelles leyde in hey or heth
Wynsyng she was as is A Ioly colte
Long as a mast and vpryght as A bolte
A broche she bar vpon hir loue colere
As brod as is a boce of A bokelere
Hir shoon were lased on hir legges hye
She was a pirimerole A pigges nye
For eny lord to liggen in his bedde
Or yit for eny good yeman to wedde
¶ Now syr and eft syr so bifel the cas
That on A day this hende Nicholas
Fel wyth this wyf to rage and pleye
Whil that hir husbond was at osneye .
As clerkes ben ful sotil and ful queynt
And piriuely he caught hir by the queynt
And seide I wis but I haue my wille
Of derne loue of the lemman I spille
And held hir hard by the haunche bones
And seyde loue me lemman at ones
Ar I wol dyen al so god me saue
And she sprong as a colt doth in the traue
And wyth hir heed she wryed fast aweye
She seide I wol not kesse yow by my foye
Whi lat be that quod she lat be Nicholas
Or I wol crye out harrow and allas
Do way your handes for your curtesye
¶ This Nicholas gan mꝰercy for to crye
And spak so faire and profered him so fast
That she hir loue graunt him at last
And swore hir othe by seint thomas of kent
That she wolde be al at his commaundement
When that she myght hir leiser wel espye
Myn housbond is so ful of Ialousye
But that ye waite wel and be piriuee
I wot ryght wel y nam but ded quod she
Ye most be ful dern as in this cas
¶ Nay ther of care yow noght quod hend Nicholas
A clerk had litherly biset his while
But yif he couthe a carpenter bygyle
And thus thei ben acorded and I sworn
To waite a tyme as I haue seide biforn
¶ Whan Nicholas had doon this euꝰerydel
And thakked hir aboute hir lendes wel
He kist hir swete and taketh his sawtrye
And pleyeth fast and maketh melodye
¶ Than fil it thus that to the parysh chirche
Cristes owne werkes for to worche
This good wyf went on an holy day
Hir forhed shone as bryght as eny day
So was it wesshen whan that she laft hir werke
¶ Now was ther of the parysh chirche a clerk
The which that cleped was absolon
Crulled was his heer and as the gold it shon
And strowted as a fanne large and brode
Ful streight and euene lay his ioly shode
In hosen rede he went fetisly
I clad hewas ful smal and ꝓproprely
Al in a kyrtel of whit wachet
Ful fair and thik be the poyntes set
And ther vp on he had agay surplice
As whit as is the blossom of the ryse
A mery cheld he was so god me saue
Wel coude he lat blood and clip and shaue
And make a chartre of lond or Aquytaunce
¶ In twenti maners couth he trippe and daunce
Aftyr the Scole of Oxenford tho
And wyth his legges casten to and fro
And pley songes vpon a smale ribible
Ther to he song som tyme aloude quynyble
And as wel couth he pley vpon a gyterne
In al the toun nas brewhous ne tauerne
That he ne vseth it wyth his solas
Ther any gaylard tapster was
But soth to sey he was som del swaymous
Of fartyng and speche daungerous
¶ This absolon that Ioly was and gay
Goth wyth censer on the holy day
Sensyng the wyues of the parysh fast
And many a louely loke he on hem cast
And namly on this carpenteres wyf
To loke on hir him thought a mery lyf
She was propre and swete and likerous
I dar wel say yif she had ben amous
And he A cat he wold hir hent Anon
¶ This parysh clerk this ioly absolon
Hath in his hert swych a loue longyng
That of no wyfe toke he non offeryng
For curtesye he seide he nolde non
The moone whan it was nyght ful bryght shon
And absoloūn his giterne hath I take
For paramours he thought for to wake
And forth he goth iolyf and amerous
Til he come to the carpenteres hous
A litil aftyr the cokkes had y crowe
He dressyd him vp by a shop wyndowe
That was vp on the carpenters walle
Hye settyng his vois gentil and smalle
He seide dere lady yif thi wil bee
I prey yow that ye wol rew on me
Ful wel accordyng to his gitꝰeryng
This Carpenter awook and herd hym syng
And spak vn to his wyf and seide anon
What Alison herest thow not absolon
That chaunteth thus vnder our boures walle
And she answerd and seide hir husbond therwtith alle
Yis god wot Iohn I here it euꝰerydeel
¶ This passeth forth what wol ye bettr than wel
From day to day this ioly absolon
So loueth hir that he is wo bigon
He walweth al the nyght And Al the day
He kembeth his lokkes brode and made him gay
He woweth hir by menes and brokage
He swore he wolde be hir verrey page
And syngen brokkynges as A nyghtyngale
He sent hir pynnes and eke spyced Ale
And waufours pipyng hote out of the glede
For she was of the toun he profered hir mede
For Som folk wol be wonwed for richesse
And som for strokes and Som for gentilnesse
¶ Som tyme to shew his lyghtenes and his maistrye
He pleyde heroude vp on a AScaffald hye
But what Auayleth him in this cas .
She loueth so this hende Nicholas
That absolon may blow the bukkes horn
He ne hed for his labour but a scorn
And thus she maketh absolon hir ape
And al this ernest torneth in to A Iape
Ful sothe is this ꝓprouerbe and no lye
Men seith ryght thus al weye the nye slye
Maketh the fer leef to be looth
Whether that absolon be wood or wroth
Be cause that he was from hir syght
This nyght Nicholas stood in his lyght
¶ Now bere the wel thow hende Nicholas
For Absolon may wepe and synge allas
And so bifel that on a seturday
This carpenter was goon to Osnay
And hende Nicholas and absolon
Accorded ben to this conclusion
That Nicholas shal shape him awyle
This sely Ialouse husbond to bigyle
And yif so be this game wend aryght
She shold slepe in his armes al nyght
For this was hir desire and his al so
And ryght anon wyth outen wordes mo
This Nicholas wolde no lenger tarye
But doth ful softe to his chambre carye
Bothe mete and drynke for a day or twey
And to hir husbond bad hir for to sey
Yif that he axed aftyr Nicholas
She shold sey she wist neuer where he was
Of al the day she sagh him noght wyth eye
She trowed that he was in som maladye
For for no crie hir mayde couth him calle
He nold answere for nothing that myght falle
¶ This passeth forth al thilk Seturday
That Nicholas still in his chamber lay
And ete and slepe and did whan him list
Til sonday that the son goth to rest
¶ This sely Carpenter hath so gret marueyll
Of Nicholas what thing myght hym ayll
And seide I am a dred by seint thomas
It stant not aryght wyth Nicholas
God shelde that he dyde sodeynly
This world is now ful fikel sykerly
I saw to day A corps y bere to chirche
That now on monday last I saw him wyrche
¶ Go vp quod he to his knaue Anon
Clepe at his dore or knok wyth a ston
Loke how it is and telle me boldlye
¶ This knaue goth him vp ful sturdylye
And atte chambre dore whil that he stode
He cried and knokked as that he were wode
What how what do ye maistyr Nicholay
How may ye slepe Al the longe day
¶ But al for noght he herd neuer a word
An hole he founde ful low vpon A bord
Ther as the Catte was wonte in to crepe
And atte hole loked in ful depe
And atte last he had of him a syght
This Nicholas Sat euyr gapyng vpryght
As he had loked on the new mone
And doun he goth and tolde his maister sone
In what arraye he saugh this ilke man
This Carpenter to blessyn him bygan
And seide help vs seint fredeswyde
A man wot litel what him shal bityde
This man is fallen wyth his astronomye
In Som woodnes or in som Agonye
I thought ay wel how that it sholde be
Men sholde not know of goddes piriuyte
Y blessed be alwey alewdeman
That not but only his bileue kan
So ferd a nother clerk wyth astronomye
He wille in the feldes for to prye
Vpon the sterres whan shold by falle
Til he was in a marble pit y falle .
He sagh not that yit by seint Thomas
Me reweth soore of hende Nicholas
He shal be rated of his studying
Yif that I may by Ihūn heuene kyng
¶ Gete me a Staff that I may vndershore
Whiles that thow Robyn heuest vp the dore
He shal oute of his studying I gesse
And to the chambre dore he gan him dresse
His knaue was a strong carle for the nones
And by the haspe he haue it vp at ones .
And in the floor the dore fil anon
This Nicholas sat ay as still as ston
And gaped vpward in the eyre
This carpenter wende he were in dispeyre
And hente him by the sholdres myghtyly
And shok him hard and cride pitously
What Nicholay what how loke a doun
A wake and thinke on cristes passioun
Y crowche the from Elues and from wyghtes
Ther wyth the nyght spel seide he Anon ryghtes
On four halues of the hous About
And on the thresshfold at the dore wyth out
Ihūn criste and seint benedight
Blesse this hous from euꝰery wykked wyght
For the nyghtes uerye the whit paternoster
Where wentestow seint petres suster
And at the last this hend Nicholas
Gan for to syke soore and seid allas
Shal al the world be lost eft sones now
¶ This Carpenter answered what seistow
What thenke on god as we men don that swynke
¶ This Nicholas answerd fecche me drynke
And aftyr wil I speke in piriuyte
Of thing that toucheth me and the
I wol telle it no nother man certayn
¶ This carpenter goth doun and comth Agayn
And broght of myghty Ale A large quarte
And whan that ech of hem had dronke hir part
This Nicholas his dore fast shette
And doun the Carpenter by him sette
¶ And seyde Iohn myn oost lief and dere
Thow shalt vpon thi trouth swere me here
That to no wight thow shalt this counseil wrye
For it is cristes counseil that I seye
And yif thow telle it man thow art for lore
For this vengeaunce thow shalt haue therfore
That yif thow wrye me thou shalt be wood
¶ Nay criste forbede it for his holy blood
Quod tho this sely man I nam but labbe
Ne thogh I sey y nam not lief to gabbe
Sey what thow wolt I shal yt neuer telle
To child ne wyf by hym that harryed helle
Now Iohn quod this Nicholas I wol not lye
I haue y founde in myn astrologie
As I haue loked in the mone bryght
That now on monday next at quarter nyght
Shall falle a reyne and that so wylde and wood
That half so gret was neuer Noees flood
This world he seide in lasse than in an hour
Shal be al dreynt so hidous is the shour
Thus shal mankynde drenche and lese hir lyf .
¶ This carpenter answerd and seide allas my wyf
And shal she drenche Allas myn Alisoun
For sorwe of this he fel almost a doun
And seide is ther no remedye in this cas
¶ Whi yis for god quod hende Nicholas
If thow wolt wyrken aftyr loore and reed
Thow maist not wyrken aftyr thyn owne heed
For thus seith Salamon that was ful trewe
Worke al bi counseil and þu shalt nat rewe
And yif thow werken wolt by good counseil
I vndyrtake wyth outen mast or seil
Yit shal I saue hir and me and thee
Hastow not herd how saued was noe
Whan that our lord had warned him biforn
That Al the world wyth watyr sholde be lorn
¶ Yis quod this Carpenter ful yore Ago
¶ Hastow not herd quod Nicholas Also
The sorwe of Noe wyth his felawshep
Er that he myght gete his wyfe to shep
Him hed be leuer I dar wel vndertake
At thilk tyme than Al his wheteres blake
That she hadde had A ship hir selue Allone
And therfore wostow what is best to done
This asketh hast and of An hastyf thing
Men may noght preche ne makyn tarying
¶ Anon go gete vs fast in to this ynne
A knedyng trogh or elles a kemelynne
For ech of vs but look that they be large
In which we mowen swymmen as in a barge
And haue ther Inne vitaille suffisaunt
But for a day fye on the remenant
The water shall aslake an gon away
Aboute pirime vp on the next day
But Robyn may not wit this thi knaue
Ne eke thi mayde Gille I may not Saue
Axe noght whi for thogh thow axe me
I wol not tellen goddes pryuyte
Suffiseth the but yif thi wyttes madde
To han As gret A garace as Noe hadde
Thi wyf shal I wel sauen out of doute
Go thow thi wey and spede the here aboute
But whan thow hast for her and the and me
Y geten vs thise knedyng tubbes thre
Than shaltow hem in the roof ful hie
That no man of our purueyaunce espie
And whan thow thus hast don as I haue seide
And hast oure vitaille faire in hem y leyde
And eke an axe to smyte the corde A two
Whan that the water comth that we may go
And breke an hole an hyegh vpon the gable
Vn to the gardeynward ouer the stable
That we may frely passen forth our wey
Whan that the gret shour is goon awey
Thanne shaltow swymme as murye I vndertake
As doth the white doke aftyr the drake
Thanne wol I clepe how Alison how Iohn
Be mery for the flood shal passe anon
And thow wolt seyn hail maistre Nicholay
Good morwe I se the wel for it is day
And thanne shall we be lordes all our lyf
Of Al the worlde as noe and his wyf
¶ But of o thing I warne the ful ryght
Be wel auysed on that ilke nyght
That we ben entred in to the shippes bord
That non of vs ne speke noght aword
Ne sleep ne crye but ben in his preyere
For hit is goddes owne heest dere
Thi wyf and thow mote hang fer a twynne
For that bitwix yow shal be no Synne
No moore in lokyng than ther shal in dede
This ordinaunce is seyde so god the spede
To Morwe at nyght whan men ben al A sleepe
In to our knedyng tubbes wol we crepe
And sitten there Abydyng goddes garace
Go now thi wey I haue no lenger space
To make of this no lenger tarying
Men seien thus sende the wyse and sey no thing
Thow art so wys it nedeth the nat teche
Go saue our lyf and that I the beseche
¶ This sely Carpenter goth forth his wey
Ful oft he seyde Allas and welawey
And to his wyf he told his priuete
And she was war and knew it bet than he
What Al this queynte cas was for to seye
But natheles she ferd as she wold deye
¶ And seide Allas go forth thi wey anon
Helpe vs to scape or we ben ded echon
I am thi trew verry wedded wyf
Go dere spouse and helpe to saue our lyf
¶ Lo which A gret thing is affeccion
Men may demen of ymaginacion
So depe may impressioun be take
This sely Carpenter bigynneth to quake
Him thinketh verraylich that he may se
Noes flood come walowyng on the see
To drenchen Alisoun his hony dere
He wepeth waileth and maketh sori chere
He siketh wyth ful many a sory swogh
And goth and getyth him a knedyng trogh
And aftyr a tubbe and a kymelyn
And priuely he sent hem to his In
And hinge hem in the rof in piriuetee
His awne hand he made laddres thre
To clymben by the ronges and the stalkes
Vn to the tubbes hangyng in the balkes .
And hem vitailled both trogh and tubbe
Wyth bred and chese And good ale in A Iubbe
Suffysing right y nogh as for a day
But er that he had mad al this array
He sent his knaue and eke his wenche Also
Vpon his nede to london for to go
And on the monday whan it drogh to nyght
He shette his dore wyth outen candil lyght
And dressed al thing as it shold be
And shortly vp thei clomben al thre
Thei seten still wel a forlong way
¶ Now pater noster clum seyde Nicholay
And clum quod Iohn and clum seide Alisoun
This Carpenter seide his deuocioun
And stil he sit and biddeth his preyere
Awaityng on the reyne yif he it here
¶ The deed sleep for wery bisinesse
Fil on this carpenter ryght as I gesse
Aboute corfue tyme or litel more
For trauaille of his gost he groneth sore
And eft he routeth for his hed mys lay
Doun of the laddre stalketh Nicholay
And Alison ful softe a doun she spedde
Wyth outen wordes mo thei gon to bedde
Ther as the carpenter is wont to lye
Ther was the reuel and the melodye
And thus lyen Alison and Nicholas
In bisines or murthe and in solas
Til that the belle of laudes gan to rynge
And freres in the chauncel gon synge
This parysh clerk this amorous absolon
That is for loue alwey so wo bigon
Vp on the monday was at Osneye
Wyth companye him to disport and pleye
And axed vp on cas a cloysterere
Ful pryuely aftyr Iohn the carpentere
And drogh him apart out of the chirche
And seyde I noot I sagh him here noght wyrche
Syth seturday I trow that he be went
For tymber ther as our Abbot hath him sent
For he is wont for tymber for to go
And dwellen at the grange a day or two
Or elles he is at his hous certeyn
Where that he be I kan not soothely seyn
¶ This absolon ful ioly was and lyght
And thoght now is tyme to wake A nyght
For Sikerly I sagh him noght stiryng
About his dore syn day bigan to springe
¶ So mote I thryue I shall at Cokkes crowe
Ful priuely knokken at his wyndowe
That stant ful low vpon his bour wall
To Alison now wol I tellen all
My loue longyng for yit I shal nat mysse
That at the lest wey I shall hir kysse
Some Maner confort shal I haue parfay
My mouth hath icched al this longe day
That is a signe of kyssyng at the leest
Al nyght me met eeke that I was at a feest
Ther fore I wol go slepe an hour or tweye
And al the nyght than wol I wake and pleye
Whan that the first cok hath crowe anon
Vp rist this ioly louer absolon
And him arrayeth gay and poynt deuys
But first he cheweth greynes and licoris
To smellen swete or he had kembd his heer
Vndyr his tong a trew loue he beer
For therby wend he to be gracious
He rometh to the Carpenters hous
And stil he stont vnder the shot wyndow
Vnto his brest it raught it was so low
And softe he coughteth wyth a semy soun
What do ye hony combe swete Alisoun
My faire brid my swete Cynomome
A wake lemman myn and speke wyth me
Wel litel thinken ye vpon my wo
That for your loue I swete ther I go
No wondyr is thogh that I swelt and swete
I moorne as dooth a lamb aftyr the tete
I wis lemman I haue swich loue longyng
That like a tirtel trew is my moornyng
I may nat ete na moore than a mayde
Go fro the wyndow Iakke fool she saide
As helpe me god it wil not be come bame
I loue a nother and elles I were to blame
Wel bet than the bi Ihu absolon
Go forth thi wey or I wol cast a ston
And let me slepe a twenty dyuelwey
Allas quod absolon and welawey
That trew loue was euꝰer so euel biset
Than kys me syn that yt may be no bet
For Ihus loue and for the loue of me
Woltow thanne go thi wey therwyth quod She
Ye certes lemman quod this absolon
Thanne make the redy quod she I come anon
This absolon doun set him on his knees
And seide I am A lord at al degrees
For aftyr this I hope ther cometh moore
Lemman thi grace and swete bridde thyn ore
The wyndew she vndoth and that in hast
Haue do quod she com of and spede the fast
Lest that our neigbours the espye
This absolon gan wipe his mouth ful drye
Derk was the nyght as pich or as the cole
And at the wyndow oute she put hir hole
And absolon him fil no bet ne wers
But wyth his mouth he kiste hir naked ers
Ful sauourly er he wer war of this
Abak he stert and thought it was amys
For wel he wist a womman hath no berde
He felt a thing al rogh and long y herd
And seide fi allas what haue y do
Te he quod she and clapt the wyndow to
And absolon goth forth a sory paas
A berd aberd seide hende Nicholas
By goddes corpus this goth fair and wel
This sely absolon herd euꝰerydel .
And on his lippe he gan for anger byte
And to him self he seide I shall the quyte
Who rubbeth now who frotheth now his lippes
Wyth dust wyth sond wyth strow wtith cloth wtith chippes
But absolon that seith ful ofte Allas
Mi saule betake vnto Sathanas
But me were leuer than Al this toun quod he
Of this despite awroken for to be
Allas quod he allas I ne hadde I bleynt
His hot loue was colde and I queynt
For fro the tyme that he had kist hir ers
Of paramours he rought not a kers
For he was heelid of his maladye
Ful ofte paramours he gan de fye
And weep as doth a childe that ys y bete
A softe pas he went him ouꝰer the strete
Vn til a smyth men clepeth Daun Gerneys
That in his forge smythed plow herneys
He sharpeth share and cultree bisily
This absolon knokketh al esily
And seide vnto Gerueys and that Anon
What who artow it am . I Absolon
What Absolon what cristes swete tree
Whi rise ye so rathe ey benedicitee
What eyleth yow som gay gerle god it wot
Hath broght yow thus vpon the viritoot
Be seint note ye woot wel what I mene
This absolon ne rought not a bene
Of al this pley ne word ayeyn he yaf
He had moore towe on his distaf
Than Gerueys knew and seide frend so dere
That hote cultre in the chymney heere
As lene it me I haue ther wyth to done
¶ I wol bryng it the agayn ful sone
Gerueys answerd certes were it gold
Or in a poke nobles al vntold
Thow sholdest haue as I am trew smyth
Ey crystes foo what wol ye do ther wyth
Ther of quod absolon be as be may
I shall wel telle it the Another day
He caught the cultur by the corde stele
Ful softe oute at the dore he gan to stele
And went vn to the Carpenteres walle
He cougheth first and knokketh ther wyth alle
Vpon the wyndow ryght as he did yer
This Alison answerd who is ther
That knokketh so I warant him a theef
Nay nay quod he god wot my swete leef
I am thin absolon thi derlyng
Of gold quod he I haue the brought aryng
My moder yaf it me so god me saue
Ful fyn it is and ther to wel I graue
This wol I yeuen the yif thow me kysse
This Nicholas was rysen vp to pisse
And thought he wolde amende al the iape
He sholde kys his ers er that he scape
And vp the wyndow did he hastyly
And oute his ers he putteth piriuely
Ouer the buttok to the haunche boon
And ther wyth spak this clerk this absolon
Speke swete brid I noot not where thow art
This Nicholas anon let fle a fart
As gret as it had ben a thonder dent
That wyth the strook he was wel nygh I brent
And he was redy wyth his yren hoot
And Nicholas in the ers he smoot
Of goth the skynne an handbred aboute
The hote cultur brend so his toute
That forthe smert he wende for to dye
As he were wood for wo he gan to crye
Helpe water water hep for goddes herte
This Carpenter out of his slombre sterte
And herd on crye water as he were wood
And thought allas now comyth Noes flood
He set him vp wyth out wordes moo
And wyth his axe he smote the corde a twoo
A doun goth al he founde neither to selle
Ne bred ne Ale til he cam to the celle
Vp on the floore and there a swowne he lay
Vp sterte hir alison and Nicholay
And criden out harrow in the strete
The neigbours bothe smale and grete
In ronnen for to gauren on this man
That aswow lay bothe pale and wan
For whith the fal he brosten had his arm
But stond he most vnto his owne harm
¶ For whan he was anon bore doun
Wyth hende Nicholas and wyth alisoun
They tolden euꝰery man that he was wood
He was agast so of Nowelys flood
Thurgh fantasie that of his vanitee
He had y boght him knedyng tubbes thre
And had hem honged in the rofe aboue
And that he preyde hem for goddes loue
To sitten in the roof per compaignye
The folk gan laughen at his fantasye
In to the roof they kiken and thei gape
And turned al this harm vnto a iape
For what so this carpenter answerde
It was for noght no man his resoon herde
Wyth othes grete he was so sworne adoun
That he was holden wood in al the toun
For euery clerk anon ryght heeld wyth other
He seide the man was wood my leue brother
And euꝰery wyght gan laughen of this stryf
Thus swyued was the Carpenteres wyf
For all his kepyng and his Ialousye
And absolon hath kyst hir nether eye
And Nicholas is scalled in the towte .
This tale is doon and god Saue al the route .

(base) To whom answerde Tiburce o suster deere
(base) Ne seydestow right now in this manere
(base) Ther nys but o god lord in sothfastnesse
(base) And now of thre how maystow bere witnesse
(base) That shal I telle quod she er I go
(base) Right as a man hath Sapiences thre
(base) Memorie engyn and intellect also
(base) So in o beynge of diuinytee
(base) Thre persones may ther right wel be
(base) Tho gan she hym ful bisily to preche
(base) Of cristes come and of his peynes teche
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) And manye pointes of his passioun
(base) How goddes sone in this world was withholde
(base) To doon mankynde pleyn remyssioun
(base) That was ybounde in synne and cares colde
(base) Al this thyng she vnto Tiburce tolde
(base) And after this Tiburce in good entente
(base) With Valerian to Pope Vrban he wente
(base) That thanked god and with glad herte and light
(base) He cristned hym and made hym in that place
(base) Parfit in his lernyng goddes knyght
(base) And after this Tiburce gat swich grace
(base) That euery day he say in tyme and space
(base) The Aungel of god and euery maner boone
(base) That he god axed it was sped ful soone
(base) It were ful hard by ordre for to seyn
(base) How many wondres Ihesus for hem wroghte
(base) But at the laste to tellen short and pleyn
(base) The sergeantz of the town of Rome hem soghte
(base) And hem biforn Almache the Prefect broghte
(base) Which hem opposed and knew al hir entente
(base) And to the ymage of Iubiter hem sente
(base) And seyde who so wol nat sacrifise
(base) Swap of his heed this is my sentence heer
(base) Anon thise martirs that I yow deuyse
(base) Oon Maximus that was an Officer
(base) Of the Prefectes and his Corniculer
(base) Hem hente and whan he forth the Seintes ladde
(base) Hymself he weep for pitee that he hadde
(base) Whan Maximus hadde herd the Seintes loore
(base) He gat hym of the tormentours leue
(base) And ladde hem to his hous withoute moore
(base) And with hir prechyng er that it were eue
(base) They gonnen fro the tormentours to reue
(base) And fro Maxime and fro his folk echone
(base) The false feith to trowe in god allone
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Cecile cam whan it was woxen nyght
(base) With preestes that hem cristned alle yfeere
(base) And afterward whan day was woxen light
(base) Cecile hym seyde with a ful stedefast cheere
(base) Now cristes owene knyghtes leue and deere
(base) Cast al awey the werkes of derknesse
(base) And armeth yow in armure of brightnesse
(base) Ye han for sothe ydoon a greet bataille
(base) Youre cours is doon youre feith han ye conserued
(base) Goth to the corone of lyf that may nat faille
(base) The rightful Iuge which that ye han serued
(base) Shal yeue it yow as ye han it disserued
(base) And whan this thyng was seyd as I deuyse
(base) Men ledde hem forth to doon the sacrifise
(base) But whan they weren to the place broght
(base) To tellen shortly the conclusioun
(base) They nolde encense ne sacrifise right noght
(base) But on hir knees they setten hem adoun
(base) With humble herte and sad deuocioun
(base) And losten bothe hir heuedes in the place
(base) Hir soules wenten to the kyng of grace
(base) This Maximus that say this thyng bityde
(base) With pitous teerys tolde it anon right
(base) That he hir soules saugh to heuene glyde
(base) With Aungeles ful of cleernesse and of light
(base) And with his word conuerted many a wight
(base) For which Almachius dide hym so bete
(base) With whippe of leed til he his lyf gan lete
(base) Cecile hym took and buryed hym anon
(base) By Tiburce and Valerian softely
(base) With Inne hir buryyng place vnder the stoon
(base) And after this Almachius hastily
(base) Bad hise Ministres fecchen openly
(base) Cecilie so that she myghte in his presence
(base) Doon sacrifice and Iubiter encense
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) But they conuerted at hir wise loore
(base) Wepten ful sore and yauen ful credence
(base) Vnto hir word and cryden moore and moore
(base) Crist goddes sone withouten difference
(base) Is verray god this is al oure sentence
(base) That hath so good a seruant hym to serue
(base) This with o voys we trowen thogh we sterue
(base) Almachius that herde of this doynge
(base) Bad fecchen Cecilie that he myghte hir se
(base) And alderfirst lo this was his axynge
(base) What maner womman artow quod he
(base) I am a gentil womman born quod she
(base) I axe thee quod he thogh it the greue
(base) Of thy religioun and of thy bileue
(base) Ye han bigonne youre question folily
(base) Quod she that wolden two answeres conclude
(base) In o demande ye axed lewedly
(base) Almachie answerde vnto that similitude
(base) Of whennes comth thyn answeryng so rude
(base) Of whennes quod she whan that she was freyned
(base) Of conscience and of good feith vnfeyned
(base) Almachius seyde ne takestow noon hede
(base) Of my power and she answerde hym this
(base) Youre myght quod she ful litel is to drede
(base) For euery mortal mannes power nys
(base) But lyk a bladdre ful of wynd ywys
(base) For with a nedles point whan it is blowe
(base) May al the boost of it be leyd ful lowe
(base) Ful wrongfully bigonne thow quod he
(base) And yet in wrong is al thy perseueraunce
(base) Wostow nat how oure myghty princes free
(base) Han thus comanded and maad ordinaunce
(base) That euery cristen wight shal han penaunce
(base) But if that he his cristendom withseye
(base) And goon al quyt if he wol it reneye
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Youre Prynces erren as youre nobleye dooth
(base) Quod tho Cecile and with a wood sentence
(base) Ye make vs gilty and is nat sooth
(base) For ye that knowen wel oure Innocence
(base) For as muche as we doon a reuerence
(base) To crist and for we bere a cristen name
(base) Ye putte on vs a cryme and eek a blame
(base) But we that knowen thilke name so
(base) For vertuous we may it nat withseye
(base) Almache answerde chees oon of thise two
(base) Do sacrifice or cristendom reneye
(base) That thow mowe now escapen by that weye
(base) At which this holy blisful faire mayde
(base) Gan for to laughe and to the Iuge she sayde
(base) O Iuge confus in thy nycetee
(base) Wiltow that I reneye Innocence
(base) To maken me a wikked wight quod she
(base) Lo he dissimuleth heere in audience
(base) He stareth and woodeth in his aduertence
(base) To whom Almachius vnsely wrecche
(base) Ne wostow nat how fer my myght may strecche
(base) Han noght oure myghty princes to me yeuen
(base) Ye bothe power and auctoritee
(base) To maken folk to dyen or to lyuen
(base) Why spekestow so prowdly thanne to me
(base) I speke noght but stedefastly quod she
(base) Nat proudly for I seye as for my syde
(base) We haten dedly thilke vice of pryde
(base) And if thow drede nat a sooth to here
(base) Thanne wol I shewe al openly by right
(base) That thow hast maad a ful greet lesyng here
(base) Thow seist thy princes han thee yeuen myght
(base) Bothe for to sleen and for to quyken a wight
(base) Thow that ne mayst but oonly lyf byreue
(base) Thow hast noon oother power ne no leue
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) But thow mayst seyn thy princes han thee maked
(base) Ministre of deeth for if thow speke of me
(base) Thow lyest for thy power is ful naked
(base) Do wey thy boldnesse seyde Almachius tho
(base) And sacrifice to oure goddes er thow go
(base) I recche nat what wrong that thow me profre
(base) For I kan suffre it as a Philosophre
(base) But thilke wronges may I nat endure
(base) That thow spekest of oure goddes here quod he
(base) Cecilie answerde o nyce creature
(base) Thow seydest no word syn thow spak to me
(base) That I ne knew therwith thy nycetee
(base) And that thow were in euery maner wise
(base) A lewed Officer a veyn Iustise
(base) Ther lakketh no thyng to thyne outter eyen
(base) That thow nart blynd for thyng that we seen alle
(base) That is a stoon that men may wel espien
(base) That ilke stoon a god thow wolt it calle
(base) I rede thee lat thyn hand vpon it falle
(base) And taste it wel and stoon thow shalt it fynde
(base) Syn that thow seest nat with thyne eyen blynde
(base) It is a shame that the peple shal
(base) So scornen thee and laughe at thy folye
(base) For comenly men woot it wel oueral
(base) That myghty god is in hise heuenes hye
(base) And thise ymages wel thow mayst espye
(base) To thee ne to hem self mowe noght profite
(base) For in effect they be nat worth a myte
(base) Thise and swiche othere seyde she
(base) And he weex wrooth and bad men sholde hir lede
(base) Hoom til hir hous and in hir hous quod he
(base) Bren hire right in a Bath of flambes rede
(base) And as he bad right so was doon the dede
(base) For in a Bath they gonne hire faste shetten
(base) And nyght and day greet fyr they vnder betten
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) The longe nyght and eek a day also
(base) For al the fyr and eek the Bathes hete
(base) She sat al coold and feeled no wo
(base) It made hir nat o drope for to swete
(base) But in that Bath hir lyf she moste lete
(base) For he Almachius with a ful wikke entente
(base) To sleen hire in the Bath his sonde sente
(base) Thre strokes in the nekke he smoot hire tho
(base) The tormentour but for no maner chaunce
(base) He myghte noght smyte al hir nekke atwo
(base) And for ther was that tyme an ordinaunce
(base) That no man sholde doon man swich penaunce
(base) The ferthe strook to smyten softe or soore
(base) This tormentour ne dorste do namoore
(base) But half deed with hir nekke ycoruen there
(base) He lefte hir lye and on his wey he went
(base) The cristen folk whiche that aboute hire were
(base) With shetes han the blood ful faire yhent
(base) Thre dayes lyued she in this torment
(base) And neuere cessed hem the feith to teche
(base) That she hadde fostred hem she gan to preche
(base) And hem she yaf hir moebles and hir thyng
(base) And to the Pope Vrban bitook hem tho
(base) And seyde I axed this of heuene kyng
(base) To han respit thre dayes and namo
(base) To recommende to yow er that I go
(base) Thise soules lo and that I myghte do Werche
(base) Here of myn hous perpetuelly a cherche
(base) Seint Vrban with hise deknes pryuely
(base) The body fette and buryed it by nyghte
(base) Among hise othere Seintes honestly
(base) Hir hous the chirche of Seinte Cecilie highte
(base) Seint Vrban halwed it as he wel myghte
(base) In which in to this day in noble wyse
(base) Men doon to crist and to his Seinte seruyse

div.l: Here bigynneth the prologe of the Clerkes tale of Oxonford
Sire clerk of Oxenford our hoost sayde
Ye ride as stylle and coy as doth a mayde
Were new spoused sittyng atte borde
This day ne herd I of your tonge a worde
I trowe ye studye abouten some sophyme
But Salamon seyth that euꝰery thing hath tyme
For goddes sake as beeth of better chere
It is no tyme for to studien here
Telle vs som mery tale bi your fey
For what man that is entred in a pley
He needes must vnto the pley assent
But pꝰercheth nat as freres don in lent
To make vs for our olde synnes wepe
Ne that thi tale make vs nat to slepe .
Telle vs som thing of auentures
Your termes your coloures and figures
Kepe hem in stoore til so be ye endite
Hy style as whan that men to kyng wryte
Speketh so pleyn at this tyme we yow praye
That we may vnderstande what ye saye
This worthi clerk benygly answerde
Oste quod he I am vnder your yerde
Ye han of vs as now the gouꝰernance
And therfore wolde I do yow obeisance
As fer as reson axith hardily
I wol you telle a tale which that I
Lerned at padow of a worthi clerke
As preued bi his wordes and his werk
He is now ded and nayled in his cheste
I prey to god so yeue his soule reste .
Franceys petrark the laureat poete
Hight this clerk whos retorik swete
Enlumyned al ytaile of poetrye
As lynyan dide of philosophie
Or lawe or other art particuler
But deth that wol not suffre vs dwellen here
But as it were a twynclyng of an ye
He bothe hath slayn and al shol we dye
But forth to tellen of this worthi man
That taught me this tale as I bigan
I sey that first he wyth hye style enditeth
Or he the body of his tale wryteth
A prophemye in the which destruyeth he
Pemond and Saluces the contre
And speketh of appenyn the hilles hye
That ben the boundes of westlumbardye
And of a mount Vesulus in specyal
Wher as the poo out of a welle smal
Taketh his first spryngynge and his sours
That Estward ay encreseth in his cours
To emeleward to ferare and Venyse
The which a longe thing were to deuyse
And trewly as to my Iuggement
Me thinketh it a thing inpartynent
Sauf that he wol conueyen his matere
But this his tale which that ye may here
Here endeth the prologe
Here bigynneth the Clerkes tale of Oxenforde
Ther is ryght at the west syde of ytaille
Doun atte rote of vesulus the colde
A lusty playn habondant of vitaille
There many a toun and tour thou maist biholde
That founded were in tyme of fadres olde
And many a nother delitable sight
And Saluces this noble countre hight
A markys whilom lord was of that lond
As were his worthi eldres hem bifore
And obesant ay redy to his hond
Were al his lieges bothe lasse and moore
Thus in delite he lyueth and hath doon yore
By loued and dred thrugh fortune
Bothe of his lordes and of his Commune
Ther wyth he was to speken as of lynage
The gentileste I born of lumbardye
A fair ꝑpersoon and stronge and yong of age
And ful of honour and of Curtesye
Discret ynow his contre for to gye
Sauf in sum thinges that he was to blame
And Wauter was this yonge lordes name
I blame him thus he concidred noght
In tyme comyng what myght him bityde
But on his lust pꝰersent was al his thought
And for to hauke and hunt on euꝰery syde
Wel ny al other cures let he slide
And eke he nolde and that was werst of alle
Wedde no wyf for aught that may befalle
Only that poynt his peple bar so soore
That flokmele on a day to him they went
And on of hem that wisest was of loore
Or elles that the lord wold best assent
That he sholde telle him what the peple ment
Or elles coude he shew wel swich matere
He to the Marquys seyde as ye shal here
O noble Marquys your humanyte
Assureth vs and yeueth vs hardynesse
As ofte as tyme is of necessite
That we to yow may telle our heuynesse
Accepteth lord thanne of your gentilnesse
That we wyth pitous hert vnto yow pleyne
And let your eris nat my voys desdeyne
Al haue I nat to do in this matere
More thanne an othere man hath in this place
Yit for as moche as ye my lord so dere
Han alwey shewed me fauour and garace
I dar the better aske you of a space
Of audience to shewen our requeste
And ye my lord to do ryght as you leste
For certes lord so wel vs liketh yow
And al your werk and euꝰer han don . that we
Ne coude nat our self deuysen how
We myghten lyuen in more felicite
Sauf o. thing lord if it your wil be
That for to be a wedded man yow leste
Then were your peple in souereyn hertes reste
Bowyth your nekke vnder that blisful yok
Of souereynte nat of seruise
Which that men clepen spousaile or wedlok
And thinketh lord among your thoughtes wise
How that our dayes passe in sundry wise
For though we slepe or wake or rome or ryde
Ay fleeth the tyme it wol no man abyde
And though your grene youth floure as yit
In crepith age alwey as stil as stoon
And deth manaceth euꝰery age and smyt
In eche estat for ther eschapeth noon
And also certeyn as we know echon
That we shul dye and vncerteyn we alle
Ben of that day that deth shal on vs falle
Accepteth thanne of vs the trew entente
That neuer yit refuseden your heeste
And we wol lord yif that ye wol assente
Chese yow a wyf in short tyme atte leeste
Borne of the gentileste and of the meeste
Of al this lond so that it ought seme
Honour to god and yow as we can deme
Deliuere vs out of al this bisi drede
And take a wyf for hie goddes sake
For if so bifel as god forbede
That thurgh your deth your lynage sholde slake
And that a straunge Successour shulde take
Your heritage .o. wo / were vs alyue
Wherfore we paray yow hastyly to wyue
Hir meke praier and hir pitous chere
Made the Marquys hert han pitee
Ye wol quod he myn owne peple dere
To that y neuer er thoght streyne me
I me reioyced of my libertee
That selden tyme is founde in mariage
Ther I was fre y most ben in seruage
But nathalees y se your trew entente
And trust vpon your wit and haue don ay
Wherfore of my fre wille I wol assente
To wedde me as sone as euyr I may
But ther as ye han profered me to day
To chese me a wife y . yow relese
That choyse and pray you that ꝓprofre cese .
For god it wot that children often ben
Vnlik hir worthi eldres hem bifore
Bounte comth al of god nat of the stren
Of which thei ben engendred and y bore
I trust in goddes bounte / and therfore
My mariage and myn estat and reste
I him bitake / he may do as him leste
Lat me allone in chesyng of my wif
That charge vp on my bak I wol endure
But I yow prey and charge vpon your lyf
That what wif that I take ye me assure
To worshep hir whil that hir lif may dure
In word in werk booth here and euꝰery where
As she an Emperours doughter were .
And forthermore this shol ye swere that ye
Agayn my choys shul neuer grocche ne stryue
For syn I shal forgo my libertee
At your requeste as euer mote I thryue
There as myn hert is set there wol I wyue
And but ye wold assent in swich manere
I prey yow speke no more of this Matere
With hertly wil thei sworen and assenten
To al this thing ther seyde no wyght nay
Bisekyng him of grace or that thei wenten
That he wolde graunten hem a certeyn day
Of his spousaille as sone as euer he may
For yit alwaye the peple som what dredde
Lest that the Marquys no wif wold wedde
He graunted hem a day swich as him leste
On which he wol be wedded sykerly
And seyde he did al this atte hir requeste
And thei wyth humble entente ful buxumly
Knelyng vpon hir knees ful reuerently
Him thanken alle and thus thei han and ende
Of hir entent and hoom ageyn thei wende
And here vpon he to his officers
Commaundeth for the fest to purueye
And to his pduey knyghtes and squyers
Suche charge yaf as him list on hem to leye
And thei to his commaundement obeye
And eche of hem doth al his diligence
To do vnto the fest a reuerence
Naught fer fro thilke paleys honurable
Where as this Marquys shoop his mariage
Ther stood a throop of site delitable
In which that poore folk of that vilage
Hadden hir bestes and hir herbergage
And of hir labour gret sustenance
After the erthe yaf hem habundance
Among this pore folke ther dwelte a man
Which that was holden porest of hem alle
But hye god sum tyme sende can
His grace in to a litel oxes stalle
Ianicola men of that throop him calle
A doughter hadde he fair ynow to sight
And grisildis this yonge mayden hight
But for to speke of vꝰertous beautee
Than was she on the fairest vnder sonne
Ful poorely yfostred vp was she
No likours lust was in hir hert y ronne
Wel ofter of the wel than the tonne
She drank and for she wold vꝰertu plese
She knew wel labour but non ydel ese
But though this mayde tendre were of age
Yit in the brest of hir virginytee
Ther was enclosid rip and sad corage
And in gret reuerence and charite
Hir olde poore fadre fostred she
A few sheep spynnyng on felde she kepte
She wolde nat ben ydel til she slepte
And whan she whom ward come she wolde brynge
Wortes or other yerbes tymes ofte
The which she shred and seeth for hir lyuyng
And made hir bed ful hard and no thing softe
And ay she kepte hir fadres lif on lofte
Wyth euꝰery obeisance and diligence
That childe may do to fadres reuerence
Upon grisilde the poore creature
Ful often sithe the Marquys sette his eye
As he on huntyng rood perauenture
And whan hit fel that he myght hir espye
He nat wyth wanton lokyng of folye
His eyen cast on hir but in sad wyse
Vpon hir chere he wolde him oft auyse
Commendyng in his hert hir wommanhede
And ek hir vertu passyng any wight
Of so yonge age as wel in chere and dede
For though the peple haue no gret insight
In vꝰertu he considered ful ryght
Hir bountee and disposed that he wold
Wedde hir oonly if euer he wedde shold
The day of weddyng cam / but no wyght can
Telle what womman that it sholde be
For which maruaille wondrith many a man
And seiden whan thei were in pduyte
Wol not our lord yit leue his vanyte
Wol he not wedde allas allas the while
Whi wol he thus him selfe and vs bigyle
But nathales this Marquys hath don make
Of gemmes sette in gold and in asure
Broches and rynges for grisildes sake
And of hir clothyng took he the mesure
Of a mayden lyke vnto hir stature
And ek of other ornamentes alle
That vwich a weddyng shulde falle
The of vndren of the same day
Approchet that this weddyng sholde be
And al the palays put was in array
Bothe halle and chambres eche in his degre
Houses of office stuffed wyth plentee
Theer maistow se of deynteuous vitaille
That may be founde as fer as last ytaille
This real Marquys richely arayde
Lordes and ladyes in his compaignye
The which vn to the fest were I prayed
And of his retenue the bachelrye
Wyth many a soun of sondry melodye
Vnto the vilage of the which I tolde
In this array the ryght wey han thei holde
Grisilde god wot of this ful Innocent
That for hir shapen was this array
To fecche watyr at a welle is went
And cometh hoom as sone as euer she may
For wel she hadde hard seyde that thilke day
The Marquys shulde wedde and yif she myght
She wolde fayn han seen sum of that syght
She thought I wol wyth other Maydenes stonde
That been my felaws in oure dore and se
The Marquysesse and therfore wol I fonde
To do at home as sone as it may be
The labour which that longeth vnto me
And thanne I may at leiser hir biholde
If she this wey vnto the Castel holde
And as she wold ouer the thresshold gon
The Marquys cam and gan hir for to calle
And she set doūn hir water pot anon
Byside the thresshfold of this oxes stalle
And doun vpon hir knees she gan to falle
And wyth sad contenance kneleth stille
Til she had herd what was the lordes wille
This thoghtful Markys spak vnto the mayde
Ful sobrely and seyde in this manere
Where is your fadyr Grisildis he sayde
And she wyth reuerence and humble cheere
Answerd lord he is al redy here
And ynne she goth wyth owten lenger lette
And to the Marquys she hir fadre fette
He bi the hand than took this poore man
And seyde thus whan he him had a syde
Ianicola y nother may ne can
Lenger the plesaunce of myn hert hide
If that thou vouche sauf what so bityde
Thi doughter wol I take or that I wende
As for my wyf vn to hir lyues ende
Thow louest me that wot I wel certeyn
And art my feithful liege man y bore
And al that liketh me I dar wel seyn
It liketh the and specyally ther fore
Telle me that poynt as I haue seyde bifore
If that thow wolt vn to that purpose drawe
To take me as for thin sone in lawe
This sodeyn cas the man astonyed soo
That reed he wax / abaist and al in quakynge
He stood vnneth seyde he wordes moo
But oonly thus lord quod he my wyllynge
Ys as ye wol ne ayayns your likynge
Y wolde no thing myn owne lord so deere
Ryght as yow list gouꝰerneth this matere
Yit wol. I quod this Marquys softely
That in thi Chambre I. thow. and she
Haue a colacioun and wostow whi
For I wol aske if it hir wille be
To be my wif and rule hir after me
Al this shal be doon in thi pꝰersence
Y wol t speke out of thyn audience
And hir chambre while thei were aboute
Hir tretee which as ye shal aftyr here
The peple cam in to the hous wyth oute
And wondredyn in how honest manere
Ententifly she kepte hir fadre deree
But vttrely grisildis wondre myght
For neuer erst ne saw she swich a syght
No wondre is though that she were astoned
To se so gret a geest come in that place
She neuer was to swich gestes woned
For which she loked wyth ful pale face
But shortly forth this Mater for to chase
Thise arn the wordes that the Marquys sayde
To this benygne verray feithful mayde .
Grisilde he seyde ye shul wel vnderstonde 78'
It liketh to your fadyr and to me
That y yow wedde and ek it may so stonde
As I suppose ye wol that it so be
But this demandes aske I first quod he
That syn it shal be don in hasty wyse
Wol ye assente or elles yow auyse
I sey this be ye redy wyth good hert
To al my lust and that y frely may
As me best thinketh do yow laugh or smert
And neuer ye to grucche it nyght ne day
And eke whan I sey. ye ne sey nat nay
Nouthir bi worde ne frounyng contenance
Swere this and here y swere our alliance
Wondryng vpon this word quakyng for drede
She seyde lord vndigne and vnworthi
Am y to thilke honour that ye me bede
But as ye wol your self ryght so wol. I.
And here I swere that neuer willyngly
In werke ne thought y nil yow disobeye
For to be deed thogh me were loth to dye.
This is y now grisilde myn quod he
And forth he goth wyth a ful sobre chere
Out atte dore and thanne cam she
And to the peple he seide in this manere
This is my wif quod he that stondeth here
Honureth hir and loueth hir I prey
Who so me loueth ther nys no more to sey
And for that nothing of hir olde gere
She sholde brynge in to his hous he bad
That wommen sholde despoylen hir ryght there
Of which this ladyes were no thing glad
To handil hir clothes wher in she was clad
But nathales this mayden bryght of hew
Fro foot to heed thei clothed han al new
The heris han thei kempt that lay vntressed
Ful rudely and wyth hir fyngers smale
A corone on hir hed thei han y dressed
And sette it ful of nouches grete and smale
Of hir array what sholde I make a tale
Vnneth the peple hir knew for hir fairnesse
Whan she transmewed was in swich richesse
This Marquys hath hir spoused wyth a rynge
Brought for the same cause and than hir sette
Vpon an hors snow white and wel amblynge
And to his paleys or he lenger lette
Wyth ioyful peple that hir lad and mette
Conueyde hir and thus the day thei spende
In reuel til the sonne gan descende
And shortely forth this Matere for to chase
I sey to this new Marquysesse
God hath swich fauour sent hir of his garace
That it ne semed nat by liklynesse
That she was born and fed in rudenesse
As in a cote or in oxes stalle
But norissed in an Emperours halle
To euery wyght she woxen is so dere
And worshipful that folk there she was bore
And from hir byrthe knew hir yeer bi yeer
Vnneth trowed thei but durst han swore
That to Ianycle of which I spake bifore
She doughter was for as bi coniecture
Hem thought she was a nothe creature
For though that euer vꝰertuous was she
She was encresid in swich excellence
Of thewes goode / yset in hie bounte
And so discret and fair of elloquence
So benygne and so digne of reuerence
And coude so the peples herte embrace
That eche hir loueth that loketh on hir face
Nat only of saluces in the toun
Puplisshed was the bounte of hir name
But ek biside in many a regioun
If on seith wel a nother seith the same
So spredeth of hir hie bounte the fame
That men and wommen as wel yonge as olde
Gon to saluce vpon hir to biholde
Thus Wauter lowly nat but really
Wedded wyth fortunat honeste
In goddes pes lyueth ful esily
At home / and grace ynow outeward had he
And for he saw that vnder low degre
Was often vꝰertu hid the peple him helde
