A prudent man and that is seen ful seelde
Nat only this grisildis thurgh hir wit
Coude al the fait of wifly homelynesse
But ek whan the cas requyred it
The commune profite coude she redresse
Ther nas discord rancour ne heuynesse
In al that land that she ne couthe appese
And wysely brynge hem al in hertes ese
Thogh that hir housbond absent were or non
If gentilmen or other of hir contre
Were wroth she wolde brynge hem at on
So wyse and rype wordes had she
And Iuggement of so gret equytee
That from heuene she sent was as men wende
Peple to saue and euꝰery wrong tamende
Nat longe tyme after that this grisilde
Was wedded she a doughter hath y bore
Al had hir leuer han born a knaue childe
Glad was the Marquys and his folke therfore
For thogh a mayden child come al bi fore
She may vn to a knaue childe atteyne
Bi liklyhed syn she nys nat bareyne
Ther fil as it bifalleth tymes mo
Whan that this childe had souked but a throw
This Marquys in his herte longeth so
To tempte his wif hir sadnesse for to knowe
That he ne myght out of his hert throwe
This merueilles desire his wif tassaye
Nedeles god wot he thoght hir taffraye
He had assayde hir ynow bifore
And foond hir euer good what nedid it
Hir for to tempte and weylaweylaweyweylawey more and more
But as for me y sey that euel it sit
Thogh som men preyse it for a sotil wit
Tassay a wif whan that it is no nede
And putten hir in anguyssh and in drede
For which this Marquys wroght in this manere
He cam a nyght allone there she lay
Wyth steerne face and wyth ful trouble chere
And seyde thus Grysilde quod he that day
That y yow took oute of your poure array
And putte yow in estate in hye noblesse
Ye han it nat forgeten as I gesse .
I sey grisilde this pꝰersent dignyte
In which that I haue put yow as I trow
Makith yow nat forgeteful for to be
That I yow took in poure estat ful low
For any wele ye mote your seluen know
Take hede of euꝰery word that I seye
Ther nys no wyght that hereth it but we tweye .
Ye wot your self how that y cam here
In to this hous it is nat longe ago
And thogh to me ye be ryght leef and dere
Vnto my gentiles ye be no thing so
Thei sey to hem it is gret shame and wo
For to be sugetes and ben in seruage
To the that born art of a smal vilage
And namely syn thi doughter was ybore
This wordes han thei spoken doutelees
But I desyre as I haue don bifore
To lyue my lif. with hem in rest and pees
I may nat in this cas be recheles
I mote do wyth thi doghter for the best
Nat as I wol but as my gentiles lest
And yit god wot this is ful lothe to me
But nathales wyth outen your wetyng
I wol not do but thus wole I quod he
That ye to me assenten in this thing
Shew now your pacience in your wyrkyng
That ye me hight and swore in your vilage
The day that maked was our mariage
Whan she had herd al this she nat ameued
Nouther in word chere ne contenaunce
For as it semed she was nat agreued
She seyde lord al lith in your plesaunce
Mi child and I. wyth hertily obeisaunce
Ben youres and ye mow saue and spille
Youre owne thing workith aftyr your wille
Ther may nothing so god my soule saue
Like vnto yow that myght displese me
Ne y desire nothing for to haue
Ne drede for to lese sauf oonly ye
This wille is in myn hert and ay shal be
No lengh of tyme or deth may this deface
Ne chaunge my corage to an other place .
Glad was this Marquys for hir answeryng
But yit he feyned as he were nat so
Al drery was his chere and his lokynge
Whan that he shold out of the chambre go
Sone aftyr this a forlong wey or two
He pduely hath tolde al his entente
Vn to a man and to his wyf him sente
A maner Sergeant was this pdue man
The which he feithful often he founden hadde
In thinges grete / and ek swich folk wel can
Doon execucioun on thinges badde
The lord knew wel that he him loued and dradde
And whan that this sergeant knew his lordes wille
Out of the chambre he stalketh him ful stille
Ma dame he seyde ye mote foryeue it me
Though I do thing to which I am constreyned
Ye ben so wise that ryght wel know ye
That lordes heestes mow nat be restreyned
Thei mow wel be wailled and compleyned
But men mot needes to hir lust obeye
And so wol I ther nys no more to seye
This child am I commaunded for to take
And spak no more but out the childe he hent
Despitously and gan a chere make
Ryght as he wold han slayn it or he went
Grisildis mot al sofre and al consent
And as a lambe she sitteth meke and stylle
And let this cruwel sergeant haue his wille
Suspecious was the deffame of this man
Suspect his face. suspect his word also
Suspecte the tyme in which he this bigan
Allas hir doughter that she loued so
She wende he wolde han slayn it ryght tho
But nathales she neyther wepte ne syked
Conformyng hir to that the Markys likyd .
But atte last speke she bigan
And mekely to the sergeant preyde
So as he was a worthi gentilman
That she muste kisse hir childe er that it deide
And in hir barm this litel child she leyde
Wyth ful sad face and gan the child to blesse
And lulled it and after gan it kysse .
And thus she seyde in hir benygne vois
Far wel my childe I shal the neuer se
But syn y the haue maked wyth the croys
Of thilke fader blessed mot he be
That for vs died vpon a croys of tre
Thi soule litel child I him bitake
For this nyght shaltow dyen for my sake
I trow that a norice in this cas
It hadde ben ruthe for to se
Wel myght a modre than han cride allas
But nathales so sad stedfast was she
That she endured al aduersitee
And to the sergeant mekely she sayde
Haue here agayn your litel yonge mayde
Goth now quod she and do my lordes heste
But o thing wold I pray yow of your grace
That but my lord forbade yow atte leste
Burieth this litel body in som place
That beestis ne no briddes it to race
But he no word wolde to the purpos sey
But took the childe and went vpon his wey
This sergeant cam vnto his lord agayn
And of Grisildis wordis and hir chere
He tolde him poynt for poynt in short and pleyn
And him pꝰersenteth wyth his doughter dere
Sum what this lord hath ruthe in his manere
But nathales his purpos helde he stille
As lordes doo whan thei wil haue hir wille .
And bad this sergeant that he pduely
Shulde this childe ful softe wynde and wrappe
Wyth al the circumstaunces tendrely
And cary it in a cofre or in a lappe
But vpon peyne his hed of for to swappe
That no man sholde wyten his entente
Ne when that he cam ne whider that he went
But at boleigne it to his suster dere
That thilke tyme of payue was countesse
He sholde it take and shew hir this matere
Besekynge hir to do hir bisinesse
This child to fostren in al gentilesse
And whos childe that it was he bad hir hide
From euꝰery wyght for aght that may betyde
This sergeant goth and hath fulfilde this thinge
But to the Marquys now retourne we
For now goth he ful ofte ymagynynge
If bi his wifes chere he myght se
Or bi hir word apperceyue that she
Were chaunged but he neuer coude hir fynde
But euer in on y like sad and kynde
As glad as humble as bisi in seruyse
And eke in loue as she was wont to be
Was she to him in euꝰery maner wyse
Ne of hir doughter nat a word spak she
Non accident for non aduersite
Was seyn in hir / ne neuer hir doghtres name
Ne neuened she for ernest ne for game
In this estat ther passed ben .iiij. yer
Or she wyth childe was but as god wolde
A knaue childe she bar bi this Wauter
Ful gracious and fair for to biholde
And whan that folk it to his fadre tolde
Nat oonly he but al his contre merye
Was for this childe and god thei thanke and hery
Whan it was two yeer old and fro the brest
Departed of his norice on a day
This Marquys caught him eft another lest
To tempte his wif yit ofter if ye may
O needles was she tempted in assay
But weddid men ne know no mesure
Whan that thei fynde a pacient creature
Wif quod this Marquys ye han herd or this
My peple seekly bereth our mariage
And namely syn my sone yborn is
Now is it wers than euer in al our age
The murmur sleeth myn hert and my corage
For to myn eris comth the vois so smerte
That it wel ny destruyed hath myn herte
Now sey thei thus whan Wauter is agon
Than shal the blod of Ianicle succede
And be our lord for other haue we non
Swich wordes seith my peple it is no drede
Wel ought I of swich murmur taken hede
For certeynly I drede swich sentence
Though thei not pleyn speke in myn audience
I wold lyue in pees yif that I myght
Wherfore I am desposed vttrely
As I his sister serued haue by nyght
Ryght so thinke I. to serue him pryuely
This warne I you . for ye not sodeynly
Out of your selfe for no wo shold outreye
Beth pacient and ther of I wol yow preye
I haue quod she seide thus and euer shal
Y wol nothing ne nil no thing certayn
But as yow list nat greueth me at al
Thogh that my doghter and my sone be slayn
At your commaundement that is to seyn
I haue nat had no part of children tweyne
But first seeknesse and aftyr wo and peyne
Ye ben my lord do wyth your owne thing
Ryght as yow lest asketh no reed of me
For as I lefte at home al my clothing
Whan that I first cam to yow ryght so quod she
Left y my wille and al my libertee
And took your clothing wherefore y yow preye
Doth your plesaunce y wol your lust obeye
And certes yif I hed had presciens
Your wille to know or ye your lust me tolde
I wolde it do wyth outen neglicence
But now I wot your lust and what ye wolde
Al your plesaunce ferme and stable I holde
For wist I that my deth myght do yow ese
Ryght gladly wold I dye yow to plese
Deth may not make no comparisoun
Vn to your loue and whan this Markys say
The Constance of his wif he caste a doun
His eyen two and wondreth that she may
In pacience suffre al this array
And forth he goth wyth drery contenance
But to his hert it was ryght gret plesance
This vgely sergeant in the same wyse
That he hir doghter caught ryght so he
Or wers yif men wers can deuyse
Hath hent hir sone that ful was of beaute
And euer in on so pacient was she
That she no chere made of heuynesse
But kist hir sone and aftyr gan it blesse
Saue this she preyde him yif that he myghte
Hir litel sone he wolde in erthe graue
His tendre lymes delicat to syght
Fro foules and fro bestes for to saue
But she non answere of him myght haue
He went his way as him nothing ne rought
But to boleigne he tendrely it broght .
This Markuys wordreth euer longe the more
Vpon hir pacience and yif that he
Ne hadde sothely knowen there bifore
That parfitely hir children loued she
He wolde han wend that of sum sotiltee
And of malice or for cruel corage
That she had soffred this wyth sad visage
But wel he knew that next him self certeyn
She loued hir children best in euꝰery wyse
But now of wommen wolde I asken feyn
If this assayes myght nat suffise
What coude a sturdy husbonde more deuyse
To preue hir wifhode and hir stedfastnesse
And he contynuyng euer in sturdynesse
But ther ben folk of which condicioun
That whan thei han a certeyn purpos take
Thei can not stynte of hir entencyoun
But ryght as thei were bounde to a stake
Thei wol not of hir first purpos slake
Ryght so this Markys fully hath prraposed
To tempte his wyf as he was first disposed
He waiteth yif bi word or contynaunce
That she to him was chaunged of corage
But neuer coude he fynde variaunce
She was ay on in hert and in visage
And ay the ferther that she was in age
The more trewe yif that it were possible
She to him in loue and more penyble .
For which it semed thus that of hem two
Ther nas but o wille for as Wauter leste
That same lust was hir plesaunce also
And god bethanked al fil for the beste
She shewed wel for no worldely vnreste
A wif of hir selfe nothing ne sholde
Wille in effect but as hir husbond wolde
The sclaundre of Wauter ofte and wyde sprad
That of a cruel hert he wykkedly
For he a pore womman wedded had
Hath murdrid bothe his children pduely
Swich murmur was among hem communely
No wondre is for to the peples yere
Ther cam no word but that thei murdrid were
For which ther as his peple ther bifore
Had loued him wel the sclaundre of this deffame
Made hem that thei him hated therfore
To ben a mordrour is an hateful name
But nathales for ernest ne for game
He of his cruel purpos nolde stente
To tempte his wif was set al his entente
Whan that this doughter twelue yeer was of age
He to court of Rome in sotil wyse
Enformed of his wille sent his Message
Commaundyng him swich bulles to deuyse
As to his cruwel purpos may suffice
How that the pope as for his peples reste
Bad him to wedde a nother yif him leste
I sey he bad thei sholden contrefete
The popes bulles makyng mencyoun
That he hath leue his first wif to lete
And bi the popes despensacioun
To stynte rancour and discencioun
Be twix his peple and him thus spake the bulle
The which thei han publisshed atte fulle
The rude peple as it no wondre is
Wenden ful wel that it had ben ryght so
But whan this tydyng cam to grisildis
I deme that hir hert was ful wo
But she ylike sad for euer mo
Disposid was this humble creature
The aduersitee of fortune to endure
Abidyng euer his lust and his plesaunce
To whom that she was euer in hert and al
As to hir verray wordly suffisance
But shortly if this story telle I shal
This Marquys writen hath in specyal
A lettre in which he sheweth his entente
And secretly he to boleigne it sente
To the Erl of pauy which that had tho
Wedded his suster preyde he specyally
To bryngen home agayn his children two
In honurable estate al openly
But o thing he him preyde vttrely
That he to no wyght thogh thei wolde ēmquere
Shold nat telle whos children that thei were
But sey the mayden shulde wedded be
Vnto the Marquys of Saluce anon
And as the erl was preyde ryght so did he
For at day set he on his wey is gon
Toward Saluce and lordes many on
In ryche array this mayden for to gyde
Hir yonge brother rydyng bi hir syde
Arrayde was toward hir mariage
This fressh maiden ful of gemmes cleere
Hir brother which that vij yeer was of age
Arrayde eke ful fressh in his manere
And thus in gret noblesse and wyth glad chere
Toward saluce rydyng hir iourneye
Fro day to day thei shape hem in hir weye
Among al this after his wikke vsage
This Marquys yit his wif to tempte more
To thuttrest preef of hir corage
Fully to han experience and loore
If that she were as stedfast as bifore
He on a day in open audience
Ful boystosely hath seyde hir this sentence
Certes grisilde y had ynow plesaunce
To haue yow to my wif for your goodnesse
As for your trouthe and your obeisaunce
Nat for your lynage ne for your rychesse
But now know I in verray sothefastnesse
That in gret lordship if y wol auyse
Ther is gret seruytute in sundry wyse .
I may not doon as euꝰery plowman may
My peple constreyneth for to take
A nother wif and crien day bi day
And eke the popes Rancour for to slake
Consentith it that dar y vndertake
And truly thus moche I wol you seye
My new wif is comyng bi the wey .
Be stronge of hert and voide anon hir place
And thilke dower that ye broghten me
Take it agayn I graunt it of my grace
Retourneth to your fadres hous quod he
No man may haue alwey prosperyte
Wyth euene hert I rede yow tendure
The strook of fortune or of auenture
And she agayn answerde in pacience
Mi lord quod she I wote and wist alway
How that bitwix your magnificence
And my pouert no wyght can ne may
Make comparisoun it is no nay
I heeld me neuer digne in no manere
To be your wyf ne your chambrere .
And in this hous there ye me lady made
The hie god take I for my witnesse
And also so wisly god my soule glade
I neuer helde me lady ne maistresse
But humble seruant to your worthinesse
And euer shal whil that my lif may dure
Abouen euꝰery worldly creature
That ye so longe of your benygnytee
Han holden me in honour and in nobley
Where as I was not worthi for to be
That thanke I god and you to whom y prey
For yelde it yow ther is no more to sey
Vnto my fadre gladly wol I wende
And wyth him dwelle to my lyues yende
Ther I was fostrid of a childe ful smal
Til y be deed my lif there wol I lede
A widwe clene in hert body and al
For syn y yaf to you my maydenhede
And am your trew wif it is no drede
God shilde swich a lordes wif to take
A nother man to husbond or to make
And of your new wif god of his garace
So graunte you wele and hie ꝓprosperite
For y wol gladly yelden hir my place
In which that I was blisful wont to be
For syn it lyketh you my lord quod she
That whilom weren al myn hertes reste
That y shal go y wol go whan you lest
But there as ye me profre swich dowaire
As y first brought it is wel in my mynde
It were my wrecched clothes no thing faire
The which to me now were ful hard to fynde
O good god how gentil and how kynde
Ye semed by your speche and your visage
The day that maked was our mariage .
But sooth is seyde algate y fynde it trewe
For in effect it preued is on me
Loue is nat olde as whan it is newe
But certes lord for noon aduersite
To dyen in the cas it shal not be
That euer in word or werk I shal repente
That I yow yaf myn herte in hool entente
My lorde y wote that in my fadres place
Ye did me strepe out of my poore wede
And richely me cladden of your grace
To yow broght I not elles out of drede
But feith and nakednesse and maydenhede
And here agayn your clothing I restore
And ek your weddyng rynge for euer more
The remanaunt of your iewelx redy be
Wyth ynne your chambre dar I sauely seyn
Naked out of my fadres hous quod she
I cam and naked mote I turne ageyn
Al your plesaunce wold I folwe feyn
But yit y hope it be not your entente
That y smoklees out of your paleys wente
Ye coude not do so dishonest a thing
That thilke wombe in which that your children leye
Shulde be fore the peple in my walkyng
Be seyn al bare wherfore y yow preye
Lat me nat lik a worme go bi the weye
Remembre yow myn owne lord so deere
I was your wif though y vnworthi were
Wherfore in guerdoun of my maydenhede
Which that I broght and nat awey I bere
As voucheth sauf to yeue me for my mede
But swich a smok as I wont to were
That I therwyth may wrye the wombe and here
That was your wif and here take I my leue
Of yow myn owne lord lest y yow greue .
The smok quod he that thou hast on thi bak
Lat it be stille and bere it forth wyth the
But wel vnnethis thilke word he spak
But went away for routhe and for pite
Beforn the folk hir seluen strepeth she
And in hir smok wyth foot and heed al bare
Toward hir fadres hous forth is she fare
The folk hir folwen wepyng in hir wey
And fortune ay thei cursen as thei gon
But she fro wepyng kepte hir eyen drye
Ne in this tyme word ne spake she non
Hir fader that this tydyng herd anon
Curseth the day and tyme that nature
Shoop him to ben a lyues creature
For out of dout this olde pore man
Was euer in suspect of hir mariage
For euer he demed syn it first bigan
That whan the lord fulfild had his corage
Hym wolde think it were a disꝑperage
To his estat so low for to alight
And voyden hir as sone as euer he myght
Ageyn his doughter hastily goth he
For he bi noyse of folk knew hir comyng
And wyth an olde cote as it myght be
He couered hir sorowefully wepyng
But on hir body myght he it nat bryng
For rude was the clothe and more of age
By dayes fele thanne hir mariage
Thus wyth hir fadre for a certeyn space
Dwelleth this flour of wyfly pacience
That nouther bi hir wordes ne hir face
Be forn the folk ne ek in hir absence
Ne shewed she that hir was doon offence
Ne of hir hie estat no remembrance
Nad she as by hir contenance .
No wondre is for in hir gret estat
Hir gost was euer in pleyn humilite
To tendre mouth no hert delicat
No pompe no semblant of realte
But ful of pacient benygnyte
Discret and prideles ay honurable
And to hir husbond euer meke and stable
Men speke of Iob and most for his humblesse
As Clerkes whan hem lest can wel endyte
Namly of men but as in sothfastnesse
Thogh Clerkes preysen wommen but a lyte
Ther can no man in humblesse him aquyte .
As womman can ne can be half so trewe
As womman be but it be falle of newe
Fro boleigne is this Erl of pauy come
Of which the fame vp sprang to more and lesse
And to the peples eris al and some
Was couth ek that a new Marquysesse
He wyth him broght wyth swich pompe and richesse
That neuer was ther sen wyth mannes eye
So noble array in al westlumbardy
The Marquys which that shoop and knew al this
Or that this Erl was comen . sente his message
For thilke sely poore grisildis
And she wyth humble hert and glad visage
Nat wyth a swollen thought in hir corage
Cam at his heest and on hir knees hir sette
And reuꝰerently and wysely she him grette
Grisilde quod he my wille is vttrely
This mayden that shal wedded be to me
Receyued be to morn as really
As possible is it in myn hous to be
And ek euꝰery wyght in his degre
Haue his estat in sittyng and seruyse
And bi plesance as I can best deuyse
I haue no womman suffisant certeyn
The chambres for to array in ordenaunce
Aftyr my lust and therfore wold I feyn
That thyn were al swich maner gouꝰernaunce
Thow knowest ek of olde al my plesaunce
Thogh thyn array be badde and euel besey
Do thow thi deuer atte lest wey
Nat oonly lord that I am glad quod she
To do your lust but I desire also
Yow for to serue and plese in my degre
Wyth outen feyntyng and shal euer mo
Ne neuer for no wele ne no wo
Ne shal the gost wyth ynne myn herte stente
To loue yow best wyth al my trew entente
And wyth that word the hous she gan to dyghte
An tables for to sette and beddes make
And peyned hir to do al that she myght
Preyng the chambreres for goddes sake
To hasten hem fast to swepe and shake
And she the most seruysable of alle
Hath euꝰery chambre arrayde and his halle
Abouten vndren gan this Erl talyght
And wyth him broght his noble children tweyne
For which the peple ran to se the syght
Of hir array so rychely beseye
And than at erst among hem thei sey
That wauter was no fool thogh that him lest
To chaunge his wif for it was for the best
For she is fairer as thei demen alle
Than is grisild and more tendre of age
And fairer fruyt bitwene hem shold falle
And more plesant is ek for hir lynage
Hir brother ek so fair was of visage
That hem to see the peple hath caught plesance
Commendyng now the Marquys gouernance .
O stormy peple vnsad and euer vntrewe
And vndiscret and changyng as a fane
Delyten ay in Rombil that is newe
For lyk the moone waxen ye and wane
Ay ful of clappyng dere ynow a Iane
Your dome is fals your Constance euel preueth
A ful gret fool is he that on yow leueth
Thus seyden folk in that Citee
Whan that the peple gazed vp and doun
For thei were glad ryght for the nouelte
To haue a new lady of the toun
No more of this now make y mencyoun
But to grisilde anon wol I me dresse
And telle hir constance and hir bisynesse
Ful bisy was grisilde in euꝰery thyng
That to the fest was appertynent
Ryght naught was she abaist of hir clothyng
Thogh it were rude and sumdel eke to rente
But wyth glad chere to the yate is went
Wyth other folk to grete the Marquysesse
And aftyr that doth forth hir bisynes
Wyth so glad chere his gestes she receyueth
And konnyngly euꝰerych in his degre
That no defaute no man apperceyueth
But ay thei wondren what she myght be
That in so poore array was for to se
And coude swich honure and reuerence
And worthily thei preysen hir prudence
In al this mene while she ne stente
This mayde and ek hir brother to commende
Wyth al hir herte in ful benygne entente
So wel that no man coude hir pris amende
But atte last whan this lordes wende
To sitten doun to mete he gan to calle
Grysilde as she was bisi in his halle .
Grisilde quod he as it were in his pley
How liketh the my wyf and hir beaute
Ryght wel quod she my lord in good feye
A fairer saw I neuer mo than she
I praye to god yeue yow ꝓprosperite
And so y hope that he wol to yow sende
Plesaunce ynow vnto your lyues ende
O thing I beseke yow and warne also
That ye ne prike wyth no turmentyng
This tendre mayden as ye han do mo
For she is fostrid in hir norisshyng.
More tendrely and to my supposyng
She myght nat aduersite endure
As coude a poore fostred creature
And whan this Wauter saw hir pacience
Hir glad chere and no malice at al
And he so often had doon hir offence
And she ay sad and constant as a wal
Contynuyng euer hir innocence ouꝰeral
This sturdy Marquys gan his hert dresse
To ruwe vpon hir wifly stedfastnesse
This is ynow grisild myn quod he
Be now no more agast and euel apayde
I haue thi feith and thi benygnyte
As wel as euyr womman was assayde
In gret estat and porelych arrayde
Now know I dere wif thi stedfastnesse
And hir in armes took and gan hir kesse
And she for wondre took of it no kepe
She herd not of it what thing he to hir seyde
She firde as she had stirte out of hir sleep
Til she out of hir mazednesse abreyde
Grisild quod he bigod that for vs deyde
Thow art my wif ne no nother I haue
Ne neuer hadde so god my soule saue
This is thi doghter which thow hast supposed
To be my wif that other feithfully
Shal be myn heir as y haue ay purposed
Thow bar hem in thi body trewly
At boleigne haue I kep hem pryuely
Taak hem agayn for now maistow nat sey
That thow hast lorn non of thi children twey
And folk that otherweyes han seyde of me
I warne hem wel that I haue doon this dede
For no malice ne no crueltee
But for tassay in the thi wommanhede
And nat to slee my children god for bede
But for to kepe hem pryuely and stille
Til I thi purpos knew and ek thi wille
Whan she this herd aswoun doun she falleth
For pitous ioy and aftyr hir swounynge
She bothe hir yonge children vn to hir calleth
And in hir armes pitously wepyng
Embraceth hem and tendrely kyssyng
Ful lyk a modyr wyth hir salte teres
She bathed bothe hir visage and hir heres
O which a pitous thing it was to se
Hir swounynge and hir humble voys to here
Graunt mercy lord god thanke it yow quod she
That ye han saued me my children dere
Now rekke I neuer to be ded ryght here
Syn I stonde in your loue and in your grace
No force of deth ne whan my spirit pace
O tendre o. dere .o. yonge children myn
Your woful modyr wende stedfastly
That cruwel houndes or sum foul vermyne
Had eten yow but god of his mercy
And your benygne fadre tendrely
Hath doon yow kepte and in the same stounde
Al sodeynly she swapte adoun to grounde
And in hir swoun so sadly haldeth she
Hir children two wan she gan hem embrace
That wyth gret sleght and gret difficultee
The children from hir arme thei gan arace
O many a teer and many a pitous face
Doun ran of hem that stonden hir biside
Vnneth abouten hir myght thei abyde
Wauter hir gladeth and hir sorwe slaketh
She ryseth vp abaisid from hir traunce
And euꝰery wyght hir ioy and fest maketh
Til she hath caught ayen hir contenance
Wauter hir doth so feithful plesaunce
That it was deynte for to se the chere
Betwix hem two now thei ben met in fere
This ladyes whan that thei hir tyme say
Han taken hir and in to chambre gon
And strepen hir out of hir rude array
And in a cloth of gold that bryght shon
Wyth a corone of many a riche stoon
Vpon hir hed thei in to halle hir broght
And there she was honured as she ought
Thus hath this pitous day a blisful ende
For euery man and womman doth his myght
This day in murthe and reuel to dispende
Til on the welkyn shon the sterres bryght
For more solempne in euꝰery mannes syght
This fest was and gretter of costage
Than was the reuel of hir mariage.
Ful many a yeer in hie prosperite
Lyuen this two in concord and in reste
And richely his doughter maried he
Vnto a lord on of the worthiest
Of al ytaille and thanne in pees and reste
His wyues fadre in his court he kepith
Til that his soule out of his body crepith
His sone succedith in his heritage
In rest and pees aftyr his fadres day
And fortunat was ek in mariage
Al put he nat his wyf in gret assay
This world is not so stronge it is no nay
As it hath ben in olde tymes yore
And herkeneth what this auctor seith therfore.
This stori is seide nat for that wyues sholde
Folwe grisilde as in humilite
For it were importable though thei wolde
But for that euꝰery wyght in his degre
Shulde be constant in aduersite
As was grisilde therfore petrark wryteth
This stori which he wyth hie style enditeth
For syn a womman was so pacient
Vnto a mortel man wel more vs ought
Receyuen al in gre that god vs sent
For gret skyle is he preue that he wroght
But he ne tempteth no man that he boght
As seith seint Iame if he his pistle rede
He preueth folk al day it is no drede
And suffreth vs as for your excersise
Wyth sharpe scourges of aduersitee
Ful ofte to []bebe bete in sundry wyse
Nat for to know our wille for certes he
Or we were born knew al our freletee
And for our best is al his gouꝰernance
Lat vs then lyue in vertuous suffrance
But lordynges .o. word herkeneth or I go
It were ful hard to fynde now a dayes
In al a toun Grisildis thre or two
For yif that thei were I put in swich assayes
The gold of hem hath new so badde alayes
Wyth bras that though the coygne be faire at eye
It wolde rather breste atwo than plie .
For which heer for the wyues loue of bathe
Wos lif and hir secte god mayntene
In hie maistrye and elles were it scathe
Y wol wyth lusty herte fressh and grene
Sey yow a songe to glade yow I. wene
And let vs stente of ernestful matere
Herkeneth my songe that seith in this manere
Lenuoy de Chaucer
Grisilde is ded and eke hir pacience
And bothe at ones in ytaille
Wherefore I crie in open audience
No wedded man be hardy to assaille
His wyues pacience in hope to fynde
Grisildis for certeyn he shal fayle
O noble wyues ful of prudence
Lat nat humilite your tonge nayle
Ne lat no clerk haue cause or diligence
To wryte of yow a story of which maruaille
As of grisildis pacient and kynde
Lest chychyuache yow swolow in hir entraille
Folwyth ecto that holdeth no silence
But euer answereth at the countretaille
Be nat bidaffed for your Innocence
But sharpely take on yow the gouꝰernaylle
Emprentyth this lessoun in your mynde
For commune profit syn it may auaylle
Ye archewyues standeth at deffence
Syn ye ben stronge as is a gret camaile
Ne suffreth nat that men do yow offence
And sclendre wyues feble as in bataille
Beth egre as is a tigre yonde in ynde
Ay clappeth as a mylle y yow consaille .
Ne drede hem nat do hem no reuerence
For thogh thyn husbond armed be in mayle
The arwes of thi crabbed eloquence
Shal peerce his brest and ek his auentaille
In gelousye y rede ek thow him bynde
And thou shalt make him couche as doth a quayle
If thow be fair the folk ben in pꝰersence
Shew thou thi visage and thin apparaille
If thou be foul be fre of thi despence
To gete the frendes ay do thi trauaille .
Be ay of cheer as lyght as leue on lynde
And lat him care and wepe and wrynge and waille
Here bigynneth the prologe of the Marchauntz tale
Wepyng and waillyng care and other sorwe
I know ynow on euen and on morwe
Quod the Marchant and so dooth other mo
That wedded ben I trowe that it be so
For wel y wote it fareth so wyth me
I haue a wif the worst that may be
For thogh the fende to hir coupled were
She wold him ouer macche y dar wel swere
What shold I yow reherce in special
Hir malice she is a shrew at alle
Ther is a longe a large difference
Bitwix Grisildis gret pacience
And of my wif the passyng cruwelte
Were I vnbounden also mote I the
I wolde neuer eft come in the snare
We wedded men leuen in sorwe and care
Assay who so wol and he shal fynde
That I sey soth bi seynt Thomas of ynde
As for the more part I sey nat alle
God shilde that it shold so bifalle
¶ A good sire hoost I haue wedded be
This monthes two and more nat parde
And yet I trow he that al his lyue
But take no kepe of al swich vanyte
Diffye theofrast and herkene me
¶ A wif is goddes yefte verrayly
Al other maner yeftes hardyly
As londes rentes pasture or commune
Thise ben the yeftes of fortune
That passen as a shadow on the wal
But drede thow noght yif pleynly speke y shal
A wif wol last and in this hous endure
Wel lenger than the list perauenture
¶ Mariage is a ful gret sacrament
He which that hath no wif I holde him shent
He lyueth helplees and al desolat
Y speke of folk in seculer estat
And herken whi I sey nat this for naght
That womman is for mannes helpe ywroght
The hie god whan he had Adam ymaked
And saugh him allone baly naked
God of his gret goodnesse seyde than
Let vs now make an helpe vnto this man
Lik to him selue and thanne he made him yeue
Here may ye se and here may ye preue
That wif is mannes help and confort
His paradys terrestre and his disport
So buxom and so vꝰertuous is shee
Thei moste nedys lyue in vnyte
O flessh thei ben and o flessh as I gesse
Hath but on hert in wele and in distresse
¶ A wyf a seynt marie benedicite
How myght a man haue any aduꝰersite
That hath a wif certes I can not sey
The blisse the which is bitwix hem twey
Ther may no tonge telle ne herte thinke
Yf he be poore she helpeth him to swynke
She kepeth his good and wasteth neueradel
Al that hir husbond doth hir liketh wel
She seyth not ones nay whan he seyth ye
Do this seith he al redy syr seith she
O blisful ordre .o. wedlok precious
Thow art so mury and ek so pꝰercious
And so commendid and approued eke
That any man that halt him worth a leke
Vpon his bare knees oghte al his lif
Thanken his god that hym hath sent a wyfe
Or elles prey to god him for to sende
A wif to laste vnto his lyues ende
For thanne his lif is set in sykernesse
He may nat be desceyued as I gesse
So that he werche aftyr his wyues reed
Thanne may he boldely kepen vp his heed
Thei ben so trew and therwyth so wyse
For which yif thou wolt werche as the wyse
Do alwey so as wommen wole the rede
Lo how that Iacob as this clerkes rede
By good counseil of his Rebekke
Boond the kyddes skynne aboute his nekke
For which his fadres benysoun he wan
Lo Iudith as the storie eke telle can
By good counseil she goddes peple kepte
And slow him Olofernes whil he slepte
Loo Abigail by good counseil how she
Saued hir husbond Nabal whan that he
Sulde han beslayn and look ester also
By good counseil delyuꝰered out of wo
The peple of god and made him mardochee
Of Assuere enhanted for to be
¶ Ther nys no thing in gre suꝑperlatif
As seith Senek aboue an humble wif
Suffre thi wyues tonge as Caton bit
She shal comaunde and thow shalt suffren it
And yit she wol obeye of curtesy
A wif is keper of thin husbandry
Wel may the seekman bewayle and wepe
There as is no wif the hous to kepe
I warne the yif wysely thow wolt werche
¶ Loue wel thi wif as crist loueth his cherche
Yif thow louest thi self thow louest thi wif
No man hateth his flessh but in his lif
He fostred it and therfore bid he thee
Cherissh thi wif or thou shalt neuer thee
Housbonde and wif what so men iape or pley
Of worldly folk ye holden the syker wey
Thei ben so knet ther may no man betyde
And namely vpon the wyues syde
For which this Ianuarye of whom y tolde
Considred hath in wyth his dayes olde
The lusty lif the vertuous quyete
That is in mariage hony swete
And for his frendes on a day he sent
To tellen hem theffect of his entent
¶ Wyth face sad this tale he hath hem tolde
He seyde frendes I am hoor and olde
And almoost god wot on my pittes brynke
Vpon my soule som what most y thynke
I haue my body folily despended
Blessed be god that I shal ben amended
For I wol be certeyn a wedded man
And that anon in al the hast I can
Vnto som mayde fair and tendre of age .
I pray yow shapeth for my mariage
Al sodeynly for I wol nat abyde
And I wol fonde tespien on my syde
To whom I may be wedded hastily
But for as moche as ye ben mo than I
Ye shul rather swich think espyen
Than I and where me best were to allien
But o thing warne I yow my frendes dere
I wole no wif han in no manere
She shal not passe twenty yeer certeyn
Olde fissh and yonge flesshe wold I haue feyn
Bet is quod he a pike than a pikerel
And bet than an old beof is the tendre veel
I wol no womman xxxtiri yer of age
It is but benestrawe and gret forage
And eke thise olde widwes god it wot
Thei conne so moche craft on wades boot
So mochel broken harm whan hem lest
That wyth hem shold I neuer lyue in rest
For sundry scoles maken subtile clerkes
Womman of many scoles half a clerk is
But certeynly yonge thing men may gye
Ryght as men may warme wex wyth handes plye
Wherfore I sey yow pleynly in a clause
I wole noon olde wif han ryght for this cause
For yif so were I hed swich meschaunce
That I in hir couche haue no plesaunce
Than shold y lede my lyf in auoutrye
And streight to the deuel whan y dye
Ne children shold I none vpon hir geten
Yet were me leuer houndes me had eten
Than that myn heritage sholde falle
In strange hand and thus I telle yow alle
I dote nat y wot the cause whi
Men sholde wedde and ferthermore wote I
Ther speketh many a man of Mariage
That wot no more of it than wote my page
For which causes a man sholde take a wif
If he ne may not lyue in chastite his lif
Take him a wif wyth gret deuocioun
Be cause of leueful ꝓprocreacioun
Of children to honour of god aboue
And nat oonly for paramour or for loue
For thei sholde lechery eschue
And yelde hir dette whan that it is due
And for that eche of hem shold helpen other
In myschief as suster shal the brother
And lyue in chastite ful holyly
But syrs bi your leue that am not I
For god be thanked I dar make auaunt
I fele my lymes stark and sufficiaunt
To do al that aman bilongeth to
I woot my selfe best what I may do
Thogh I be hoor I fare as dooth a tre
That blosmeth er the fruyte I woxen be
And blosmy tre nys neyther drye ne deed
I fele me nogh wher hoor but on myn heed
Myn hert also and my lymes ben as grene
As laurer thurgh the yeer is for to sene
And syn that ye han herd al myn entente
I prey yow to my counseil ye wol assente
¶ Diuꝰerse men diuꝰersyly him tolde
Of mariage many ensamples olde
Some blamed it some preysed it certeyn
But atte last shortly for to seyn
Alday falleth altercacioun
Bitwix frendes in dispitacioun
Ther fil a stryf bitwix his britheren two
Of which that oon was cleped Placebo
Iustinus sothley cleped was that other
¶ Placebo seyde .o. Ianuarie brother
Ful litel nede had ye my lorde so dere
Counseil to axe of any that is here
But that ye ben so ful of Sapiens
That yow ne liketh for your high prudens
To weyuen fro the word of Salamon
This word seyde he vnto vs euꝰerychone
Werk al thing bi counseil this seyde he
And thanne shalt thow nat repente the
But thogh that salamon spak swich a word
Myn owne dere brother and my lord
So wisly god my soule brynge to reste
I holde your owne counseil is the best
For brother myn of me take this motif
I haue now ben a court man al my lif
And god it woot thogh I vnworthi be
I haue stonden in ful gret degre
Abouten lordes in ful gret estate
Yit hadde I neuer wyth non of hem debate
I neuer contraryed hem truly
I wot wel that my lord can more than I.
What that he seith I holde it ferme and stable
I sey the same or elles thing semblable
A ful gret fool is any counseillour
That serueth any lord of high honour
That dar pꝰersume or think ones it
That his counseil sholde passe his lordes wit .
Nay lordes be no fooles bi my fay
Ye han your seluen shewed here to day
So high sentence so holily and wel
That I concente and conferme euerydel
Your wordes alle who couth bet han y sayde
Crist halt him of this counseil ful wel apayde
And trewly it is an high corage
Of any man that stopen is in age
To take a yonge wif by my fadre kyn
Your hert hangeth on a ioly pyn
Doth now in this mater ryght as yow lest
For fynally I holde it for the best
¶ Iustinus that ay stil sat and herd
Ryght in this wyse he to placebo answerd
Now britheren myn be pacient I preye
Syn ye han seyde and herkeneth what I seye
¶ Senek amonges other /. othir wordes wyse
Seith that a man oght him ryght wel to auyse
To whom he yeueth his lond or his catel
And sith I oght auyse me ryght wel
To whom I yeue my good away fro me
Wel moche more I oght auysed be
To whom I yeue my body for alwey
¶ I warne yow wel it is no childes pley
To taken a wif wyth outen auysement
Men most enquere this is myn assent
Whether she be wyse or sobre or dronkelew
Or prowde or elles other weyes a shrew
A chidester or wastour of thi good
Or riche or pore or elles mannysh wood
Al be it so that no man fynde shal
Noon in this world that trotteth hool al
Ne man ne best swich as men coude deuyse
But nathalees it oghte ynow suffice
Wyth any wif if so were that she hadde
Moo good thewes thanne hir vices badde
And al this axeth leiser for tenquere
For god it wot I haue wepte many a teere
Ful priuely syn that I had a wyf
Preysen who so wol a wedded mannes lif
Certeyn I fynde in it but cost and care
And obseruances and al of blisses bare
And yit god woot my neyburghs aboute
And namely of wommen many a route
Seyn that I haue the stedfast wif
And eke the mekest that bereth lif
But I woot best where wryngeth me my shoo
Ye mow for me ryght as yow liketh doo
Auyseth yow ye ben a man of age
How that ye entren in to mariage
And namely wyth a yonge wif and a faire
Bi him that made water erthe and eyre
The yongest man that is in al this route
Ys bisi ynow to bryngen it aboute
To han his wif allone trusteth me
Ye shul nat plesen hir yeres thre
This is to seyn to don hir ful plesaunce
A wif axeth ful many an obseruaunce
I prey yow that ye be nat euel apayed
¶ Wel quod this Ianuary and hastow sayde
Straw for Senek and straw for thi ꝓprouerbes
I counte nat a panyer ful of yerbes
Of scole termes a wiser man than thow
As thow hast herd assenteden ryght now
To my purpos placebo what sey ye
¶ I sey it is a cursed man quod he
That letteth matirimonye sykerly
And wyth that word thei risen sodeynly
And ben assented fully that he sholde
Be wedded to whom him lest and where he wolde
¶ Hygh fantasye and curious bisynes
Fro day to day gan in the soule impresse
Of Ianuarye abouten his mariage
Many a faire shap and many a faire visage
Ther passed thurgh his hert nyght be nyght
As who so took a mirrour pollisshed bryght
And set it in a commune Market place
Thanne sholde he se ful many a figure pace
By his Mirour and in the same wyse
Gan Ianuarye in wyth his thoght deuyse
Of maidens which that dwelten him biside
He wist nat where that he myght abyde
For if that on haue beaute in hir face
A nother stant so in the peples garace
For hir sadnesse and hir benygnyte
That of the peple grettest voys had she
But nathales bitwix ernest and game
And some weren riche and hadden bad name
He atte last apoynted him on oon
And let al other from his hert goon
And chees hir of his owne auctorite
For loue is blynde alday and may nat se
And whan that he was in his bedde ybroght
He purtreyde in his hert and in his thoght
Hir fresshe beaute and hir age tendre
Hir myddil smal hir armes longe and sclendre
Hir wyse gouꝰernaunce hir gentilesse
Hir wommanly beryng and hir sadnesse
And whan he on hir was condescended
Him thoght his choys myght nat ben amended
For whan that he him self concluded hadde
Hym thoght eche othir mannes was badde
That impossible it were to replie
Agayn his choys this was his fantasie
His frendes sent he to at his instaunce
And preyde hem to doon him that plesaunce
That hastily thei wolden to him come
He wolde abregge hir labour al and some
Nedeth na more to hem to go ne ryde
He was apoynted ther he wolde abyde
¶ Placebo cam and ek his frendes sone
And alder first he bad hem al abone
That noon of hem non argumentis make
Agayn the purpos which that he hath take
Which purpos was plesant to god seide he
And verrey ground of his ꝓprosperyte .
¶ He seyde ther was a mayden in the toun
Which that of beaute had gret renoun
Al were it so she were of smal degre
Suffiseth him hir youthe and hir beaute
Which maide he seyde he wolde haue to his wif
To lede in ese and holynesse his lif
And thankid god that he myght han hir al
That no wyght his blisse parten shal
And preyde hem to labouren in this nede
And shapen that he fayle nat to spede
For thanne he seide his spirit was at ese
Thanne is quod he nothing may me displese
Saue o thing priketh in my conscience
The which y wol reherce in your pꝰersence
¶ I haue quod he herd seyde ful yore ago
Ther may no man haue parfite blisses two
This is to seyn in erthe and eke in heuene
For thogh he kepe him fro the synnes seuene
And eke from euery braunche of thilke tre
Yit is ther so parfit felicite
And so gret ese and lust in mariage
That euer I am agast now in myn age
That I shal lede now so murye a lif
So delicat wyth outen woo or strif
That I shal han my heuene in erthe here
For sith that verray heuene is boght so dere
Wyth tribulacions and gret penaunce
How sholde I thanne lyue in swich plesaunce
As al wedded men doon wyth hir wyuis
Come to the blisse that crist eterne on lyue is
This is my drede and ye my britheren twey
Assoyleth me this questioun I prey
¶ Iustinus which that hated his foly
Answerd anon ryght in his Iapery
And for he wolde his longe tale abregge
He wolde non auctorite allegge
But seyde syr so ther be non obstacle
Other than this god of his miracle
And of his mercy may so for yow wirche
That er ye haue your ryghtes of holy chirche
Ye may repente of wedded mannes lif
In which ye seyn ther is no wo ne strif
And elles god forbede but he sente
A wedded man hym grace to repente
Wel ofte rather than a sengel man
And therfore syr the best reed I can
Despeire yow noght but haue in memorie
Perauenture she may be your purgatorie
She may be goddes mene and goddes whippe
Thanne shal your Soule vnto heuene skippe
Swifter than dooth an arwe out of a bowe
I hope to god heer after shul ye knowe
That ther nys noon so greet felicite
In mariage neuer more shal be
That yow shal lette of your saluacioun
So that ye vse as skil is and resoun
The lustes of your wif attemprely
And that ye plese hir nat toamorously
And that ye kepe yow eke from other synne
My tale is doon for my wit is thynne
Beth nat agast here of my brother dere
But lat vs waden out of this Matere
The wif of bathe yif ye han vnderstonde
Of mariage which we haue vp on honde
Declared hath ful wel in litel space
Fareth now wel god haue yow in his garace
And with that worde Iustinus and his brother
Han take hir leue and eche of hem of other
For whan thei saw that it moste nedes be
Thei wroghten so bi sligh and wys trete
That she this maiden which that Mayus hight
As hastily as euere that she myght
Shal wedded be vn to this Ianuarye
I trow it were to longe yow to tarye
Yif I yow tolde of euꝰery scrit and bonde
By which that she was feffed in his londe
Or for to herken of hir ryche array
But fynally ycomen is that day
That to the chirche bothe be thei went
For to receyue the holy sacrament
Forth cometh the prest wyth stole aboute his nekke
And bad hir be lik Sarra and Rebekke
In wisdome and in trouthe of mariage
And seide his orisons as was his vsage
And trouthplyght hem and bad god shulde hem blesse
And made al siker ynow wyth holynesse
¶ Thus ben thei wedded wyth solempnytee
And atte last sitteth he and she
With other worthi folk vppon the deys
And ful of blisse and ioy is the paleys
And ful of Instrumentz and of vitaille
The most deynteuous of al ytaille
Biforn hem stood Instrumentz of such soun
That orphius ne of Thebes Amphioun
Ne maden neuer swich a melodye
¶ At euꝰery cours than cam loude mynstralcye
That neuer tromped Ioab for to here
Ne he theodomas yit half so clere
At thebes whan the Citee was in doute
Bacus the wyne hem shenketh al aboute
And Venus laghet vpon euery wyght
For Ianuarye was bicome hir knyght
And wolde bothe assayn his corage
In liberte and eke in mariage
And wyth firbrond in hir hond aboute
Daunceth bi fore the bride and al the route
And certeynly I dar wel sey ryght this
Ymeneus that god of weddyng is
Sei neuer his lif so mery a wedded man
Holde thow thi pees thow poete marcian
That writest vs that ilke weddyng murye
Of hir philologie and he mꝰercurye
And of the songes that the muses songe
To smale is bothe thi penne and eke thi tonge
For to discreuen of his mariage
Whan tendre youth hath wedded stoupyng age
Ther is swich murthe that it may not be wryten
Assayeth it your self than may ye witen
Yf that I lye or non in this Matere
¶ Mayus that sitte with so benygne chere
Hir to beholde it semed feirye
Queene ester loked neuer wyth swich an eye
On assuer so meke aloke hath she
Y may nat now deuyse al hir beaute
But thus moche of hir beaute telle I may
That she was like the bryght morwe of may
Fulfillid of al beaute and plesaunce
¶ This Ianuary is rauysshed in atraunce
At euꝰery tyme he loked on hir face
But in his hert he gan hir to manace
That he that nyght in armes wolde hir streyne
Hardyr than euer parys ded Eleyne
But nathales yit had he gret pite
That thilke nyght offenden hirx most he
And thoght allas .o. tendre creature
¶ Now wolde god ye myght endure
Al my corage it is so sharpe and kene
I am agast ye shal not it sustene
But god forbede that I did al my myght
Now wold god that it were woxen nyght
And that the nyght wold lasten euer moo
I wolde that al this peple were ago
And fynally he doth al his labour
As he best myght sauyng his honour
To haste hem fro the mete in subtil wise
The tyme cam that reson was to rise
And after that men dauncen and drynke faste
And spices al aboute the hous thei caste
And ful of ioye and blisse is euꝰery man
Al but a squyer that hight damyan
Which carf biforn the knyght many a day
He was so rauysshed on his lady may
That for the verry pyne he was ne wood
Almost he swelte and swoned as he stood
So soore hath venus hirt him wyth hir brond
As that she bare it dauncynge in hir hond
And to his bedde he went him hastily
No more of him at this tyme speke I.
But ther I let him wepe ynow and pleyn
Til Fressh may . wol rewen on his peyne
¶ O ꝑperilous fir that in the bedstraw bredeth
O famulier foo that his seruyse bedeth
O seruant nay traitour fals homely hew
Lik to the naddre in bosom sligh vntrew
God shilde al from your acqueyntance
O Ianuarye dronken in plesance
In mariage se how thi Damyan
Thyn owne squyer and thi born man
Entendeth for to do the vilenye
God graunte the thin homly fo tespie
For in this world nys wors pestilence
Thant hoomly foo al day in his pꝰersence
¶ Parformed hath the sonne his ark dyourne
No lenger may the body of him soiourne
On thorisonte as in latitude
Nyght wyth his mantel that is derk and rude
Gan ouersprede the Mesperies aboute
For which departed is al this lusti route
From Ianuarye wyth thanke on euꝰery syde
Hoom to hir houses lustily thei ride
Where as thei doon her thinges as hem lest
And whan thei sey hir tyme thei goon to rest
¶ Sone after that this hasty Ianuarye
Wolde go to bed he wol no lenger tarye
He drynketh ypocras clarre and vernage
Of spices hoote to encresen his corage
And many a letuary had he ful fyne
Swich as the cursed monk daun Constantyne
Hath writen in his book de coitu
To eten hem alle he nas nothing eschu
And to his priue frendes thus seyde he
For goddes loue als sone as it may be
Lat voiden al this hous in curteys wise
And thei han doon ryght as thei wole deuyse
Men drynken and the trauers draw anon
The bryde was broght to bedde as stille as ston
And whan the bedde was wyth the prest yblessed
Out of the chambre hath euꝰery wyght him dressed
And Ianuarie hath fast in armes take
His fresh may his paradys his make
He lullith hir he kisseth hir ful ofte
Wyth thilke bristlis of his berd vnsofte
Lik to a Skynne of an houndefysshe sharpe as brere
For he was shaue al new in his manere
He rubbeth hir aboute hir tendre face
And seyde thus allas me most trespace
To yow my spouse and yow gretly offende
Or tyme come that I wol descende
But neuerthelees considereth this quod he
Ther nys no werkemon what so euꝰer he be
That may bothe worche wel and hastily
This wolde he doon at leiser parfitly
It is no force how longe that we pley
I trow in wedlok coupled ben we twey
And blessed be the yok that we ben ynne
For in our actes we may do no synne
A man may do no synne wyth his wif
Ne hurte him self wyth his owne knyf
For we han leue to pley vs bi the lawe
Thus laboreth he til that day gan dawe
And thanne he taketh a sop in fyne clarre
And vpryght in his bedde than sitteth he
And after that he songe ful loude and clere
And kist his wif and made wanton chere
He was al coltissh ful of Ragerye
And ful of Iargoun as is a flekked pie
The slak skynne aboute his nekke shaketh
Whil that he songe so chaunteth he and craketh
But god wot what that may thoght in hir herte
Whan she him saw vp sittyng in his sherte
In his nyght cappe and wyth his nekke leene
She preyseth not his pleyyng worth a bene
Thanne seide he thus my rest wol I take
Now day is come I may no lenger wake .
And doun he leide his heed and slept til pryme
And aftyr ward whan that he saugh his tyme
Vp riseth Ianuarye but fressh may
Heeld hir chambre vnto the fourth day
As vsage is of wyues for the best
For euꝰery labour som tyme mot haue reste
Or elles may he not longe endure
This is to seyn no lyues creature
Be it fyssh or brid or best or man
Now wol I speke of woful damyan
That languyssheth for loue as ye shol here
Therfore I speke to him in this manere
¶ I sey .o. sely damyan allas .
Answere to my demaunde as in this cas
How shaltow to thi lady fressh may
Telle thi woo she wol alwey sey nay
Eke yif thow speke she wol the bewreye
God be thin help I can no bettre sey
¶ This seek damyan in venus fir
So brenneth that he dyeth for desir
For which he put his lif in auenture
No lenger myght he in this wise endure
But pryuely a penner gan he borwe
And in a lettre wrote he al his sorwe
In maner of a complaynt or of a lay
Vnto his feir fressh lady may
And in a purs of silke hynge on his sherte
He hath it put and leide it at his herte
¶ The sonne that atte the noone was thilke day
That Ianuarye hath wedded fressh may
In two of taur was in to Cancre gliden
So longe hath Mayus in hir chambre abyden
As custume is to this nobles alle
A bride shal not eten in the halle
Til dayes four or thre atte lest
Y passed ben than lat hir go to fest
The fourthe day complete fro noon to noon
Whan that the high masse was y doon
In halle sitte this Ianuarye and may
As fressh as is the bryght somers day
And so bifil that this good man
Remembred him vpon this damyan
And seyde seynt marye how may this be
That damyan entendeth nat to me
Is he ay seek or how may this bitide
His squyers than stonden ther biside
Excused him bi cause of his seeknesse
Which letted him to doon his bisynesse
Noon other cause myght make him tarye
¶ That me forthinketh quod this Ianuarye
He is a gentil squyer bi my trouthe
Yif that he dyed it were harme and routhe
He is as wis discreet and eke secre
As any man y woot of his degree
And ther to manly and eke seruysable
And for to be a thrifty man ryght able
But after mete as sone as euer I may
I wil my self visiteir him and eke may
To doon him al the comfort that I can
And for that word him blessed euꝰery man
That of his bounte and his gentilesse
He wolde so conforten in seeknesse
His squyer for it was a gentil dede
Dame quod this Ianuarie take good hede
And after mete ye wyth your wommen alle
Whan ye han ben in Chambre out of this halle
That alle ye goon to this damyan
Doth him disport he is a gentilman
And telleth him that I wil him visite
Haue I no thing but rested me alite
And spede yow fast for I wol abide
Til that ye slepe fast bi my syde
And wyth that word he gan to him calle
A squyer that was Marchal of his halle .
And told him certeyn thinges what he wolde
¶ This fressh may hath streight hir wey holde
With alle hir wommen vn to damyan
Doun bi his beddis side sitte she than
Confortyng him as goodly as she may
This damyan whan that he is tyme say
In secree wise his purs and ek his bille
In which that he ywryten hath his wille
Hath put in to hir hond wyth outen more
Saue that he syketh wondre depe and sore
And softely to hir ryght thus seide he
Mercy and that ye nat discouere me
For y am deed if that this thing be kid
This purs hath she in with hir bosom hid
And went hir wey ye gete no more of me
But vnto Ianuarye comen is she
That on his beddes syde sitte ful softe
And taketh hir and kisseth hir ful ofte
And leide him doun to slepe and that anon
She feyned hir as that she most goon
Ther as ye woot that euꝰery man mote nede
And whan she of this bille hath taken hede
She rente it al to cloutes atte laste
And in the pryue softely she it caste
¶ Who studyeth now but fair fressh may
Adoun bi olde Ianuarye she lay
That sleep til that the cough haue him awaked
Anon he preyde to stripen hir al naked
He wolde of hir haue some plesaunce
He seyde hir clothes ded him comberaunce
And she obeieth be hir leef or looth
But lest that folk be wyth me wroth
How that he wroght I dar nat to yow telle
Or whether it thoght him paradys or helle
But here I let hem worken in hir wise
Til euesong ronge and that thei most rise
Were it bi destenye or bi auenture
Where be Influence or be nature
Or constellacioun that in that which estate
The heuene stood that tyme fortunate
As for to putte a bille of venus werkes
For al thing hath tyme as seyn thise clerkes
To any womman for to gete hir loue
I can nat sey but gret god aboue
That knoweth that non acte is causelees
He deme of al for y wol holde my pees
But sooth is this how that this fressh may
Hath taken swich impꝰerssioun that day
Of pite on this sike damyan
That from hir hert she ne dryue can
The remembraunce for to doon him ese
Certeyn thoght she whom that this thing displese
I rekke not for here y him assure
To loue him best of any creature
Thagh namore hadde than his shert
Loo pite renneth sone in gentil herte
¶ Here may ye se how excellent franchise
In womman is whan thei hem narwe auyse
Som tirant is as ther ben many oon
That hath an hert as hard as any stoon
Which wolde haue letten him steruen in the place
Wel rather than han graunted him hir grace
And hem reioyce in hir cruwel pride
And rekke nat to be calde an homycide
¶ This gentil May fulfild of pite
Ryght of hir hond a lettre maked she
In which she graunteth him hir verry garace
Ther lakketh no thing oonly but day and place
Where that she myght vn to his lust suffice
For it shal be ryght as he wole deuyse
And whan she saugh hir tyme vpon a day
To visite this Damyan goth may
And subtily this lettre doun she thriste
Vnder his pilwe rede it if hym leste
She taketh hym by the hand and harde hym twiste
So secrely that no man of it wiste
And bad him be al hool and forth she went
To Ianuarie whan that he for hir sent .
Vp riseth Damyan the next morowe
Al passed was his sekenesse and his sorwe
He kembeth him he preyneth him and piketh
He dooth al that his lady lust and liketh
And ek to Ianuarye he gooth as lowe
As euer did a dog for the bowe
He is so plesant to euꝰery man
For crafte is al who so that do it kan
That euꝰery wight is fayn to speke him good
And fully in his lady grace he stood
Thus lete y damyan in his nede
And in my tale forth I wol procede
¶ Some clerkes holden that felicite
Stant in delite and therfore certeyn he
This noble Ianuarye wyth al his myght
In honest wyse and as longeth to a knyght
Shoop him to lyue ful deliciously
His housyng his array as honestly
To his degre was maked as a kynges
Amonges other of his honest thinges
He mad a gardyn walled al wyth stoon
So fair a gardyn wote y nogh where noon
For oute of doute I verryly suppose
That he that wrot the Romance of the rose
Ne coude of it the beaute wel deuyse
Ne priapus ne myght neuer suffise
Thogh he be god of gardeyns for to telle
The beaute of the gardeyn and the welle
That stod vnder a laurer alwey grene
For ofte tyme he pluto and his quene
Proserpina and hir fayrye
Disporten hem and maken melodye
Aboute that welle daunced as men tolde
¶ This noble knyght this Ianuarye the olde
Swich deynte hath in it to walke and pley
That he wole no wyght suffre to bere the key
Saue he himself for of the smale wiket
He bar alwey of siluer a cliket
Wyth which whan that him lest he it vnshet
And whan he wolde pay his wif hir det
In somer sesoun thider wolde he go
And May his wif and no wyght but thei two
And thinges which were nat doon abedde
He in the gardeyn ꝑperformed hem and spedde
And in this wise many a mery day
Lyued this Ianuarye and ek fressh may
But worldly ioy may nat alwey dure
To Ianuarye ne to no creature
O. sodeyn hap .o. thou fortune vnstable
Like to the scorpioun so deceyuable
That flatrest wyth thin heed whan thow wolt stynge
Thi tayl is deth thurgh thin envenymynge
O bretil ioy o. swete venym queynte
O monstre so sotillich kanst peynte
Thi yeftes vnder hew of stedfastnesse
That thow desceyuest bothe more and lesse
Whi hastow Ianuarye thus deceyued
That haddest for thi ful frende him receyued
Now thow hast rafte him bothe his eyen
For sorwe of which desireth he to dyen
Allas this noble Ianuarie free
Amyd his lust and his ꝓprosꝑperite
Is woxen blynde and that al sodeynly
He wepith and he wailleth ful pitously
And therwith al the fir of Ialousye
Lest that his wif sholde falle in som foly
So brent his hert that he wold fayn
That som man bothe him and hir had slayn
For neither after his deth ne in his lif
Ne wolde he that she were loue ne wif
But euer lyue as widow in clothes blake
Sool as the turtil that lost hath hir make
But atte last after a month or twey
His sorwe gan aswage sooth to sey
And whan he wist it myght noon other be
He paciently took his aduersite
Saue out of doute he may not forgon
That he was Ialouse euer more in oon
Wyth Ialousie he was so outeraious
That neither in halle ne in noon other hous
Ne in noon other place neuer the mo
He nolde suffre hir to ryde or goo
But yif that he had hond on hir alway
For which ful ofte wepeth fressh may
That loueth damyan so benygnely
That she mot either dyen sodeynly
Or elles she mot han him at hir leste
She waiteth whan hir herte wolde to breste
¶ Vpon that othir syde damyan
Bicome is the sorwefullest man
That euyr was for neither nyght ne day
Ne myght he speke a word to fressh may
As to the purpos of non swich matere
But yif that Ianuarie most it here
That had an hond vpon hir euer moo
But nathalees bi writyng to and fro
And piriue signes wist he what she mente
And she knew ek the fyn of his entente
O Ianuarye what myght the auaille
Thogh thow myghtest se as fer as shippes saille
For as good is blynde desceyued be
As to be desceyued whan man may se
Loo Argus which that had an hundred eyen
For al that he coude poure or prien
Yit was he blent and so ben many mo
That weneth wisly that it be nat so
Passe ouꝰer is an ese y sey no more
¶ This fressh may that I spak of yore
In warm wex hath prented the cliket
That Ianuarye bar of that smal wyket
Bi which in to his gardyn ofte he went
And damyan that knew al this entent
The cliket countrefeted piriuely
Ther nys no more to sey but hastyly
Some wondre of this cliket shal betide
Which ye shal heren yif ye wol abide
O noble ouyde wel sooth seistow god woot
What sleight is it yif loue be longe and hoot
That he nyl fynden out in som manere
By pyramus and bi thesbe may men lere
Thogh thei were kepte ful longe streyte ouer al
Thei ben accordid rownyng thurgh awalle
There no wyght coude haue founde swich a sleighte
But now to purpos er that the day eighte
Were passed er the month of Iuyl bifille
That Ianuarye hath caught so gret wille
Thurgh eggyng of his wif him for to pleye
In his gardyn and no wyght but thei tweye
That in a Morwe vnto this May seith he
Rys vp my wif my loue my lady fre
The turtils vois is herd my dowue swete
The wynter is goon wyth Reynes wete
Comforth now wyth thyn eyen colombyn
How fairer ben thi brestes than is wyn
The gardeyn is enclosed al aboute
Com forth my white spouse out of doute
Thow hast me wounded in my herte .o. wif
No spot of the ne know y al my lif
Com forth and lat vs take our dispoort
I chees the for my wif and for my confort
¶ Swich olde lewde wordes vsed he
On damyan a signe made she
That he shold go biforn wyth his cliket
This damyan hath than opned the wiket
And insterte and that in swich manere
That no wyght myght it se neither here
And stille he sitte vnder a bussh anon
¶ This Ianuarye as blynde as is a stoon
Wyth Mayus in his hand and no wyght mo
In to his fressh gardyn is y go
And clapte to the wyket sodenly
¶ Now wif quod he here nys but thow and .I.
Thow art that creature that I best loue
For bi that lord that is in heuene aboue
Leuer ich hedde to dyen on a knyf
Than the offende my trew dere wif
For goddes sake thenke or the chees
Noght for couetyse doutelees
But oonly for the loue I hadde to the
And thogh that y be olde and may nat se
Beth to me trew and I shal telle yow whi
Thre thinges certes shal ye wynne ther bi
First is loue of crist and to your self honour
And al myn heritage toun and ek tour
Y yeue it yow maketh chartres as yow lest
This shal be doon to morwe or sonne rest
So wisly god my soule brynge in blisse
I prey yow first in couenant ye me kisse
And thogh I be Ialous wite me noght
Ye ben so depe empꝰerntid in my thoght
That whan I concidre your beautee
And therwyth al the vnlikly elde of me
I may nat certes thogh I shold dye
Forbere to ben out of your companye
For verray loue this is wyth outen doute
Now kisse me wif and lat vs rome aboute
¶ This Fresshe may whan she thise wordes herd
Benyngly to Ianuarye answerd
But first and forward she bigan to wepe
I haue quod she a soule ek to kepe
As wel as ye and also myn honour
And of my wifhode thilke tendre flour
Which that I haue assured in your hond
Whan that the preest to yow my body bond
Wherfore I wol answere in this manere
Be the loue of my lord so dere
I prey to god that neuer dawe the day
That I ne sterue as foule as womman may
Yif euer I do vnto my kyn that shame
Or elles I empeire so my name
That I be fals and if I do that lakke
Do strepe me and put me in a sakke
And in the next Ryuer do me drenche
I am a gentil womman and no wenche
Whi speke ye thus but men ben euer vntrew
And wommen haue reproue of yow ay new
Ye han non othir contenance I leue
But speke to vs of vntriste and repreue
¶ And with that word she saugh where Damyan
Sat in the bussh and coughen he bigan
And with hir fynger signes made she
That Damyan shuld clymbe vppon a tre
That charged was wyth fruyt and vp he went
For verrily he knew al hir entent
And euꝰery signe that she coude make
Wel bet than Ianuarye hir owne make
For in a lettre she had tolde him alle
Of this mater how he worken shalle
And thus I lette him sitte vpon the pirie
And Ianuarye goo may romyng myrye
¶ Bryght was the day and blew the firmament
Phebus hath of gold the streemes doun sent
To gladen euꝰery flour wyth his warmenesse
He was that tyme in geminis as I gesse
But a litel fro his declinacioun
Of cancer Iouis exaltacioun
And so bifel that bright morwe tyde
That in the gardyn in the ferther side
Pluto that is kyng of fairye
And many a lady in his compaignye
Folowyng his wif the quene Proserpynea
Which that he rauesshed out of Sithea
Whil that she gadred floures in the mede
In cladyan ye may the stories rede
How in his grisly cart he hir sette
This kyng of fairye than him doun sette
Vpon a benche of turues Fressh and grene
And ryght anon thus seyde he to his quene
¶ My wif quod he ther may no wight sey nay
The experience so preueth euꝰery day
The tresons which that womman doth to man
Ten hundred thousand tellen I can
Notable of your vntrouth and brotelnesse
O Salamon wisest and richest of richesse
Fulfild of sapience and of worldly glorie
Ful worthi ben thi wordes to drawen in memorie
To euꝰery wight that wit and resoun can
Thus preiseth he yit the bounte of that man
¶ Amonges a thousand men yit founde I. oon
But of womman alle found I noon
¶ Thus seith the kyng that knouth your wykkednesse
And Ihus filius Syrak as I gesse
Ne speke of yow but seelde reuꝰerence
A wild fir and corrupte pestilence
So falle vpon your bodyes yit to nyght
Ne se ye not this honurable knyght
Bi cause allas that he is blynd and old
His owne man shal make him cokewold
Loo where he sitte the lechour in the tre
Now wol I graunte of my maieste
Vnto this olde blynde worthi knyght
That he shal haue ayen his eyen sight
Whan that his wif wold doon him vileyny
Than shal he knowen al hir harlotrye
Both in repreef of hir and other mo
¶ Ye shal quod proserpyne . and wol ye so
Now bi my modres syr soule I swere
That I shal euen hir sufficiant answere
And al wommen aftyr for hir sake
That thogh thei ben in any gilte I take
Wyth face bold thei shul hemself excuse
And bere hem doun that wold hem accuse
For lakke of answer noon of hem shal dyen
Al had a man seyn it wyth his eyen
Yit shal we wommen visagen it hardily
And wepe and swere and chide subtylly
So that men shul been as lewde as gees
What rekketh me of auctoritees
¶ I wote wel that this Iewe this Salamon
Fonde of vs wommen foles many oon
But thogh that he ne fonde no good womman
Yit hath ther founden many another man
Wommen ful trew ful good and vꝰertuous
Witnesse of hem that dwellen in cristes hous
With Martyrdom thei preued hir constance
The Romayn geestes make ek remembrance
Of many a verrey trew wif also
But syr ne be nat wroth / al it be so
Thagh that y seyde he foonde no good womman
I paray yow take the sentence of that man
He mente thus that in souereigne bounte
Nis nat but god . but neither he . ne she
¶ Ey for verry god that nys but oon
What make ye so moche of Salamon
What thogh he made a temple goddes hous
What thogh he were riche and glorious
So made he ek a temple of fals goddes
How myght he do a thing that more forbode is
Parde as faire as ye his name emplastre
He was a lechour and an ydolastre
And in his elde he verry god forsoke
And yif god ne had as seith the boke
I spared him for his fadres sake he sholde
Haue lost his regne rather than he wolde
I sette ryght noght of al the vilenye
That he of wommen writeth / a boterflye
I am a womman nedes mot I speke
Or elles swelle til myn hert breke
For sithen he seide that we ben Iangleresse
As euer hool mote y brouke my tresse
I shal nat spare for no curtesie
To speke hem harm that wol vs vileynye
¶ Dame quod this pluto be no lenger wroth
I yeue it vp but seth I swoor myn oth
That I wolde graunten him his syght ayeyne
Mi word shal stond I warne yow certeyne
I am a kyng it sitte me noght to lye
¶ And I quod she a queene of fayrie
Hir answer shal she haue I vndertake
Let vs no more here of wordes make
Forsothe I wole no lenger yow contrarye
¶ Now lat vs turne agayn to Ianuarye
That in the gardeyn with his fair may
Syngeth ful mirier than the popynIay
Yow loue I best and shal and other noon
So longe aboute the aleys is she goon
Til he was come agayns thilke pirye
Where as this Damyan sitteth ful myrye
An high amonge the fressh leues grene
¶ This fressh may that is so bright and shene
Gan for to syke and seyde allas my side
Now syr quod she for oghte that may bityde
I moste han of the peres that I se
Or y mote dye so soore longeth me
To eten of the smale peris grene
Helpe for hir loue that is of heuene quene
I telle yow wel a womman in my plite
May han to fruyt so gret an appetite
That she may dyen but she of it haue
¶ Allas quod he that I nad here a knaue
That coude clymbe allas allas quod he
For ich am blynde ye sir no fors quod she
But wolde ye vouchefafe for goddes sake
The pirye in with your armes for to take
For wel I wote that ye ne triste me
Thanne shold I clymbe wel ynow quod she
So y my foot myght set vpon your bakke
¶ Sertis quod he ther on shal be no lakke
Might y yow helpen wyt myn hert blood
He stoupeth doun and on his bakke she stood
And caught hir bi atwist and vp she goth
Ladyes I paray yow that ye be nat wroth
I can nat glose I am a rude man
And sodeynly anon this damyan
Gan pulle vp the smok and In he thronge
¶ And whan that pluto saugh this grete wronge
To Ianuarye agayn he yaf his sight
And made him se as wel as euꝰer he myght
And whan that he had caught his sight agayn
Ne was ther neuer man of sight so fayn
But on his wif his thoght was euer mo
Vnto the tre he caste his eyen two
And saugh that damyan his wif had dressed
In swich maner it may nat ben expressed
But yif y wolde speken vncurteysly
And vp he yaf aroryng and a crye
As doth the modre whan the child shal dye
Out helpe allas harrow he gan to crye
O stroong lady stoor what doost thow
¶ And she answerde syr what eilleth yow
Haue pacience and resoun in your mynde
I haue yow holpen in bothe in your eyen blynde
Vp perile of my soule I shal nat lyen
As me was taught to heele wyth your eyen
Was no thing bette to make yow to se
Than strogle wyth a man vpon a tree
God woot I did it in ful good entente
¶ Strogle quod he algate in it wente
God yeue yow bothe on shames deth to dyen
He swyued the I saugh it wyth myn eyen
And elles be I hanged bi the hals
¶ Thanne is quod she []thisthis medicine al fals
For certeynly if that ye myght se
Ye wolde not seyn thise . wordes . vnto me
Ye han som glymsyng and no ꝑperfite syght
¶ I so quod he al so wel as euꝰer I myght
Thonked be god wyth bothe myn eyen two
And bi my trouth me thought he did the so
Ye maze maze good syr quod she
This thank haue I for I made yow to se
Allas quod she that euer I was so kynde
Now dame quod he lat passe al out of mynde
Come doun my lef and yif I haue myssayde
God helpe me so as I am euel apayde
But by my fadres soule y wende haue seyn
How that this damyan had bi the layn
And that thi smok had leyn vpon thi brest
¶ Ye syr quod she ye may wene as yow lest
But syr a man that waketh out of his sleep
He may nat sodeynly wel take keepe
Vpon a thing to se it parfitly
Til that he be adawed verrayly
¶ Ryght so a man that longe blynde hath ybe
Ne may nat sodeynly so wel y se
First whan his sight slaked be a while
Ther may ful many a sight yow bigile
Beth war I prey yow for bi heuene kyng
A man may ful lyghtly seen a thing
And it is al a nother thanne it semeth
He that mys conseyueth he mys demeth
And wyth that word she leep doun fro the tre
¶ This Ianuarye who is glad but he
He kysseth hir and clippeth hir ful ofte
And on hir wombe he stroketh hir ful softe
And to his paleys hoom hath he hir ladde
Now good men I paray yow to be gladde
Thus endeth here my tale of Ianuarye
God blesse vs and his modre seint marye
Here endeth the Marchantz tale
By goddes mercy seide our hoost tho
Now swich a wyf I prey god kepe me fro
Lo which sleightes and subtilitees
In wommen ben for as bisi as bees
Ben thei vs sely men for to deceyue
And from a soth euer wol thei weyue
Bi this Marchantz tale it proueth wel
But doutelees as trew as any stele
I haue a wif thogh that she pore be
But of hir tonge a labbyng shrew is she .
And yit she hath an heep of vices mo
Ther of no force lat alle suche thinges go
But wit ye what . in counseil be it seide
Me ruweth soore I am to hir teyde
For and I sholde reken euꝰery vice
Which that she hath I wis . I were to nyce
And cause whi it sholde repented be
And tolde to hir of some this meyne
Of whom it nedeth nat to declare
Syn wommen konnen out such chaffare
And ek my wit suffiseth nat ther to
To tellen al wherfore my tale is y do
¶ Squier come nere yif it your wille be
And sey some what of loue for certes ye
Konne ther on as moche as any man
¶ Nay syr quod he suche thing as I can
Wyth hertily wille for I wol not rebelle
Agay your heest a tale for to telle
Haue me excused yif I speke amys
Mi wille is good and loom my tale is this
(base) Here bigynneth the Squiers tale
(base) AT Sarray in the land of Tartarye
(base) Ther dwelte a kyng that werreyed Russye
(base) Thurgh which ther deyde many a doghty man
(base) This noble kyng was clepid Kambyuskan
(base) Which in his tyme was of so greet renoun
(base) That ther nas nowher in no Regioun
(base) So excellent a lord in alle thyng
(base) Hym lakked noght that longed to a kyng
(base) As of the secte of which that he was born
(base) He kepte his lay to which that he was sworn
(base) And ther to he was hardy wys and riche
(base) Pietous and Iust and eueremoore yliche
(base) Sooth of his word benigne and honurable
(base) Of his corage as any Centre stable
(base) Yong fressh and strong in armes desirous

div.l: (base) A fair persone he was and fortunat
(base) And kepte alwey so wel Roial estat
(base) That ther nas no wher swich another man
(base) This noble kyng this Tartre Cambyuskan
(base) Hadde two sones on Elfeta his wyf
(base) Of whiche the eldeste highte Algarsyf
(base) That oother sone was clepid Cambalo
(base) A doghter hadde this worthy kyng also
(base) That yongest was and highte Canacee
(base) But for to telle yow al hir beautee
(base) It lyth nat in my tonge nyn my konnyng
(base) I dar nat vndertake so heigh a thyng
(base) Myn englyssh eek is insufficient
(base) It moste been a Rethor excellent
(base) That koude his colours longyng for that Art
(base) If he sholde hire discryuen euery part
(base) I am noon swich I moot speke as I kan
(base) And so bifel that whan this Kambyuskan
(base) Hath twenty wynter born his dyademe
(base) As he was wont fro yeer to yeer I deme
(base) He leet the feste of his Natiuitee
(base) Don crien thurgh out Sarray his Citee
(base) The laste Idus of March after the yeer
(base) Phebus the sonne ful iolyf was and cleer
(base) For he was ny his exaltacioun
(base) In Martes face and his mansioun
(base) In Aries the Coleryk hote signe
(base) Ful lusty was the weder and benygne
(base) For which the foweles agayn the sonne shene
(base) What for the sesoun and the yonge grene
(base) Ful loude songen hir affeccions
(base) Hem semed han geten hem proteccions
(base) Agayn the swerd of wynter kene and cold
(base) This Cambyuskan of which I haue yow told
(base) In Roial vestyment sit on his deys

div.l: (base) That in this world ne was ther noon it liche
(base) Of which if I shal tellen al tharray
(base) Thanne wolde it ocupie a Someres day
(base) And eek it nedeth nat to deuyse
(base) At euery cours the ordre of hir seruyse
(base) I wol nat tellen of hir straunge sewes
(base) Ne of hir Swannes ne of hir heroun sewes
(base) Eek in that land as tellen knyghtes olde
(base) Ther is som mete that is ful deyntee holde
(base) That in this land men recche of it but smal
(base) Ther nys no man that may reporten al
(base) I wol nat tarien yow for it is pryme
(base) And for it is no fruyt but los of tyme
(base) Vnto my firste I wol haue my recours
(base) And so bifel that after the thridde Cours
(base) Whil that this kyng sit thus in his nobleye
(base) Herknynge his Mynstrals hir thynges pleye
(base) Biforn hym at the bord deliciously
(base) In at the halle dore al sodeynly
(base) Ther cam a knyght vpon a steede of bras
(base) And in his hand a brood Mirour of glas
(base) Vpon his thombe he hadde of gold a ryng
(base) And by his syde a naked swerd hangyng
(base) And vp he rydeth to the heighe bord
(base) In al the halle ne was ther spoke a word
(base) For merueille of this knyght hym to biholde
(base) Ful bisily they wayten yonge and olde
(base) This straunge knyght that cam thus sodeynly
(base) Al armed saue his heed ful richely
(base) Salueth kyng and queene and lordes alle
(base) By ordre as they seten in the halle
(base) With so heigh reuerence and obeisaunces
(base) As wel in his speche as in his contenaunces
(base) That Gawayn with his olde curteisye
(base) Thogh he were come agayn out of Fairye
(base) Ne koude hym nat amende with a word
(base) And after this biforn the hye bord
