div.l: (base) He with a manly voys seyde his message
(base) After the forme vsed in his langage
(base) Withouten vice of silable or of lettre
(base) And for his tale sholde seme the bettre
(base) Acordant to his wordes was his cheere
(base) As techeth art of speche hem that it leere
(base) Al be that I kan nat sowne his style
(base) Ne kan nat clymben ouer so heigh a style
(base) Yet seye I this that as to commune entente
(base) Thus muche amounteth al that euere he mente
(base) If it so be that I haue it in my mynde
(base) He seyde the kyng of Arabe and of Inde
(base) My lige lord on this solempne day
(base) Salueth yow as he best kan and may
(base) And sendeth yow in honour of youre feste
(base) By me that am al redy at youre heste
(base) This Steede of bras that esily and weel
(base) Kan in the space of o day naturel
(base) This is to seyn in twenty foure houres
(base) Wher so yow list in droghte or ellis shoures
(base) Beren youre body in to euery place
(base) To which youre herte wilneth for to pace
(base) Withouten wem of yow thurgh foul or fair
(base) Or if yow list to flee as hye in the Ayr
(base) As dooth an Egle whan hym list to soore
(base) This same Steede shal bere yow eueremoore
(base) Withouten harm til ye be ther yow leste
(base) Though that ye slepen on his bak or reste
(base) And turne agayn with writhyng of a pyn
(base) He that it wroghte koude many a gyn

(base) Er he hadde doon this operacioun
(base) And knew ful many a seel and many a bond
(base) This Mirour eek that I haue in myn hond

div.l: (base) Vnto youre regne or to your sel also
(base) And openly who is youre freend or fo
(base) And oueral this if any lady bright

(base) If he be fals she shal his trayson see
(base) His newe loue and al his subtiltee
(base) So openly that ther shal no thyng hyde
(base) Wher fore agayn this lusty someres tyde
(base) This Mirour and this ryng that ye may see
(base) He hath sent to my lady Canacee
(base) Youre excellente doghter that is heere
(base) The vertu of the ryng if ye wol heere
(base) Is this that if hir list it for to were

(base) And euery gras that groweth vpon roote

(base) It failleth nat whiles it is in youre hold

div.l: (base) And is vnarmed and to mete yset
(base) The presentz been ful realliche yfet
(base) This is to seyn the swerd and the Mirour
(base) And born anon in to the heighe tour
(base) With certein Officers ordeyned therfore
(base) And vnto Canacee the ryng is bore
(base) Solempnely ther she sit at the table
(base) But sikerly withouten any fable
(base) The hors of bras that may nat been remewed

(base) Ther may no man out of the place it dryue

(base) And cause why for they kan nat the craft

(base) Thou blasphemour of Crist with vileynye

(base) Myn holy pardoun may yow alle warisse

(base) Boweth youre heed vnder this holy bulle
(base) Cometh vp ye wyues offreth of youre wolle

(base) I yow assoille by myn heigh power
(base) Ye that wol offre as clene and eek as cler
(base) As ye were born and lo sires thus I preche
(base) And Ihu crist that is oure soules leche

(base) For that is best I wol yow nat deceyue
(base) But sires o word forgat I in my tale

(base) Parauenture ther may falle oon or two
(base) Doun of his hors and breke his nekke atwo
(base) Looke which a seuretee is it to yow alle

(base) That may assoille yow bothe moore and lasse
(base) Whan that the soule shal fro the body passe
(base) I rede that oure hoost shal bigynne
(base) For he is moost envoluped in synne
(base) Com forth sire hoost and offre first anon

(base) Ye for a grote vnbokele anon thy purs
(base) Nay nay quod he thanne haue I Cristes curs
(base) Lat be quod he it shal nat be so thee ich
(base) Thow woldest make me kisse thyn olde breech
(base) And swere it were a Relyk of a Seint
(base) Thogh it were with thy fondement depeynt
(base) But by the croys which that Seint Eleyne foond

(base) In stide of Relikes or of Seintuarie

div.l: (base) Anon they kiste and ryden forth hir weye
Here bigynneth the shipmannes tale
A Marchaunt whilom dwelt at seint denys
That riche was for which men hild him wis
A wyf he had of excellent beaute
And compaynable and reuꝰerent was she
Which is a thing that causeth more dispence
Than worth is al the cheer and reuerence
That men doon hem at festes or at daunces
Swich Salutacions or contenances
Passeth as doth the shadow on a walle
But wo is him that pay most for alle
The Sely husbond algate he most pay
He moste vs clothe and also array
Al for his owne worship richely
In which array we dauncen Iolyly
And yif that he may nat perauenture
Or elles non swich dispences endure
But thenketh it is a wast and y lost
Thanne mote an othir pay for our cost
And lene vs gold and that is ꝑperilous
¶ This noble Marchaunt heeld a noble hous
For which he had alday gret repeyr
For his largenesse and for his wif was feir
That wondir is but herkeneth to my tale
Among al his gestes grete and smale
Ther was a Monk a fair man and a bold
I trowe a xxxtiri wynter he was olde
That euer in on was drawyng to that place
This yong monk that was so fair of face
Aquaynted was so with this good man
Sithen that thei first knowlech bigan
That in his hous as famulier was he
As it is possible any frende to be
¶ And for as moche as this good man
And ek this Monk of which that I bigan
Were bothe two yborn in on vilage
The monk him claymeth as for Cosynage
And he ayen seith nat ones nay
But was as glad ther of as foule of day
For to his hert it was a gret plesaunce
Thus ben thei knyt bi eterne alliaunce
And eche of hem gan other to assure
Of brother hed whils that hir lyues may dure
¶ Fre was dan Iohn and namely of despence
As in that hous and ful of diligence
To do plesaunce and also gret costage
He noght forgate to yeuen the lest page
In al that hous but after hir degre
He yaue the lord and sithens his meynee
Whan that he cam som Maner honest thing
For which thei were as glad of his comyng
As foule is fayn whan sonne vp riseth
No more of this as now for it suffiseth
¶ But so bifil this Marchant vpon a day
Shope him to make redy his aray
Toward the toun of brugges for to fare
To bien there a porcioun of ware
For which he hath to parys sent anon
A messanger and preide hath dan Iohn
That he sholde com to seint denys and pley
With him and with his wife a day or twey
Er he to brigges wente in al wise
¶ This noble monk of which I yow deuyse
Hath of his abbot as him lust licence
Bi cause he was a man of hie prudence
And ek an officere out for to ride
To se hir graunges and hir bernes wide
And vnto seint denys he comth anon
Who was so welcom as my lord dan Iohn
Our dere cosyn ful of curtesie
With him brought he a Iubbe of maluesie
And ek an othir ful of fyn vernage
And volatil as ay was his vsage
And thus I lete hem ete and drynke and pleye
This Marchaunt and this monk a day or tweye
The thrid day this Marchaunt vp riseth
And on his nedes sadly him auyseth
And vp in to his countyng hous goth he
To reken with him self as wel may be
Of thilke yeer how that with him it stood
And how that he dispended had his good
And yif that he encresed were or non
His bookes and his bagges many on
He leith biforn him on his countyng bord
For riche was his tresour and his hord
For which ful fast his counter dore he shette
And eke he nolde no man sholde him lette
Of his acountes for the meene tyme
And thus he sat til it was passed pirime
¶ Dan Iohn was risen in the morwe also
And in the gardyn walked to and fro
And hath his thinges seide ful curteysly
¶ This good wif cam walkyng piriuely
In to the gardeyn there he walketh softe
And him salueth as she hath doon ful ofte
A mayden child cam in hir compaignye
Which as hir luste she may gouꝰerne and gye
For yet vnder the yerd was the mayde
O dere cosyn myn dan Iohn she seide
What eileth yow so rathe to arise
¶ Nece quod he hit aught ynogh suffise
Fyue houres for to slepe in on nyght
But it were for an old palled wight
As ben thise wedded men that ly and dare
As in a forme sitteth a wery hare
Were al forcaught with houndes grete and smale
But dere nece whi be ye so pale
I trow certes that our good man
Hath yow laboured sithen nyght bigan
That yow were nede to resten hastily
And with that word he logh ful myrily .
And of his owne thought he wex al reed .
¶ This faire wif gan to shake hir heed
And seyde thus ye god wot al quod she
Nay Cosyn myn it stont nat so with me
For bi that god that yaf vs soule and lif
In al the Reame of fraunce is ther no wif
That lasse luste hath vnto that sory play
For y may synge allas and welawey
That I was born but no wight quod she
Dar I nowght telle how it stant with me
Wherfore I thinke out of this lond to wende
Or elles of my lif to make an ende
So ful am I of drede and eke of care
¶ This monk bigan vpon this wif to stare
And seide allas my nece god forbede
That ye for any sorwe or any drede
For do your self but telleth me your greef
Perauenture I may in your myscheef
Conseil or help and therfore telleth me
Alle your annoy for it shal be secre
For on my portuos I make an oth
That neuer in my lif for leef ne loth
Ne shal I of your counseil yow biwrye
¶ The same ageyn to yow quod she I seye
Bi god and bi this portuos I swere
Theigh men me wolde al in peces to tere
Ne shal I neuer for to go to helle
Biwrye word of thing that ye me telle
Nat for no Cosynage ne alliaunce
But verrayly for loue and affiaunce
Thus ben thei swore and heer vpon kist
And eche of hem told other what him list
¶ Cosyn quod she yif I had tyme or space
As I haue noon and namely in this place
Thanne wold I telle a legend of my lif
What I haue suffred syn that I was a wif
With myn husbond al though he be your cosyn
¶ Nay quod this monk bi god and bi seynt martyn
He is no more Cosyn vnto me
Thanne is this leef that hangeth on this tre
I clepe him so bi seint denys in fraunce
To haue the more cause of aqueyntaunce
Of yow which I haue loued specially
Abouen al wommen sykerly
This swere I now on my professioun
Telleth your greef lest that he come adoun
And hasteth yow and goth your wey anon
My dere loue quod she .o. dan Iohn
Ful leef me were this counseil for to hide
But out it mote it may no lenger abide
Mi husbond is to me the worst man
That euer was sithe the world bigan
But sith I am a wif it sit nat to me
To telle no wight of our priuyte
Neither in bed ne in non othir place
God shilde I shold telle it for his garace
A wif ne shal nat sey of hir husband
But al honour as I can vnderstand
Saue vn to yow thus moche telle I shal
As helpe me god he is noght worth at al
In no degre the value of a flie
But yit me greueth most his nygardye
And wel ye wot that wommen naturelly
Desiren al six thinges as wel as I
Thei wold han hir husbondes shold be
Hardy and wys riche and fre
Buxom to his wif and fressh a bedde
But bi that lord that for vs blood bledde
For his honour my self to array
On sonday next I most pay
An hundreth frankes or elles am I lorn
Yit were me leuer that I were vnborn
Than me were doon a sclaundre or a vilenye
And yif myn husbond ek myght espie
I nere but lost and therfore I yow preye
Lene me this somme or elles most y deye
Dan Iohn I sey lene me this hundreth frankes
Pardee I wil nat faylle yow my thankes
If that yow liste to do that I yow paray
For at a certayn day I wol yow pay
And do yow what plesaunce and seruyse
That I may do ryght as yow lust deuyse
And but I do god take on me vengeaunce
As foule as hed Ganielyun of fraunce
This gentil monk answerd in this manere
Now trewly myn owne lady dere
I haue on yow so gret a ruthe
That I yow swere and plight yow my truthe
That whanne your hosbond is to flaundres fare
I wol delyuer yow out of this care
For I shal brynge yow an hundreth frankes
And with that word he caught hir bi the flankes
And hir embrasid herd and kist hir ofte
Goth now your wey quod he al stille and softe
And lat vs dyne as sone as euer ye may
For bi my chilyndre hit is pirime of the day
Goth now and beeth as trewe as I shal be
Now elles god forbede syr quod she
And forth she goth as Iolyf as a pie
And bad the kokes that thei shold hem hye
So that men myght dyne and that anon
Vp to hir housbond is this wif goon
And knokketh at his countre dore boldly
Que la quod he . petyr it am .I.
Quod she what syr how long wil ye fast
How longe tyme wol ye riken and cast
Your somes your bookes and your thinges
The deuel haue part of al swich rekenynges
Ye haue ynogh of goddes sounde
Come doun to day and lat your bagges stond
Ne be ye nat a shamed that dan Iohn
Shal fastyng al this day thus eleng goon
What lat vs here messe and go we dyne
Wif quod this Marchaunt litil canst thow deuyne
The curious bisinesse that we haue
For of vs chapmen so god me saue
And bi that lord that cleped is seint yue .
Scarsly among 2xij two shuln thryue
Contynuelly lastyng vnto our age
We may wel make cheer and good visage
And dryue forth the world as it may be
And kepen our estate in piriuyte
Til we be deed or elles that we pleye
On pilgrymage or gon out of the weye
And therfore haue I gret necessite
Vpon this queynt world to auyse me
For euermore we most stond in drede
Of hap and fortune in our chapmanhede
¶ To Flaundres wol I go to morwe at day
And com agayn as sone as I may
For which my dere wif I the beseke
As be to euꝰery wight buxom and meke
And for to kepe our hous be curious
And honestly gouꝰerne ye wel our hous
Thow hast ynogh in euꝰery maner wise
That to a thrifty housbond may suffise
Yow lakketh non array ne no vitaille
Of siluer in your purs ye may nat faille
And with that word his counter dore he shet
And doun he goth no lenger wold he let
But hastily a messe was ther seid
And spedily the tables were y leid
And to the dyner fast thei hem sped
And richely this marchant this monk fed
¶ And after dyner dan Iohn soberly
This marchant took on part and piriuely
And seide him thus Cosyn it standeth so
That wel I se to Brugges wol ye go
God and seint Austyn yow spede and gyde
I pray yow Cosyn wisely that ye ride
Gouerneth yow also of your diete
Al temprely and namely in this hete
Bitwix vs two nedeth no straunge fare
Fare wel cosyn god shild yow fro care
Yif eny thing ther be by day or bi nyght
If it be in my power and my myght
That ye me wil commaunde in eny wise
It shal be don ryght as ye wol deuyse
¶ On thing er that ye gon yif it may be
I wolde prey yow for to lene me
An hundred frankes for a wook or tweye
For certenly I most ne delynges beye
To store with a place that is oures
God helpe me so I wolde it were youres
I shal nat faile sykerly of my day
Noght for a thousand frankes a myle way
But lat this thing be secre I yow paray
For this for beestes this nyght yit most I pay
And fare now wel myn owne cosyn dere
Graunt mercy of your cost and of your chere
¶ This noble Marchant gentily anon
Answerd and seide o cosyn myn dan Iohn
Now sykerly this is a smal requeste
Mi gold is yours whan so that yow lest
And noght al only my gold but my chaffare
Take what yow list god shelde yow to spare
¶ But o thing as ye know it wel ynogh
Of chapmen that hir money is hir plogh
We may creaunce whils we han a name
But goodlees for to be is no game
Pay hit ageyn whan it lieth in your ese
Aftyr my myght ful feyn wol I yow plese
This hundreth frankes he fet forth Anon
And piriuely he told hem to dan Iohn
No wight in al this world wist of this lone
Sauyng this Marchant and dan Iohn allone
Thei drynk and speke and Rome a while and pleye
Til that dan Iohn rideth to his Abbey
The Morwe cam and forth this Marchant rideth
To flaundres ward his prentys wel him gideth
Til he cam to Brugges ful meryly
Now goth this Marchant fast and bisily
Aboute his nedes and bieth and creaunseth
He neither pleyeth at the dees ne daunseth
But as a marchant shortely for to telle
He led []hishis lif and there I let him dwelle
The sonday next dan Iohn is agon
¶ To seynt denys y comen is dan Iohn
With croune and beerd al fressh and new y shaue
In al the hous ther nas so litel a knaue
Ne no wight elles that he ne was fayne
For that my lord dan Iohn was comen ayen
And shortely to hir poynt for to gon
This fair wif acordeth with dan Iohn
And for this hundreth frankes he shold al nyght
Haue hir in his armes bolt vpright .
And this accord parfourmed was in dede
In myrth al nyght abisi lif thei lede
Til it was day that dan Iohn went his way
And bad the meynee fare wel and haue good day
For non of hem ne no wight in the toun
Hath of dan Iohn right no suspecioun
And forth he rideth hoom to his Abbeye
Or where him lust no more of him I seye
¶ This Marchant whan that endid was his faire
To seint denys he gan to repayre
And with his wif he maketh fest and cheer
And telleth that chaffare is so dere
That nedes most he make a cheuysance
For he was bounden in a reconysance
To pay twenty thousand sheeldes anon
For which this Marchant is to parys gon
To borwe of certeyn frendes that he hedde
A certeyn frankes and some with him he ledde
And whan that he was comen in to that toun
For gret cherite and gret affeccioun
Vnto dan Iohn he first goth him to pley
Noght for to borwe of him money
But for to wit and se of his welfare
And for to tellen him of his chaffare
As frendes don whan thei ben met in fere
Dan Iohn him maketh fest and mery chere
And he him told ageyn ful specially
How he had bought right wel and garaciously
Thankid be god his marchandise
Saue that he most in al maner wise
Maken a cheuy sance as for his best
And thanne he shold be in ioy and ek in rest
¶ Dan Iohn answerd certes I am feyn
That ye in hele ben come hoom ayeyn
And yif that I were riche so haue I blisse
Of twenty thousand sheldes shold ye nat mysse
For ye so kyndely this othir day
Lent me gold and as I can and may
I thanke yow bi god and bi seynt Iame
But nathales I took it vnto our dame
Your wif at home the same gold ayeyn
Vpon your benche she wot it wel certeyn
Bi certeyn tokenes that I koude hir telle
Now bi your leue I may no lenger dwelle
Our Abbot wol out of this toun anon
And in his compaigny most I gon
Grete wel our dame my nece swete
And fare wel dere Cosyn til we mete
¶ This Marchant which that was war and wis
Creaunsed hath and payd ek in parys
To certeyn lumbardes redy in hir hond
This some of gold and took of hem his bond
And hoom he goth as mery as a popyngeay
For wel he knew he stood in swich array
That nedes most he wynne in swich a viage
A thousand frankes aboue al his costage
¶ His wif ful redy met him atte gate
As she was wont of olde vsage algate
And al that nyght in myrthe thei ben set
For he was riche and clerely out of det
Whan it was day this Marchant gan embrace
His wif al new and kissed hir on hir face
And vp he goth and maketh it ful togh
No more quod she bi god ye haue ynogh
And wantonly with him she pleyde
¶ Til atte last this Marchant seide
Bi god quod he I am alitel wroth
With yow my wif al thogh it be me loth
And wot ye whi bi god as that I gesse
That ye han made a maner straungenesse
Bitwix me and my Cosyn dan Iohn
Ye shuld han warned me or I had gon
That he yow had an hundreth frankes paied
Bi redy token he held him euel apaide
For that I to him spak of cheuysaunce
Me semed so bi his contenance
But nathalees bi god of heuene kyng
I thoght nat to axe him no thing
I prey the wif do no more so
Telle me alwey or that I fro the go
If eny dettour haue in myn absence
I payde the lest thurgh thi neccligence
I may him axe a thing that he hath payde
¶ This wif was noght afferd ne affrayde
But boldly she seide and that anon
Mary I defye that fals Monk dan Iohn
I keep noght of his tokenes neuer adel
He took me certeyn gold that wot I wel
What euel thedom vpon his monkes snoute
For god it wot I wende with outen doute
That he had yeue it me bi cause of yow
To do ther with my profit and my prow
For Cosynage and ek for belchere
That he hath had ful often tymes here
But synnes I stond thus in this disioynt
I wol answer yow shortly to the poynt
¶ Ye han mo slakker dettour than am I.
For I wil pay yow wel and redily
Fro day to day and yif so be I faille
I am your wif score it vpon my taille
And I shal pay it as sone as euer I may
Mi connyng is to weik . o . blisful quene
For to declare thi gret worthinesse
That I ne may nat my wit sustene
But as child of twelue moneth olde or lesse
That can vnnethes eny word expꝰersse
Right so fare I and ther fore I yow preye
Endityth my song that I shal of yow seye
Here bigynneth the Prioresse tale.
Ther was in Asy in a gret Citee
Among cristen folk a Iewerye
Susteyned bi a lord of that contree
For foul vserye and lucre of vileynye
Hatful to crist and to his compaignye
And thurgh the strete men myght ride or wende
For it was fre and open at euꝰery ende
A litel scole of cristen folk ther stood
Doun at the ferther ende in which ther wer
Children an heep I come of cristes blood
That lered in that scole yer bi yer
Such maner doctirine as men vsed ther
This is to sey to singe and to rede
As smale children doon in hir childhede
Among this children was a widow son
A litel clergioun that .vij. yer was of age
That day bi day to scole was his won
And ek also wher so he sagh themage
Of cristes moder had he in vsage
As him was taught to knele adoun and sey
His Aue mary as he goth bi the wey
Thus hath this widow hir litel child taught
Our blisful lady cristes moder dere
To worship ay and he forgate it naght
For cely child wil alwey sone lere
But ay whan I remebre of this matere
Seint Nicholas stant euyr in my pꝰersence
For he so yong to crist ded reuerence
This litel child his litel book lernyng
As he sat in the scole at his primere
He alma redemptoris mater herd singe
As children lerned hir antiphoner
And as he durst he drow him ner and ner
And herkened ay the wordes and the note
Til he the first vers couth al bi rote
Noght wist he what this latyn was to say
For he so yonge and tendre was of age
But on a day his felaw gan he paray
To expoune him this songe in his langage
Or telle him whi this songe was in vsage
Thus preyde he him to construe and declare
Ful ofte tyme vpon his knees bare
His felaw which that elder was than he
Answerd him thus this songe I haue herd sey
Was makid of our lady blisful lady fre
Hir to salwe and ek hir to preye
To ben our help our Socour whan we deye
I can no more expoune in this Matere
I lerne song I can no more gramere
And is this song made in reuꝰerence
Of cristes modre seide this Innocente
Now certes I wol do my diligence
To kon it al. er cristenmasse be wente
Thogh that I al for my prymer shal be shente
Or shal be beten thries in an hour
I wol it kon our lady to honour
His felaw him taught homward priuely
Fro day to day til he couth it bi rote
And than he lerned it wel and boldly
Fro word to word acordyng to the note
Twies on a day it passed thurgh his throte
To scoleward and hoomward whan he went
Of cristes moder was set al his entent.
As I haue seide thurgh out the Iewrye
This litel childe as he cam to and fro
Ful myrily than wold he singe and crye
Alma redemptoris euer mo
The swetnes hath his hert persed so
Of cristes moder that to hir to prey
He can noght stynte of syngyng bi the wey
Our first foo the serpent sathanas
That hath in Iewes hert his waspes nest
Vp swal and seide .o. Eborak pepil allas
Is this a thing to yow that is honest
That swich a boy shal walken as him lest
In your despite and singe of swich sentence
Which is ayeins your lawes reuerence
Fro thennes forth the Iewes haue conspired
This Innocent out of this world to enchace
An homicide ther to han thei hired
With in an ale had he a pryue place
And as the child gan forth bi to pace
This fals Iuwe him hent and held him fast
And kitte his throte and thrue him atte last
I sey that in a warderope thei him thrue
Where as thise Iewes purgen her intraile
O cursed folk .o. heroudes al newe
What may your euel entent yow auayle
Mordre wol out certeyn it wol nat faile
And namely there the honour of god shold sprede
The blood out crieth on your cursid dede
O martyr sowdid to viirginitee
Now maistow synge folowyng euer in on
The white lambe celestial quod she
Of which the gret ewangelist seint Iohn
In pathmos wroot which seith that thei goon
Bifore the lambe and singe a songe al newe
That neuer flesshely wommen thei knew
This pore widow waiteth al this nyght
Aftyr this litel child but he cometh noght
For which als sone as it was dayes lyght
With face pale for drede and bisi thought
She hath at Scole and elles where him sought
Til fynally she gan so fer espye
That he was last seyn in the Iewerye
With modres pitee in hir herte brest enclosid
She goth as she were half out of hir mynde
To euꝰery place where as she hath supposid
Bi liklihed hir childe for to fynde
And euer on cristes moder meke and kynde
She cried and atte last thus she wroght
Among the cursed Iewes she him sought
She freyned and she preyde pitously
Of euꝰery Iewe that dwelled in that place
To telle hir yif hir child went ther by
Thei seide nay. but Ihu of his garace
Yaf in hir thought with ynne a litel space
That in that place aftyr hir sone she cride
Where he was cast in a pitte biside
O grete god that ꝑperformest thi laude
Be mouth of Innocentes lo here thi myght
This Gemme of chastite this Emerawde
And ek of Martirdom the ruby. bright
That he with throte I cut lay vpright
Hie Alma redemptoris gan to synge
So loude that al the place bigan to rynge
The cristen folk that thurgh the strete wente
In camen for to wonder on this thing
And hastily for the prouost thei sente
And he came anon with owte tarying
And heried crist that is heuen kyng
And ek his modre honour of mankynde
And after that the Iewes let he bynde
This childe with pitous lamentacioun
Vp taken was syngyng his song alwey
And with honour and gret processioun
Thei caryed him to the next Abbay
His modir swownyng bi the bere lay
Vnnethes myght the peple that was there
This new Rachel brynge fro the bere
With turment and with shameful ded echon
This prouost doth this Iewes for to sterue
That of this morder wist and that anon
He nolde no swich cursednesse obserue
Euel shal haue that euel wol deserue
Therfore with wild horses he did hem drawe
And aftyr that he henge hem bi the lawe
Upon his bere lith ay this Innocente
Biforn the chief auter whiles messe last
And aftyr that the Abbot with his Couente
Hath spedde him for to biry him ful fast
And whan thei halywater on him cast
Yit spak this child whan spreyned was the halywater
And Songe .o. Alma redemptoris mater
This Abbot which that was an holy man
As monkes ben or elles ought to be
This yonge childe to coniure he bigan
And seide .o. dere child I coniure the
In vꝰertue of the holy trynyte
Telle me what is thi cause for to synge
Syn that thi throte is kit at my semynge
My throte is kit vnto my nekboon
Seyde this child and as bi wey of kynde
I shuld be ded longe tyme agon
But Ihu crist as ye in bokes fynde
Wole that his glori last and be in mynde
And for the worshep of his moder dere
Yit may I synge .o. alma loude and clere
This welle of mercy cristes moder swete
I loued alwey as aftyr my connynge
And whan that I my lif shul lete
To me she cam and bade me for to synge
This anteme verryly in my dyinge
As ye han herd and whan that I had songe
Me thought she leyde a greyn vnder my tonge
Wherfore I synge and synge mote certeyne
In honour of that blisful Maiden fre
Til fro my tonge of taken is the greyne
And aftyr that thus seide she to me
Mi litel child now wol I fecche the
Whan that the greyn is fro the tonge I take
Be noght agast I wol the noght forsake
This holy monk this Abbot him mene .I.
His tonge out caught and cast awey the greyne
And he yaf vp the gost ful softely
And whan the Abbot hath this wondre seyne
His salt teres striken doun as reyne
And groue he fel as plat to the grounde
And stille he lay as he had ben I bounde
The Couent ek lay vpon the pauement
Wepyng and herying cristes moder dere
And aftyr that thei rise and forth thei went
And took awey this Martyr fro the bere
And in a tombe of Marbil stones clere
Enclose thei this litel body swete
Ther he is now god leue vs for to mete
O yonge Hugh of lyncoln I slayn also
With cursid Iewes as it is notable
For it is but a litel while ago
Preye ek for vs we synful folk vnstable
That of his Mercy god so mercyable
On vs his gret mercy multiplie
For reuerence of his moder marye
Here bygynneth the rehetyng of our hoost
Whanne seyde was this miracle euꝰery man
As sobre was that wonder was to se
Til that our host iape bigan
And thenne at erst he loked vpon me
And seide thus what man artow quod he
Thow lokest as thow woldest fynde an hare
For euer vpon the grounde I se the stare
Approche ner and loke myrily
Now war yow syres and let this man haue space
He in the wast is as wel shape as .I.
This were a popet in armes to embrace
For eny womman smal and fair of face
He semeth eluyssh bi his contenance
For vnto no wight doth he daliaunce
Sey now somwhat sithens othir folk han said
Telle vs a tale and of murthe anon
Host quod I ne beth nat euel apayde
For other tale certes can I non
But of a ryme I lerned yore agoon
Ye that is good quod he now shul we here
Som deyntee thing me thinketh bi his chere
Here bigynneth Chaucers tale of syr Topias .
Listeth lordynges in good entente
And I wol telle veramente
Of mirthe and of solas
Al of a knyght was fair and gent
In bataille and in tornament
His name was sir Thopas
Iborn he was in fer contre
In flaundres al bi yonde the see
At poperyng in the place
His fader was a man ful fre
And lord he was of that contre
As it was goddes grace
¶ Sir topas was a doghti swayn
Whit was his face as payndemayn
His lippes Red as Rose
His rode is lik scarlet in greyn
As I yow telle in good certeyn
He had a semely nose
¶ His heer his berd was lik Safron
That to his girdel raght adoun
His shone of cordewane
Of brugges were his hosen broun
His Robe was of Siklatoun
That cost many a Iane
¶ He coude hunt at wild dere
And ride an haukyng for Ryvere
Wtith grey goshaukes on honde
Therto he was a good Archere
Of wrastelyng was ther non his pere
Ther any Ram shal stonde
¶ Ful many maide bright in bour
Thei moorned for him paramour
Whan hem were bet to slepe
But he was chaast and no lecchour
And swete as is the brambel flour
That bereth the rede hepe
¶ And so it fil vpon a day
For sothe as I yow telle may
Syr Thopas wold out ride
He warth vpon his stede gray
And in his hond a launcegay
A longe swerd bi his side
¶ He priketh thurgh a faire forest
Ther ynne is many a wilde best
Ye . bothe buk and hare
And as he piriketh North and Est
I telle it yow him hed almest
Bitid a sori care
¶ Ther spryngen herbes gret and smale
The licoris and the Cetewale
And many a clow gilofre
And notemuge to put in Ale
Whether it be moist or stale
Or for to ley in Cofre
¶ The briddes synge it is no nay
The sꝑperhauk and the popyniay
That Ioy it was to here
The threstilcok mad ek his lay
The wode dowue vpon the spray
She sange ful loude and clere
¶ Sir topias fil in loue longyng
And whan he herd the throstel syng
He piriked as he were wod
His fair stede in his pirikyng
So swat that men myght him wrynge
His sides were al blod
¶ Syr Thopias ek so wery was
For prikyng e softe gras
So fiers was his corage
That doun he leide him in the plas
To make his stede som solas
And yaf him good forage
¶ O seynt Marye benedicite
What eyleth this loue at me
To bynde me so sore
Me dremed al this nyght parde
An elf quene shal my lemman be
And slepe vnder my gore
¶ An Elf quene wol I haue I wis
For in this world no womman is
Worthi to be my make . In towne
¶ Al other wommen I forsake
And to an elf quene I me take
Bi dale and ek bi downe
¶ In to his sadel he clambe anon
And piriketh ouer stile and ston
An Elfe quene for tespie
Til he so longe hath riden and gon
That he fonde in a pryue won
The contre of fairye
So wilde
For in that contre was ther non .
neither wif ne childe
¶ Til that ther come a gre geaunt
His name was syr Olifaunt
A perilous man of dede
He seide bi turmagaunt
But yif thow pirike of myn haunt
Anon I sle thi stede
Wtith mace
¶ Here is the quene of fairye
With harpe and pipe and synphonye
Dwellyng in the place
¶ The childe seide as mote I the
To morwe wol I mete the
Whan I haue myn Armoure
And yit I hope par ma fay
That thow shalt with this launcegay
Abyen it ful soure
Thi mawe
Shal I percen yif I may
Er it be fully prime of day
for here shaltow beslawe
Sir Thopias drow on bak ful fast
This Geaunt at him stones cast
Out of a fel staf slynge
¶ But faire escapeth child topias
And al it was thurgh goddes gras
And thurgh his fair berynge
¶ Yet listeth lordynges to my tale
Miryour than the nyghtyngale
I wole yow rowne
How syr Thopias with sides smale
Prikyng ouer hille and dale
Is come ageyn to towne
¶ His mery men comaunded he
To make him bothe game and gle
for nedes most he fighte
With a geant with hedes thre
For paramour and Iolite
Of on that shon ful brighte
¶ Do come he seide mynstralles
And gestoures for to tellen tales
Anon in myn Armyng
Of Romances that ben Reales
Of popes and of Cardynales
And ek of loue likyng
¶ Thei fette him first swete wyn
And meed ek in a Maselyn
And real spicery
Of gyngerebred that was ful fyn
And licoris and ek comyn
With sugre that is trye
¶ He dide next his white lere
Of cloth of lake fyn and clere
A breche and ek a sherte
And next his shert an aketon
And ouer that an habergeon
for percyng of his herte
¶ And ouer that a fyne hauberk
Was al Iwroght of Iewes werk
ful stronge it was of plate
And ouer that his cotearmour
As white as is a lily flour
In which he wol debate
¶ His shelde was al of gold so rede
And ther ynne was a boores heede
A Charbocle bi his side
And there he swoor in ale and brede
How that the geant shuld be dede
betide what betyde
¶ Hise Iambeux were of quyrboily
His swerdes shethe of yuory
His helme of laton bright
His sadel was of Rowel bon
His bridel of the sonne shon
Or as the mone light
¶ His spere was of fyne Cipres
That bodeth werre and no thing peece
the heed ful sharp I grond .
The stede was al dappled gray
It goth an amble in the way
ful softely and rounde
In londe
¶ Lo lordes myn here is a fit
If ye wol any More of it
To telle it wol I fonde
¶ Now holdeth your mouth par charite
Both knyght and lady fre
And herkeneth to my spelle
¶ Of bataille and of Chiialrye
And of ladyes loue drurye
Anon I wol yow telle
Men speken of Romances of pris
¶ Of hornchild and ypotis
Of bevys and syr gye
Of syr libeux and playndamour
But syr Topas he bereth the flour
Of ryal Chyualrye
His good stede al he bistrode
And forth on his wey he gloode
As sparcle out of the bronde
¶ Vpon his crest he bar a tour
And ther ynne stiked a lily flour
God shelde his corps fro shonde
And for he was a knyght auntrous
He nold slepen in non hous
but liggen in his hood
¶ His bright helme was his wonger
And bi him baiteth his destrere
Of herbes fyn and good
Him self dranke water of the welle
As dide the knyght syr percyuelle
So worthly vnder wood .
Here bigynneth a reheytyng of our hoost
Na more of this for goddes dignite
Quod our host for thow makest me
So wery of thi verry lewdenesse
That also wisly god my soule blesse
Myn eris aken of thi drasty speche
Now swich aryme the deuel I beteche
This may be wel Ryme dogerel quod he
¶ Whi so quod I whi wiltow lette me
More of my tale than an other man
Syn that it is the best Ryme I can
¶ Bi god quod he for pleynly at o word
Thi drasti rymyng is nat worth a tord
Thow doost noght elles but dispendest tyme
Sir at a word thow shalt no lenger ryme
Lat se wher thow canst tellen oght in geste
Or telle in prose som what at the leste
In which ther be som myrthe or som doctirine
¶ Gladly quod I bi goddes swete pyne
I wole yow telle a litel thing in prose
That oght to like yow as I suppose
Or elles certes ye ben to daungerous
It is a moral tale vꝰertuous
Al be it tolde some tyme in sondry wise
¶ Of sondry folk as shal I yow deuyse
As thus ye wot that euꝰery Evangeliste
That telleth vs the peyne of Ihu crist
Ne seith nat al thing as his felaw dooth
But nathalees hir sentence is al sooth
And alle accorden as in hir sentence
Al be ther in hir tellyng difference
For some of hem seyn more and som seyn lesse
Whan thei his pitous passioun expꝰersse
I mene of Mark Mathew Luk. and Iohn .
But douteles hir sentence is al on
Therfore lordynges al y yow beseche
If that ye thinke I varye as in my speche
As thus thogh that I telle som what more
Of prouerbes than ye han herd bifore
Compꝰerhended in this litel tretis here
To enforcen with theffect of my matere
And though I noght the same wordes seye
As ye han herd yit to yow alle I preye
Blasphemeth me nat for as in my sentence
Shul ye noghwher fynden difference
Fro the sentence of this tretes lite
After the which this myrie tale I wryte
And therfore herkeneth what that I shal seye
And lat me tellen al my tale I preye .

div.ab: Here bigynneth Chaucers tale of Melibee and prudence

A yong man called Melibeus mighty and riche bigat vpon
his wif that called was prudence a doghtre which
that called was sophie //

vpon a day befel that for his
disport he went in to the feeldes him to pley /

his wif and ek his
doughter hath he lafte in with his hous / of which the dores
weren fast y shette /

the chief of his olde foos han it espied and
setten laddres to the walles of his hous / and bi wyndowes
ben entred /

and betten his wif and wounded his doughter
with fyue Mortal woundes in fyue sondry places /

this is to
seyn .in hir feet. in hir handes. in hir eris. in hir nose. and in
hir mouth. and leften hir for deed.and wenten a way

¶ Whan
Melibeus retourned was in to his hous / and seigh al this mes-
chief. ¶ he lik a mad man / rentyng his clothis gan to wepe
and crie

¶ Prudence his wif as ferforth as she dorste / bisoght
him of his wepyng for to stynte /

but nat for thi / he gan to wepe
and crye euer the lenger the more

¶ This noble wif prudence re-
membred hir vpon the sentence of Ouyde in his book ¶ that cle-
ped is the remedye of loue ¶ where as he seith

¶ he is a
fool that destourbeth the moder to wepe ¶ in the deth of hir
childe. til she haue wepte hir fille as for a certeyn tyme /

and
thanne shal man doon ¶ his diligence with amyable wordes
hir to reconforte and preyen hir of hir wepyng for to stynte

For
which reson this noble wif prudence ¶ soffred hir husbonde for
to wepe and crie as for a certeyn space

¶ and whan she say hir
tyme she seide him in this wise . ¶ Allas my lord quod she whi
make ye your self for to be lik a fool

for sothe ¶ it apperteyneth
nat to a wise man to maken swich sorwe

for your doughter wtith
the grace of god shal warisshe and escape.

¶ And al were it
so that she right now were deed / ye ne oght nat as for hir deth
your self destroy

¶ Senec seith the wiseman shal nat take
to gret disconfort for the deth of his children /

but certes he
shulde suffren it in pacience as wel as he abideth the deth of
his owne propre ꝑpersone

¶ This Melibeus answerd anon and
seide ¶ What man quod he shulde of his wepyng stynte
that hath so grete a cause for to wepe

Ihu crist our lord him self
wept for the deth of lazarus his freend.

¶ Prudence answerd
certes wel I woot attempre wepyng is no thing defended to
him that sorweful is amonges folk in sorowe but it is graunted
rather him to wepe

¶ The Apostle poul vnto the Romayns writeth
Man shal reioysse with hem that maketh ioy / and wepe with
swich folk as wepen

But though attempre wepyng be graunted
¶ Outerageous wepyng certes is defended

Mesure of wepyng
sholde be considerid after the lore that techeth vs Senec.

Whan
that thi frend is deed quod he / lat nat thyn eyn to moiste ben
of tiers ne to moche drye. ¶ Al thogh thi tiers comen to thyn
eyen lat hem nat falle

¶ And whan thow hast forgon thi frend
Do thi diligence to geten a nother frend / and this is more wise-
dom than for to wepe for thi frend which that thow hast lorn
¶ for ther in is no boote

¶ And therfore yif ye gouerne yow by
sapience / put away sorwe out of your herte

Remembreth yow
that Ihus Syrak seith A man that is ioyous and glad in hert
it him conserueth florisshing in his age ¶ But soothly so-
rowful herte maketh his bones drye

he seith ek thus / that
sorow in herte sleeth ful many a man /

Salamon seith / that
right as moththes in the shepes flees / anoyeth to the clothes
and the smale wormes to the tree . Ryght so anoyeth sorwe to
the herte

¶ Wherfore vs ought as wel in the deth of our chil-
dren as in the losse of our goodes temporels haue pacience

Re-
membre yow vpon the pacient Iob whan he had lost his children
and his temporel substance / and in his body endured and re-
ceyued ful many a greuous tribulacioun / yit seide he thus .

Our
lord hath biraft it me right so as our lord wolde. right so it is
ydoon I blessid be the name of our lord

To thise forseide thinges
answerd Melibeus vnto his wif prudence . Alle thi wordes quod
he ben sooth and therto ꝓprofitable . but trewly myn hert is trou-
bled with this sorwe so greuously that I not what to done.

¶ Lat calle quod prudence thi trew frendes alle and thin ly-
nage which that ben wise telleth your cas and herkeneth what
thei sey in conseilynge and yow gouerne after hir sentence .

Sa-
lamon seith werk alle thi thinges bi counseil and thow shalt
neuer repente

¶ Thanne bi the counseil of his wif dence
this Melibeus leet callen a greet congregacioun of folk

as sur-
giens Phisiciens olde folk and yonge and somme of his olde ene-
mys reconsiled as bi hir semblant to his loue and in to his grace

and ther with al. ther comen somme of his neigh bores that diden
him reuerence moore for drede than for loue as it happeth ofte

Theer coomen also ful many subtil flaterers and wis aduocatz
lerned in the lawe

and whan this folk assembled were to gider
This Mellibeus in sorowful wise shewed hem his cas.

¶ And bi
the Maner of his speche it semed that in herte he baar a cruel
Ire redy to doon vengeaunce vpon his foos and sodeynly desired
the werre sholde bygynne

but nathalees yit axed he hir counseil
vpon this mater

¶ A surgien bi licence and assent of swich as
were wise vp roos and vn to Melibeus seide as ye may here

¶ Syr quod he as to vs Surgiens apperteyneth / that we do
euꝰery wight the best that we can ¶ Where as beth with holden
and to our pacientz that we do no damage

¶ Wherfore it hap-
