ther pursue to your aduꝰersaries for pees than thei shullen to yow

¶ For I know wel that ye ben so hard herted that ye wol do no
thing for me /

And Salamon seith / that he that hath ouer
hard a herte atte last he shal myshappe and mys tyde.

Whanne Melibee had herd dame prudence make semblant
of wrath he seide in this wise

¶ Dame y prey yow that ye
be nat displesed of thinges that I sey

¶ For ye know wel
that I am angry and wroth / and that is no wonder

and thei
that ben wrooth witen nat wel what thei doon ne what
thei seyn

therfore the prophete seith that troubled eyen han
no clere sight /

but seieth or conseileth me as yow liketh / for I am
redy to do / right as ye wol desire /

And yif ye repreue me of
my foly I am the more holden to loue yow and to preyse yow
¶ For Salamon seith that he that repreueth him that doth foly

he shal fynde gretter grace than he that desceyueth bi swete
wordes

Thanne seide Dame prudence I make no semblant
of wrath ne of angir / but for your gret ꝓprofit

¶ For Salamon
seith / he is more worth that repreueth or chideth a fool for his folie
shewyng him semblant of wrath

¶ than he that supporteth him
and preiseth him in his mysdoyng / and laugheth at his folye //

And
this same Salamon seith aftyrward That bi the soroweful visage
of a man that is to seyn ¶ bi the sori and bi the heuy contenance
of a man
¶ the fool correcteth and amendeth him self

¶ Thanne
seide Melibee I shal nat konne answere vn to so many fayr resons
¶ As ye putten to me and shewen

¶ seith shortly your wille and
your conseille ¶ And I am al redy ¶ to fulfille and parforme it

Thanne Dame prudence discouered alle hir wille vn to him
and seide

¶ I conseille yow quod she abouen alle thinges that
ye make pees be twene god and yow

and beth reconsiled on to
him and to his grace

¶ For as I haue seide yow here biforn god
hath suffred yow to haue this tribulacioun and desese for your
synnes

and yif ye do as I sey yow god wol sende your aduꝰersaries
vn to yow

and make hem falle at your feet ¶ redy to do your
wille and your commaundementz

¶ For Salamon seith whan
the condicioun of a man is plesant and likyng to god

he chaun-
geth the hertes of the mannes aduꝰersaries ¶ And constreyneth
hem to biseke him of pees and of garace /

And I prey yow lat me
speke with your aduersaries in pryue place

¶ For thei shal nat
know that it be your wille or your assent /

And thanne whan
I know hir wille and hir entente I may conseil yow the more
surely
Dame quod Melibee doth your wille and your likynge
For I putte me hooly in your disposicioun and ordynaunce

Thanne prudence / whan she say the good wille of hir hus-
bond / deliuered and took auys in hir self

thinkyng how she
myght brynge this nede vn to a good conclusioun and to a
good ende

¶ And whan she saugh hir tyme she sent for thise
aduersaries to come vnto hir in to a pryue place

And shewed
wysely vn to hem ¶ the greet goodes that comen of pees //

and
the gret harmes and perils that been in werre

¶ And seide
to hem in a goodly manere how that hem oghten haue gret
repentance

of the inIurie and wronge that thei hadden
doon. ¶ to Melibee hir lord and vn to hir and to hir doghter
¶ And whan thei harden the goodlych wordes of Dame prudence

thei weren so supprised and rauysshed and hadden so gret Ioye
of hir that wonder was to telle

¶ A lady quod thei ye han
shewed vnto vs / the blessyng of swetnesse ¶ after the saw of
Dauid the prophete

¶ For the reconsilyng which we ne been nat
worthi to haue in no maner

but we oghten requeren it ¶ with gret
contricioun and humilitee /

ye of your gret goodnesse haue pꝰersen-
ted vn to vs /

Now se we wel / that the science and the konnyng
of Salamon is ful trewe

¶ For he seith / that swete wordes
multiplien and encresen frendes / And maken shrewes to be de-
bonayr and meke

¶ Certes quod thei we putten our dede / and
al our matere and cause and al holly in your good wille

¶ and
been redy to obeyn on to the speche and commaundement of my
lord Melibee

¶ And therfore dere and benygne lady we preyn
yow / and biseken yow as mekely as we konne and mowen

that it like vn to your gret goodnesse ¶ to fulfille in dede your
goodlych wordes

¶ For we consideren and knowlechen / that
we han offended and greued my lord Melibee out of mesure
so ferforth that we be nat of power to maken his amendes

And therfore we oblige and bynde vs ¶ and our frendes for
to do al his wille / and his comaundementz /

but perauenture
he hath swich heuynesse and swich wrath to vs ward bi cause
of our offence

¶ that he wol enioyne vs swich a payne as
we mow nat bere ¶ ne sustene /

And therfore / noble lady /
we beseken vnto your wommanly pitee

to taken swich a visement
in this nede ¶ that we ne our frendes ben nat disherite
and destroyed thurgh our folye.

¶ Certes quod prudence it is
an hard thing and right perilous

that a man putte him al
outrely in the arbitracioun and Iuggement and in the myght
and power of his enemys /

For Salamon seith / leeueth me
and yeueth me credence to that / that I shal seyn ¶ I sey
quod he the peple folk and gouernours of holy chirche /

to thi sone
and to thi wif

¶ ne to thi brother yeue thow neuer myght ne
maistrie ¶ of thi body whil thow lyuest

Now sithen he de-o
fendeth / that men shuld not yeue to his brother ne to his frend
¶ the myght of his body

¶ by a strenger resoun he defendeth and
forbedeth a man to yeuen himself to his enemye

¶ And nathales
I conseil yow that ye mystrust nat my lord

¶ For I woot wel
and knowe verrayly ¶ that he is debonaire and meke ¶ large
curteys
¶ and no thing desirous ne coueitous of good ne richesses

¶ For ther nys no thing in this world that he desireth saue oonly
worshep and honour

¶ Forthermore I knowe ¶ and am right
sure ¶ that he shal no thing do in this nede with outen my
counseil

And I shal so werken in this cause that bi grace of
our lord god ye shul be reconsiled vnto vs

¶ Thanne seiden
thei with .o voys ¶ Worshipfull lady we putten vs and our
goodes ¶ al fully in your wille and disposicioun

¶ And ben
redy to come what day ¶ that it like to your noblesse to ly-
myte vs or assigne vs

¶ For to make our obligacioun and
bonde as stronge ¶ as it liketh to your goodnesse

that we
mow fulfille / the wille of yow / and of my lord Melibee

¶ Whanne dame prudence had herd the answers of thise men
¶ she bad hem go ageyn pryuely

¶ And she retourned ageyn to
hir lord Melibee and tolde him ¶ how she fand his aduersaries
ful repentant /

knowlechyng ful lowly hir synnes and trespas
and how thei weren redy ¶ to suffren al peyne /

requyryng
and preyng him of mercy and of pitee

¶ Thanne seide Melibe
he is wel worthi to haue pardon and foryefnesse of his synne
¶ but knowlecheth and repreueth him axyng Indulgence

¶ For
Senek seith / there as is the remissioun and foryefnesse where
as the confusioun is
neighbore to Innocence

¶ And therfore
I assent and conforme me / to haue pees /

but it is good that
we do it nat with outen thassent and wille of our freendes
Thanne was prudence righ glad and ioyful and seide .

Certes
syr quod she ¶ ye han wel and goodly answerd

¶ For right
a bi the conseille ¶ assent and helpe / of your frendes ¶ ye han
be stired to venge yow / and make werre /

right so with outen
your conseil / shul ye nat accorde yow / ne haue pees / with
your aduersaries

¶ For the lawe seith ¶ Ther nys no thing
so good bi wey of kynde / as a thing to ben vnbounde ¶ by
him that it was ybounde

And thanne dame prudence with
outen delay or tarying ¶ sent anon messages // For hir
kyn and for hir olde frendes which that were trewe and
wise

and tolde hem bi ordre in the pꝰersence of Melibee of this
matere as it is aboue expꝰerssed and declared

and preyed hem
¶ that thei wold yeue her auys and conseil ¶ what were to
do in this nede

¶ And whan Melibeus frendes had taken hir
auys and deliberacioun of the forseyde matere

¶ and hadden exami-
ned it bi gret bisynesse ¶ and gret diligence

¶ thei yaf ful conseil
for to haue pees and reste

¶ And that Melibee shuld receyue wyth
good herte his aduersaries to foryeuenesse and mercy

¶ And whan
Dame prudence had herd thassent of hir lord Melibee and the con-
seil of his frendes
accorde with hir wil and hir entencioun

¶ She
was wonderly glad in hir herte and seide

ther is an olde pro-
uerbe quod she that seith ¶ That the goodnesse that thow
maiste do this day ¶ Do it

abide nat / ne delay it nat til to-
morwe

¶ And therfore I conseil that ye senden your Messages
swich as ben discrete and wise

vnto your aduersaries / tellyng
hem on your bihalue

¶ that yif thei wol trete of pees / and
of acord

thei shapen hem with oute delay or taryinge to
come to /vs.
which thing parformed was in dede /

and whan
thise trespassours / and repentyng folk of his folies that is to
seyn the aduersaries of Melibee

¶ hadden herd what thise
Messagers seiden vnto hem

thei weren right glad and ioyful
and answerden benygnely and ful mekely

yeldyng graces
and thankynges to hir lord Melibee ¶ And to al his compaynye

¶ And shopen hem with outen delay to go with the Messageres
and obeye ¶ to the comaundement of hir lord Melibee //

And
right anon thei token hir wey to the contree of Melibee

¶ And tooken with hem hir trew frendes to make feith for hem
and for to ben hir borowes

And whan thei were comen to the
pꝰersence of Melibee he seide hem thise wordes

¶ It standeth
thus that Melibee and soth it is / that ye

causelees and with
oute skyle and reson

han doon gret Iniuries and wronges to
me and to my wif prudence and to my doughter also

¶ For ye
han entred in to myn hous bi violence

and han doon swich
outerages that alle men knowen wel that ye han deserued
the deth /
And therfore wol I knowe and wit of yow /

whether
ye wol putte the punysshyng and chastisyng and the vengeance
of this outerage in the wil of me / and of my wif or ye wol
nat /

thanne the wisest of hem thre answerd for hem alle and
seide /

syr quod he we knowen wel that we ben vn worthi
to come vnto the court of so gret a lord / and so worthi as ye
ben

¶ For we han so gretly mystaken vs and han offended
and agelt in swich a wise a gayn your hie lordshipe

¶ and
trewly we han deserued the deth /

but yit for the gret goodnesse
¶ And debonairetee that alle the world witnesseth of your ꝑpersone //

we
submitten vs to the excellence and benygnytee of your gracious
lordshepe
and ben redy to obeye to alle your comaundementz

bise-
kyng yow that of your mercyable pitee ¶ ye wol consider our
gret repentaunce and lowe submissioun

and graunt vs foryefnes
of our outerageous trespas and offense

For wel we knowen that
your liberal grace and mercy strecchen hem ferther in to goodnesse
¶ than doon our outerageous gilte and trespas in to wikkednesse

Al be it that cursedly and dampnabely we han agilt ageyn
your hie lordshepe

¶ Thanne Melibee took him vp fro the ground
ful benygnely

and resceyued hir obligaciouns ¶ and hir bondes
bi hir othes vnto hir plegges and borowes

and assigned hem
a certeyn day ¶ to retourne vnto his court

for to accepte and
resceyue the sentence and /Iugement that Melibee wolde co-
maunde to be doon / on hem bi the causes aforeseid /

which
thinges ordeyned / euꝰery man retourned to his hous /

And whan
that dame prudence sagh hir tyme she freyned and axed hir
lord Melibee

what vengeance he thoght to taken of his aduꝰer
saries /

to which / Melibee answerd and seide Certes quod he
I thinke and purpose me fully

to disherite hem of al that euer
thei han ¶ and for to putte hem in exile for euer.

Certes quod
dame prudence this were a cruel sentence and mochel ageyn
resoun /

for ye ben riche ynow / and han no nede of other men-
nes good

¶ And ye myghten lightly in this wise gete yow a
coueitous name

which is a vicious thing / and oght to ben
eschued of euꝰery good man

¶ For after the Sawe or the word
of thapostle Coueitise is root of al harmes /

And therfore it
were bettre for yow to lese so muchel good of your owne ¶ than
for to take of hir good in this manere

¶ For better it is to lese
good with worshepe / than it is to wynne good with vileynye
and shame

and euꝰery man oght to do his diligence and his
bisinesse to gete him a good name

¶ And yit shal he nat oonly
bisy him in kepyng his good name

but he shal also enforcen him
alwey to doon some thing bi which he may renouel his good
name

¶ For it is writen that the old good loos or good na-
me of a man is soon goon and passed whan it is nat newed
ne renoueled

¶ And as touchyng that ye seyn ye wol exile your aduꝰersa-
ries
¶ that thinketh me muchel ageyn resoun and out of mesure

con-
sidred the power that thei han yeuen yow vpon hem self

And it is
wreten that he is worthi to lese his priuylege that mys vseth ¶ the
myght and the power that is yeuen him

¶ And I set cas ye myght
enioynen hem that peyne bi right / and bi lawe /

which .I. trow ye
mow nat do

I seye ye myght nat putte it to execucioun perauentu-
re

and thenne were it likly / to retourne to the werre ¶ as it was
biforne /

and therfore yif ye wole / that men do yow obeisance yow
moste deme more curteysly /

this is to seyn ye moste yeue more esi
sentences Iugementz

For it is wreten that he most curtey-
sely comaundeth / to him moste obeyen

and therfore I prey yow
as in this necessitee and in this nede ye cast yow to ouercome
your in herte

¶ For Senec seith / that he that ouercometh his herte
ouercometh twies /.

And Tulliius seith ther is no thing so comenda-
ble in a gret lord

as whan he is debonayre and meke and appei-
seth him lightly

And I prey yow that ye wol sobre now to do
vengeance

in swich maner ¶ that your good name be kept and
conserued /

and that men mow haue cause and matere to preise
yow of pite and of mercye

and that ye haue no cause to repente
yow of thinge that ye doon

¶ For Senek seith he ouercometh in
al yuel maner that repenteth him of his victorie /

wherfore I paray
yow let mercy be in your herte

to effect and entente that god
almyghty haue mercy on yow ¶ In his last Iugement //

For seint
Iame seith / Iugement with oute mercy / shal be doon to him
that no mercy. of a nother wight /

Whan Melibee had herd the
gret skiles and resons of dame prudence / and hir wise infor-
maciouns and techynges

his herte gan enclyne to the wil of
his wif consideryng hir trew entente /

conformed him anon
and assented fully to werken aftyr hir counseil

and thonked god
of whom procedeth al vertue and alle goodnesse that him
sent a wif of so gret discrescioun

¶ And whan the day came
that hise aduꝰersaries shuld appere in his pꝰersence

he spak to hem
ful goodly and seyde

¶ al be it so that of your pride by pre-
sumpcioun and folie and of your necligence and your vnkon-
nyng /
ye haue mysborne yow and trespaced vnto me /

yit
for as muchel as I se and biholde your gret humilitee

and
that ye ben sory and repentant / of your giltes /

it constreyneth me
to do you grace and mercy /
Wherfore I receyue yow tomy garace

and foryeue yow outrely alle the offences Iniuries and wron-
ges that ye han doon ageyn me and myn

to this effect and
to this ende that god of his endeles mercy

wol at the tyme
of our dyyng foryeue vs oure giltes that we han trespassed
to him in this wrecched world

for doutelees if we be sory
and repentant of the synnes which we han trespassed in
the sight of our lord god
he is so free and so mercyable

that
he wol foryeue vs our giltes

and brynge vs to the blisse that
neuꝰer hath ende
¶ Here endeth Chaucers tale of Melibee and prudence

div.l: Here bigynneth the prologe of the monkes tale
Whan ended was my tale of Melibee
And of prudence and hir benygnytee
Our hoost seide as I am feithful man
And bi that pꝰercious corps Madryan
I had leuer than a barel ale
That good leef my wif had herd this tale
She nys no thing of swich pacience
As was Melibeus with prudence
By goddes boones whanne I bete my knaues
She bryngeth me the grete clubbed staues
And crieth sle the dogges euꝰerychon
And breke hem bothe bakke and euꝰery boon
And yif that eny neyghbore of myn
Wol nat in chirche to my wif enclyne
Or be so hardy to hir to trespace
Whan she comth she raumpeth in my face
And crieth fals coard wreke thi wif
By corpus boones I wol haue thi knyf
And thow shalt haue my distaf and go spynne
Fro day to nyght right thus shul we bygynne
Allas she seith that euer I was shape
To wedde a melkesop or a coward ape
That wol ben ouerlad with euꝰery wight
Thow darst not stonden with thi wyues right
This is my lif but but that I wil fighte
And oute atte dore anon I mote me dighte
Or elles I am but lost but yif that I
Bee like a wilde leoun fool hardy
I woot wel she wol do me sle some day
Some neighbore and thanne go my way
For I am perilous with knyf in honde
Al be it that I dar nat with hir stonde
For she is bigge in armes bi my feith
That shal he fynde that hir mysdooth or seith
But lat vs passe awey fro this matere
Mi lord the monk quod he be mery of chere
For ye shul telle a tale trewly
Lo Rochestre stont here fast by
Ride forth myn owne lord breke not our game
But bi my trouthe I know nat your name
Wher shal I calle yow my lord daun Iohn
Or daun Thomas or elles daun albion
Of what hous be ye bi your fader kyn
I vow to god thow hast a ful fayr skyn
It is a gentil pasture there thow gost
Thow art nat like a penant or a goost
Vpon my feith thow art some officere
Som worthi sexteyn or some Celerere
For bi my fader soule as to my dom
Thow art a maystyr whan thou art at hom
No poure cloystrer ne no nouys
But a gouꝰernour worthi and wis
And therwith al of brawnes and boones
A welfaryng ꝑpersone for the nones
I prey to god yeue him confusioun
That the first broght vnto Religioun
Thow woldest han ben a tredefoul aright
Haddestow as grete a leue as thow hast myght
To parfourmen al thi lust in engendrure
Thow haddest bigeten ful many a creature
Allas whi werestow so side a cope
God yeue me sorowe but and I were a pope
Nat oonly thow but euꝰery myghti man
Though he were shore ful hie vpon his pan
Shuld haue a wif for al the world is lorn
Religioun hath taken vp al the corn
Of tredyng and we borel men been shrympes
Of feble trees ther comen wykked ympes
This maketh that our heires beth so sclendre
And feble that thei may nat wel engendre
This maketh that our wyues wol assaye
Religious folk for ye mow bettre paye
Of venus paymentz thanne may we
God woot no lussheborn payen ye
But be nat wroth lord thogh that I pleye
Ful ofte in game a soth I haue herd seye
This worthi monk took al in pacience
And seide I wol doon al my diligence
As fer as souneth in to honestee
To telle yow a tale or two or thre
And yif yow list to herken hiderward
I wol seyn yow the lif of seint Edward
Or ellis first tragedies wol I telle
Of which I haue an hundred in my celle
Tragedies is to seyn a certeyn storye
As olde bookes maken vs memorie
Of him that stood in gret ꝓprosperyte
And is y fallen out of high degre
In to myserye and endeth wrecchedly
And thei ben versified comunely
Of vj. feet which men clepen Exametroūn
In prose eek ben enditeth many oon
And eke in metre in many a sondry wise
Loo this declaryng oghte ynogh suffise
Now herkeneth if yow liketh for to here
But first I yow beseke in this matere
Thogh I by ordre telle nat thise thinges
Be it of Popes Emperours or kynges
Aftyr hir ages as men writen fynde
But telle hem Som by fore and som bi hynde
As it now comth vn to my remembrance
Haue me excused of myn ignorance
Here endeth the prologe
Here bigynneth the monkes tale
I wol biwaille in manere of tragedie
The harm of hem that stood in high degree
And fillen so / that ther nas no remedye
To brynge hem out of hir aduersite
For certeyn whan that fortune list to fle
Ther may no man the cours of hir with holde
Lat no man truste on blynde prosperyte
Bewar bi thise ensamples trew and olde
At lucifer though he an aungel were
And nat a man at him I wol bygynne
For though fortune may noon aungel dere
From high degree yit fel he for his synne
Doun in to helle where as he yit is ynne
O lucifer brightest of aungels alle
Now artow sathanas that maist nat twynne
Out of miserye in which that thow art falle
Too Adam in the felde of damassene
With goddes owne fynger wroght was he
And noght bigoten of mannes sperme vnclene
And welt al paradys sauyng .o. tre
Hadde neuer worldly man so high degree
As adam til he for mysgouernaunce
Was dryue out of his high prosꝑperytee
To labour and to helle and to meschaunce
To sampson which that was annuncat
Bi the aungel longe er his natyuitee
And was to god almyghti consecrat
And stood in noblesse whil he myght se
Was neuer swich another as was he
To speke of streyngth and therwith hardynesse
But to hise wyues told he his secree
Thurgh which he slow himself for wrecchednesse
Sampson this noble almyghti champioun
With outen wepne saue his handes tweye
He slow and al to rente the leoun
Toward his weddyng walkyng bithe weye
His fals wif coude him so plese and preye
Til she his counseil knew and she vntrewe
Vnto his foos his counseil gan biwreye
And him forsook and took a nother newe
Thre hundred foxes took Sampson for Ire
And alle hir taylles he to geder bonde
And sette the foxes tailles alle on fyre
For he on euꝰery taille had knette a brond
And thei brend alle the cornes in that lond
And alle hir Olyueres and hir Vynes eke
A thousand men he slow with his hond
And hadde no wepne but an asses cheke
Whan thei were slayn so thursted him that he
Was welny lorn for which he gan to preye
That god wold of his peyne haue some pitee
And sende him drynke or elles most he dye
And of this asses cheke that was drye
Out of a wang tooth sprange anon a welle
Of which y nogh shortly to seye
Thus helpe him god as Iudicum kan telle
By verray force at Gazan on a nyght
Maugre philistiens of that Citee
The gates of the toun he hath vp plight
And on his bak I caried hem hath he
Hie on an hulle where as men myght hem se
O noble almyghti sampson lief and dere
Had thow nat told to wommen thi secree
In al this world ne hadde been thi peere
This sampson neuer Ciser drank ne wyn
Ne on his heed cam rasour noon ne shere
Bi precept of that Messager dyuyn
For alle hise streyngthes in his heres were
And fully xxtiri wynter yeer bi yeer
He hadde of ysrael the gouernaunce
But sone shal he wepen many a tere
For wommen shul him bryngen to meschaunce
Un to his lemman Dalida he tolde
That in his heris al his strength lay
And falsly vnto his foo men she him solde
And slepyng in hir barm vpon a day
She made to clippe or shere his heres away
And made his foomen al this craft espien
And whan that thei him fonde in this array
Thei bonde him fast and put out his eyen
But er his heer was clipped or y shaue
Ther was no bonde with which men myght him bynde
But now is he in pirisoun in a caue
Where as thei maden him atte querne grynde
O noble Sampson strengest of mankynde
O whilom Iuge in glorie and in richesse
Now maistow wepen with thyn eyen blynde
Sith thow fro wele art falle in wrecchednesse
The ende of this caitif was as I shal seye
His fomen made a fest vpon a day
And made him as a fool biforn hem pleye
This was in a temple of gret array
But atte last he made a foul fray
For he two pilours shook and made hem falle
And doun fil the temple and al and there it lay
And slow him self and eke his foomen alle
This is to seyn the pirinces euꝰerychon
And eke thre thousand bodyes were ther slayn
With fallyng of the gret temple of stoon
Of sampson now wol I na more seyn
Beth war bi this ensample olde and playn
That no man telle hir counseil to hir wyues
Of which thing as thei wolden han secre fayn
If that it touche hir lymes or hir lyues
Of hercules the souereyne conquerour
Syngen his werkes laude and high renoun
For in his tyme of strength he was the flour
He slow and rafte the skyn fro the leoun
He of Centauros leide the boost a doun
He arpies slow the cruelle briddes felle
He golden apples rafte of the dragoun
He drow out Cerberus / the hound of helle
He slow the cruel tyrant Busirus
And made his hors to frete him flessh and bon
He slow the firy serpent venymus
Of achilois two hornes he brak on
And he slow Cakus in a Caue of stoon
He slow the geant Antheous the stronge
He slow the grisly boor and that anon
And bare the heuene on his nekke bon
Was neuer wight sith that this world bigan
That slow so many monstres as did he
Thurgh oute the world wyde his name ran
What for his streynth and his hie bounte
And euꝰery Reame went he for to se
He was so stronge that no man myght him lette
At bothe the worldes endes seith trophe
In stede of boundes / he a piler sette
A lemman had this noble Champioun
That hight dyanra fressh as may
And as thise clerkes maken mencioun
She hath him sent a sherte fressh and gay
Allas this sherte allas and welaway
Enuenymed was so subtili with alle
That er that he had werid it half a day
It made his flessh al from his bones falle
But nathalees some clerkes hir excusen
By oon that hight nessus that it maked
Be as be may I wol hir noght accusen
But on his bak the shert he weried al naked
Til that his flessh was fro the venym blaked
And whan he say noon other remedye
In hote coles he hath him seluen raked
For with no venym deyngned him to dye
Thus starf this worthi myghti hercules
Lo who may truste on fortune any throwe
For him that foloweth al this world of prees
Er he be war is ofte pleyde ful lowe
Ful wise is he that kan him seluen knowe
Beth war / for whan that fortune list to glose
Thanne waiteth she / hir man to ouerthrowe
Bi swich a wey / as he wolde leest suppose
The mighti trone the pꝰercious tresour
The glorious ceptre of Royal mageste
That hadde the kynge Nabugodonosor
With tonge vnneth may discryued be
He twies whan Ierusalem the Citee
The vesselle of the temple he with him ladde
At babiloygne was his souereyne see
In which his glorie and his delit he hadde
The fairest children of the blood Royal
Of Israel he let do gelde anon
And maked eche of hem to ben his thral
Amonges other Danyel was oon
That was the wisest child of euꝰerychoon
For he the dremes of the kyng expouned
There as in Caldey / clerke ne was ther non
That wist to what fyne his dremes souned
Th proude kyng let make a statue of gold
Sixti cubites longe / and seuene in brede
To which ymage he bothe yonge and olde
Comaunded to lowte and haue in drede
Or in a forneys ful of flambes rede
He shal be brend / that wold noght obeye
But neuer wolde assente to that dede
Danyel ne his yonge felawes tweye
The kyng of kynges proud was and elat
He wende that god that sit in mageste
Ne myght him nat byreue of his estat
But sodeynly he lost his dignitee
And like a beest him semed for to bee
And eet hey as an Oxe and lay ther oute
In reyne with wilde beestes walked he
Til certeyn tyme was I come aboute
And like an Egles federes wax his heres
His nayles like a briddes clawes were
Til god relesed him a certeyn yeres
And yaf him wit and thanne with many a teere
He thanked god / and euer his lif in fere
Was he to doon amys / or more trespace
And til that tyme he leyde was on his beere
He knew that god / was ful of myght and garace
His sone which that hight baltasar
That heelde the reygne after his fader day
He bi his fader coude noght be war
For proude he was of herte and of array
And eke and ydolastre was he ay
His hie estat assured him in pride
But fortune cast him doun and there he lay
And sodeynly his reygne gan dyuyde
A feste he made vn to his lordes alle
Vpon a tyme and made hem blithe be
And thanne his officers gan he calle
Gooth bryngeth forth the vesselles quod he
Which that my fader in his ꝓprosperitee
Out of the temple of Ierusalem birafte
And to our hie goddes thanke we
Of honour that our eldres with vs lafte
His wif his lordes and his concubynes
Ay dronken while hir appetytes last
Out of thise noble vesselles sondry wynes
And on a wal this kyng hise eyen cast
And say an hand armelees that wroot ful fast
For feer of which he quok and syked soore
This hand that Baltasar so soore agast
Wroot Mane techel phares and na more
In al that lond Magicien was non
That koude expoune what that lettre mente
But Danyel expouned it anon
And seide kyng god to thi fader sent
Glorie and honour / regne / tresor / rent
And he was proude and nothing god ne dradde
And therfore god grete wreche vpon him sente
And him birefte the regne that he hadde
He was oute cast of mannes compaygnye
With asses was his habitacioun
And eet heye as a beest in weet and drye
Til that he knew bi grace and bi resoun
That god of heuene hath domynacioun
Ouer euery regne and euery creature
And than had god of him compassioun
And him restored his regne and his figure
Eke thow that art his son art proude also
And knowest thise thynges verrayly
And art rebel to god and art his fo
Thow dranke eke of his vessel boldely
Thi wif eke and thi wenches synfully
Dronke of the same vesselles sondry wynes
And heriest fals goddes cursedly
Therfore to the I shapen ful gret pyne is
This hand was sent fro god that on the wal
Wroot Mane techel phares truste me
Thi regne is doo thow weyest noght at al
Dyuyded is thi regne and it shal be
To Medes and to perses yeuen quod he
And thilke same nyght this kyng was slaw
And darius occupieth his degree
Thogh he ther to had neither right ne law
Lordynges ensample here bi me ye take
How that in lordship is no sykernesse
For whan fortune wol a man forsake
She bereth a wey his regne and his richesse
And eke his frendes bothe more and lesse
For what man that hath frendes thurgh fortune
Mishap wol make him enemys as I gesse
This prouerbe is ful sooth and ful comune
Cenobia of palymerye queene
As writen persiens of hir noblesse
So worthi was in armes and so kene
That no wight passed hir in hardynesse
Ne in lynage ne other gentilesse
Of kynges blood of Perce is she descended
But of hir shap she myght nat ben amended
From hire childehede I fynde that she fledde
Office of wommen and to wode she wente
And many a wilde hertes blood she shedde
With arwes brode that she to hem sente
She was so swift / that she anon hem hente
And whan that she was elder she wold kille
Leons leopardes and beres al to rente
And in hir armes welde hem at hir wille
She durst wild beestes dennes seke
And rennen in the Montayns alle the nyght
And slepen vnder the busshe and she koude eke
Wrastelen by verray force and verray myght
With any yong man were he neuer so wight
Ther myght no thing in hir armes stonde
She kepte hir maydenhed from euꝰery wight
To no man deygne hir for to be bonde
But atte last hir frendes han hir maryed
To onedake a prince of that contree
Al were it so that she him longe taryed
And ye shal vnderstanden how that he
Hadde swich fantasies as had she
But nathalees whan thei were knyt in fere
Thei lyued in Ioy and felicitee
For eche of hem hadde other leef and dere
Sauyng o thing she wolde neuer assente
By no wey that he sholde bi hir lye
But onys for it was hir pleyn entente
To haue a childe the world to multiplie
And also soone / as that she myght espie
That she was nat with child with that dede
Thanne wolde she suffren him doon his fantasye
Eft sone and noght but ones out of drede
And yif she were with child at thilke caste
No moore shulde he pleyen thilk game
Til fully fourty dayes weren past
Thanne wolde she ones suffre him do the same
Al were this Onedake wilde or tame
He gat no moore of hir for thus she seide
It was to wyues lecherye and shame
In other cas yif that men with hem pleide
Two sones bi this Onedake had she
The which she kepte in vertue and lettrure
But now vn to our tale turne we
I sey so worshipful a creature
And wis ther with / and large wtith mesure
So penyble in the werre and curteys eke
Ne moore labour myght in werre endure
Was non thogh al this world men shold seke
Hire riche array / ne myght nat to be told
As wel in vessel as in clothyng
She was al clad in perrey and in gold
And eke she lafte noght for non huntyng
To haue of Sondry tonges ful knowyng
Whan that she leiser hadde and for to entende
To lerne bookes was al hir lykyng
How she in vertue myght hir lyf despende
And shortly of this storie for to trete
So doghti was hir housbond and eke she
That thei conquered many regnes grete
In thorient with many a fayre Citee
Aꝑpertenant vnto the Magestee
Of Rome and with stronge hond helde hem ful faste
Ne neuer myght hir foomen doon hem flee
Ay whil that Onedakes dayes laste
Hire batailles who so list hem for to rede
Agayn Sapor the kyng and other mo
And how that al this processe fil in dede
Whi she conquered and what title ther to
And aftyr of hir meschief and hir wo
How that she was / biseged and I take
Lat hym vnto my master Petrak go
That write ynow of this I vndertake
Whanne Onedake was dede she myghtily
The regnes heelde and with hir propre hond
Agayns hir foos she faught so cruelly
That ther nas kyng ne prince in al that lond
That he nas glad yif he that grace foond
That she ne wolde vpon his lond werreye
With hir thei made alliance bi bond
To ben in pees and let hir ryde and pleye
The Emperour of Rome Claudius
Ne him biforn the Romayn Galyen
Ne dursten neuer been so corageous
Ne noon hermyn ne non egipcien
Ne surryen ne noon arrabyen
With ynne the felde that durste with hir fyghte
Lest that she wold hem with hir hondes sleen
Or with hir meynye putten hem to flighte
In kynges habit wenten hir sones two
As heyres / of hir fadres regnes alle
And hermanno and tymolao
Hir names were as Persiens hem calle
But ay fortune hath in hir hony galle
This myghti quene may no while endure
Fortune out of hir regne made hir falle
To wrecchednesse and to mysauenture
Aurelian whan that the gouꝰernance
Of Rome cam in to his handes tweye
He shoop him vpon this quene to doon vengeance
And with his legeons / he took his weye
Toward Senobe and shortly to seye
He made hir flee and atte last hir hente
And fetred hir and hir children tweye
And wan the land home to Rome he wente
Amonges other thinges that he wan
His chaar that was with gold wroght and perre
This gret Romayn this aurelyan
Hath with him ladde forthold it se
By fore his triumphe walketh she
With gilt cheynes on hir nekke hangynge
Crowned was she as aftyr hir degre
And ful of perre charged hir clothyng
Allas fortune she that whilom was
Dredful to kynges and to Emperoures
Now gaureth al the peple on hir allas
And she that helmed was in stark stoures
And wan bi force tounes stronge and toures
Shal on hir heed now were a vitremyte
And she that baar the Ceptre ful of floures
Shal bere a distaf hir cost for to quyte
Al thogh that nero were vicius
As any feend that lieth ful low a doun
Yet he as telleth vs swetonius
This wide world had in subieccioun
Both Est and West North and septemtrioun
Of Rubyes Saphires and of perles white
Were al his clothes bronden vp and doun
For he in gemmes greetly gan delite
Moore delicat moore pompous of array
Moore proude was neuer Emperour than he
That ilke cloth that he had wered o day
Aftyr that tyme he nolde it neuer see
Nettes of gold threed hadde greet plentee
To fysshen in Tybre whan him list pleye
Hise lustes were al law in his decree
For fortune as his frende him wolde obeye
He Rome brende for his delicacie
The Senatours he slow vpon a day
To here how that men wolde wepe and crie
And slow his brother and bi his sustere lay
His moder he made in pitous array
For he hir wombe slitte to bi holde
Where he conceyued was so weylawey
That he so litel of his moder tolde
No teer out of his n for that sighte
Ne cam but seide a f wommas was she
Greet wonder is how that he coude or myghte
Be domesman of hir deed beautee
The wyn to bryngen him comaunded he
And dranke anon / noon other wo he made
Whan myght is ioyned vnto cruelte
Allas to depe wol the venym wade
In youth a maister had this Emperour
To teche him lettrure and curtesye
For of moralite he was the flour
And in his tyme but yif bokes lie
And whil this maister had of him maistrye
He maked him so louynge and so souple
That longe tyme it was er tyrannye /
Or any vice dorst in him vncouple
This Seneca of which that I deuyse
By cause Nero hadde of him swich drede
For he fro vices wolde him ay chastise
Discretly as bi word and nat bi dede
Syre wolde he seyn an Emperour mote nede
Be vertuous and hate tyrannye
For which he in a bath made him to blede
On bothe his armes til he moste dye
This nero hadde eke of a Custumance
In youth ageynste his maister for to ryse
Which afterward him thought a gret greuance
Therfore he made him dyen in this wise
But nathalees this Seneca the wise
Chees in a bath to dye in this manere
Rather than han a nother tormentrise
And thus hath nero I slayn his maister dere
Now fil it so that fortune list no lenger
The hie pryde of nero to cherce
For thogh that he was strong yit was she strenger
She thoght thus bi god I am to nyce
To sette a man that is fulfild of vice
In high degree and Emperour him calle
By god out of his sete I wol him trice
Whan he leest weneth sonnest shal bifalle
The peple roos vpon him on a nyght
For his defaute and whan he it espied
Out of his dores anon he hath him dight
Allone and there he wende han ben allied
He knokked fast and ay the moore he cried
The faster shette thei the dores alle
For drede of this him thoght that he dyed
And wente his wey no lenger dorste he calle
The peple cryed and rombled vp and doun
That with hise erys herde he how thei seide
Where is this fals tyrant this Neroun
For fere almost out of his wit he breide
And to hise goddes pitously he preyde
For socour but it myght noght bityde
For drede of this him thoght that he deyde
And ran in to a gardeyn him to hide
And in this gardeyn foond he cherles tweye
That seten by a fyr greed and reed
And to thise cheerles two he gan to preye
To sleen him and to girden of his heed
That to his body whan that he were deed
Were no despite ydoon for his defame
Him self he slow he koude no better reed
Of which fortune lough and hadde a game
Was neuer Capitayn vnder a kyng
That regnes moore putte in subieccioun
Ne strenger was in feld of alle thing
As in his tyme ne gretter of renoun
Ne more pompous in high pꝰersumpcioun
Than Oloferne which fortune ay kiste
So likerously and ladde him vp and doun
Til that his heed was of er that he wist
Nat oonly that this world had him in lawe
For lesynge of Rychesse or of libertee
But made euꝰery man renyen his lawe
Nabugodonosor was god seide he
Noon other god sholde adoured be
Agayns his heest no wight dorste trespace
Saue in bethulia a stronge Citee
Where Eliachim a prest was of that place
But take keep of the deth of Oloferne
A mydde his hoost he dronke lay a nyght
Wyth Inne his tente large as is a berne
And yit for al his pompe and al his myght
Iudith a womman as he lay vp right
Slepyng his heed of smote and from his tente
Ful pryuely she stal from euꝰery wight
And with his heed vnto hir toun she wente
What nedeth it of kyng Antiochus
To telle his hie Royal Magestee
His hie pride his werkes venymus
For swich another / was ther noon as he
Rede which that he was in Machabee
And rede the proude wordes that he seide
And whi he fel fro hie prosperite
And in an hille how wrecchedly he died
Fortune him hadde enchaunted so in piride
That verrayly he wende he myght attayne
Vn to the sterres vpon euꝰery side
And in balance weyen ech montayne
And alle the floodes of the see restrayne
And goddes peple / hadde he moost in hate
Hem wold he sleen in torment and in payne
Wenyng that god ne myght his piride abate
And for that Nichanore and Tymothee
Of Iewes weren venquysshed myghtyly
Vnto the Iewes swich an hate had he
That he bad greithen hir chaar ful hastily
And swore and seide ful despitously
Vnto Ierusalem he wolde eft sone
To wreken his Ire / on it ful cruelly
But of his purpos he was let ful sone
God for his manace him so soore smoot
With inuisible woundes ay incurable
That in his guttes carf it so and boote
That hise peynes weren inportable
And certeynly the wreche was so resonable
For many a mannes guttes dede he peyne
But from his purpos cursed and dampnable
For al his smert he wold him nat restreyne
But bad anon apparaile his hoost
And sodeynly er he was of it war
God daunted al his piride and al his boost
For he so soore fil oute of his chaar
That it his lymes and his skynne totar
So that he neither myght go ne ride
But in a chaier men aboute him baar
Al for brosed bothe bak and side
The wreche of god him smoote so cruelly
That thurgh his body wikked wormes crepte
And ther with al he stank so horribily
That noon of al his meynye that him kepte
Whether so he wook or elles slepte
Ne myght not for stynke of him endure
In this meschief he wailed and eke he wepte
And knew god lord of euꝰery creature
To al his hoost and to him self also
Ful waltsom was the stynke of his careyne
No man ne myght him bere to and fro
And in this stynke and this horrible peyne
He starf ful wrecchedly in a montayne
Thus hath this Robbour and this homycide
That made many a man to wepe and pleyne
Swich gerdoun as bilongeth vn to piride
The story of Alisaundre is so comune
That euꝰery wight that hath discrescioun
Hath herd some what or al of his fortune
This wide worlde as in conclusioun
He wan by strength or for his hye renoun
Thei were glad for pees vn to him sende
The piride of man / and beest he leide a doun
Where so he cam vnto the worldes ende
Comparisoun myght neuer yit been maked
Bitwix him and a nother conquerour
For al this world for drede of him hath quaked
He of knyghthode and of fredom flour
Fortune him made the heire of hir honour
Saue wyn of wommen nothing myght aswage
His hie in entente in armes and labour
So was he ful of leonyn corage .
What pris were it to him thogh I yow tolde
Of darius and a hundred thousand mo
Of kynges pirinces Erles Dukes bold
Which he conquered and broght hem in to wo
I sey as fer / as man may ride or go
The world was his what shold I more deuyse
For thogh I write or told yow euer more
Of his knyghthode it myght nat suffise
Twelf yeer he regned as seith Machabee
Philippes sone of Macedoigne he was
That first was kyng in Grece the contree
O worthi gentil alisaundre allas
That euer sholde fallen swich caas
Empoysened of thin owne folk thow were
Thi sys fortune hath turned in to aas
And for the ne wepte she neuer a teere
Who shal me yeue teres to compleyne
The deth of gentilnesse / and of franchise
That al the world wold in his demeyne
And yit him thoght it myght nat suffise
So ful was his corage of hie empryse
Allas who shal me helpe to endyte
Fals fortune and poysoun to despise
The which two of al this woo I wite
By wisdom manhede and bi gret labour
Fro humble bed to Roial Magestee
Vp roos he Iulius the conquerour
That wan al thoccident bi land and see .
Bi strenth of hond or elles bi tretee
And vnto Rome made hem tributarye
And sith of Rome the Emperour was he
Til that fortune weex his aduersarie
O myghti Cesar that in Thessalye
Ageyn Pompeus fader thin in lawe
That of thorient hadde al chyualrye
As fer as that day bygynneth dawe
Thow thurgh thi knyghthode hast hem take and slawe
Saue few folk that with Pompeus fleedde
Thurgh which thow puttest al thorient in awe
Thank fortune that so wel the spedde
But now a litel while I wol be waille
This pompeus this noble gouernour
Of Rome which that fligh al this bataille
I sey oon of his men a fals traitour
His heed of smoot to wynnen him fauour
Of Iulius and him the heed he broght
Allas pompey of thorient conquerour
That fortune vnto swich a fyn the brought
To Rome agayn repaireth Iulius
With his triumphe lauriat ful hie
But on a tyme Brutus Cassius
That euer had of hie estat enuye
Ful piriuely hath maad conspiracie
Agayns this Iulius in subtil wise
And caste the place in which he shold dye
With boydekyns as I shal yow deuyse
This Iulius to the Capitolie wente
Vpon a day as he was wonte to goon
An in the Capitole anon him hente
This fals brutus and his other foon
And stiked him with boydekyns anou
With many a wounde and thus thei let him lie
But neuer grounte he at no stroke but oon
Or elles at two but yif his storie lye
So manly was this Iulius of herte
And so wel loued estately honestee
That though his deedly woundes soore smerte
His mantel ouer his hipes cast he
For no man sholde seen his piriuetee
And al he lay of dying in a traunce
And wist verrayly that deed was he
Of honeste yit hadde he rememberaunce
Lucan to the this storye I recommende
And to swetoun and to valerius also
That of this story wryten word and ende
How that thise Conquerours two
Fortune was first frende and sith a foo
No man truste vpon hir fauour longe
But haue hir in awaite for euer mo
Witnesse of al thise conquerours stronge
This riche Cresus whilom kyng of lide
Of which Cresus / Cirus soore him dradde
Yet was he caught amyddes al his piride
And to be brent men to the fyr him ladde
But swich a reyne doun fro the welkyn shadde
That slow the fyr and maad him to eschape
But to be war no grace yit he hadde
Til fortune on the galowes made him gape
Whan he escaped was he can nat stente
For to bigynne a new werre ageyn
He wende wel for that fortune him sente
Swich hap that he escaped thurgh the Reyne
That of his foos he myght no be slayn
And eke a sweuene vpon a nyght he mette
Of which he was so proude and eek so fayne
That in vengeance he al his herte sette
Upon atre he was and that him thought
Ther Iuppiter him wessh bothe bak and side
And phebus eek a fair towaille him broght
To drye him with and therfore wex his pride
And to his doughter that stood him biside
Which that he knew in high sentence habounde
He bad hir telle him what it signyfiede
And she his dreme by gan right thus expounde
The tre quod she the galowes is to mene
And Iuppiter bitokeneth snow and Reyn
And Phebus with his towailes so clene
Tho ben the sonne beemes for to seyn
Thow shalt an hanged be fader certeyn
Reyne shal the wasshe and sonne shal the drie
Thus warned him ful plat and ful pleyn
His doughter which that called was phanye
Anhanged was Cresus the proude kyng
His Roial trone myght him nat availle
Tragedies / noon other maner thing
Ne can in syngyng crie ne bewaille
But that fortune alway wol assayle
With vnwar strook the Regnes that ben proude
For whan man trusteth hir thanne wol she faille
And couere hir bright face with a cloude
O noble .o. worthi Petro glorie of spaigne
Wham fortune heeld so hie in magestee
Wel oghten men thi pitous deth compleyne
Out of thi land thi brother made the flee
And after at sege bi subtilite
Thow were bitraised and lad vnto his tente
Where as he with his owne hond slow the
Succedyng in thi Reyne and in thi Rente
The feeld of snow with thegle of blak ther ynne
Caught with the lymerod coloured as the glede
He brew this cursednesse and al this synne
The wikked nest was werker of this nede
Noght Charles Olyuere that took ay hede
Of trouth and honour / but of Armorike
Geniloun Olyuer corrupt for mede
Brought this worthi kyng in swich a brike
O worthi petro kyng of Cipre also
That Alisandre wan bi hie maistrie
Ful many a hethen wroghtestow ful wo
Of which thin owne liege had enuye
And for no thing but for thi Chyualrye
Thei in thi bed han slayn the bi the morwe
Thus kan fortune hir wheel gouꝰerne and gye
And oute of Ioy brynge men to sorwe
Of Melan grete barnabo viscounte
God of delit and stronge of lumbardye
Whi sholde I nat thin Infortune acounte
Sith in estate thow clombe were so hie
Thi brother sone that was thi double allie
For he thi nevew / was and sone in lawe
Wit Inne his pirisoun made the die
But whi ne how / noot I that thow were slawe
Of the Erle hugelyn of pize the langour
Ther may no tonge telle for pitee
But litel out of pise stant a tour
In which tour in prisoun put was he
And with him been hise litel children thre
The oldest Scarsly fyue yeer was of age
Allas fortune it was grete crueltee
Swich briddes for to putte in swich a Cage
Dampned was he to dyen in that prisoun
For Rogger which that bisshop was of pize
Hadde on him made a fals suggestioun
Thurgh which the peple gan vpon him rise
And putten him to prisoun in swich wise
As ye han herd and mete and drynke he hadde
So smal that vnneth it may suffise
And ther with al it was ful pore and badde
And on a day bifil that in that hour
Whan that his mete was wont to be brought
The galler shette the dores of the tour
He herd it wel / but he spak right noght
And in his hert anon ther fil a thought
That thei for hunger wold doon him dyen
Allas quod he allas that I was wroght
Ther with the teres fillen from his eyen
Hise yonge sone that thre yeer was of age
Vnto him seyde fader / fader whi do ye wepe
Whanne wole the geailer bryngen our potage
Is ther no morsel brede that ye do kepe
I am so hungry that I may nat slepe
Now wolde god that I myght slepen euer
Thanne sholde noght hunger in my wombe crepe
Ther nys no thing but breed that me were leuer
Thus day bi day this childe bigan to crie
Til in his fadres barm adoun it lay
And seide fare wel fader I moote dye
And kist his fadre and dide the same day
And whan the woful fader deed it say
For wo hise armes two he gan to bite
And seide allas fortune and weylawaye
Thi fals whele my wo al may I wite
Hise children wende that it for hunger was
That he hise armes gnow and nat for wo
And seiden fader do nat so allas
But rather ete the flessh vpon vs two
Oure flessh thow yaf taak our flessh vs fro
And ete ynogh right thus thei to him seide
And after that wyth Inne a day or two
Thei leiden hem in his lappe adoun and deyde .
Him self despired eek for hunger starf
Thus ended is this myghti Erl of Pise .
From hie estate fortune a wey him carf
Of this tragedie it ought ynogh suffise
Who so wole here it in a lenger wise
Redeth the gret poete of ytaille
That hight Dant / for he kan alle deuyse
Fro point to point nat .o. word wol he faille
Here endeth the Monkes tale

l.hi: Here bigynneth the prologe of the tale of the nonnes prest

div.l: Hoo quod this knyght good syr no moore of this
That ye han seide is right ynogh I wis
And mochel moore for to telle heuynesse
Is right ynogh for mochel folk I gesse
I sey for me it is a gret desese
Where as men han been in gret welth and ese
To heren of hir sodeyn falle allas
And the contrarie is Ioy and gret Solas
And whan a man hath been in pore estate
And clymbeth vp and wexeth fortunate
And there abideth in prosperite
Swich thing is gladsom as thinketh me
And of swich thing were goodly for to telle
Ye quod our hoost bi seint poules belle
Ye sey right soth this Monke hath clapped loude
He spak how fortune couered was with cloude
I noot neuer what / and als of tregedye
Ryght as ye herd and pardee no remedye
It is for to waille or for to complayne
That is doon and also it is a payne
As ye han saide to here heuynesse
Syr monke no more of this so god yow blesse
Your tale anoyeth al this companye
Swich talkyng is nat worth a boterflye
For ther Inne is no desport ne game
Wherfore syr Monke Daun pierce bi your name
I preye yow hertily telle vs somwhat elles
For sykerly nere clynkyng of your belles
That on your bridel honge on euꝰery side
Bi heuene kyng that for vs alle dide
I shulde or this haue fallen doun for slepe
Al thogh the slough had neuer been so depe
Thanne hadde your tale betolde in veyn
For certeynly as thise clerkes seyn
Where as a man may haue non audience
Noght helpeth him to tellen his sentence
And wel I wote the substance is in me
Yif any thing shal wel reported be
Syre sey som what of huntyng I yow pray
Nay quod the monke I haue no luste to playe
Now lat another telle as I haue tolde
Than spak our hoost with rude speche and bolde
And seide vnto the Nonnes pꝰerst anon
Come nere thow preest come nere thow syr Iohn
Telle vs swich thing as may our hertes glade
Be blithe thogh thow ride vpon a iade
What thogh thin hors be bothe foul and lene
Yif he wool serue the recche noght a beene
Look that thin hert be mery euer mo
Yis sir quod he / yis hoost so mote I go
But I be mery y wis I wol be blamed
And right anon his tale he hath I tamed
And thus he seide vnto vs euꝰerychon
This swete preest this goodly man syr Iohn

l.hi: Here endeth the prologe of the tale of the nonnest prest
Here bigynneth the tale of the nonnes prest

div.l: A pore widow somdel stepe in age
Was whilom dwellyng in a narow cotage
Biside a groue stondyng in a dale
This widow of which I telle yow my tale
Sithen thilke day that she wast last a wif
In pacience lad a ful symple lif
For litel was hir catel and hir rente
Bi housbandrye of which as god hir sente
She foonde hir self and eek hir doughtren two
Thre laarge sowes had she and no mo
Thre kyn and ek a sheep that hight malle
Ful soty was hir boure and eke hir halle
In which she ete many a sclender mele
Of poynant sauce hir neded neuer a dele
No deynte mossel passed thurgh hir throte
Hir diete was accordant to hir cote
Replexions ne made hir sike
Attempre diete was al hir phisik
And excercise and hertus suffisaunce
The goute let hir no thing for to daunce
Napeplexi shent nat hir heed
Ne wyn ne drank neuer white ne reed
Hir borde serued bothe with white and blak
Milk and broun bred in which she foond no lak
Seynd bacon and som tyme an eye or tweye
For she was as it were a maner deye
¶ A yeerd she hadde was closed al aboute
With stikkes and with drye dyche with oute
In which she had a Cok hight Chauntecleer
In al the lond of crowyng ne was his peer
His vois was murier than the mury orgon
On massedayes that in the Chirche goon
Wel sikerer was his crowyng in his logge
Than is a clok or an abbey orlogge
Bi nature he knew eche ascencioun
Of equynoxial in thilke toun
For whan degrees xv were ascended
Thanne krewe he that it myght nat been amended
His combe was redder than the fyn coral
And batailled as it were a Castel wal
His bil was blak and as the geet it shoon
Lik asure were his legges and his toon
His nayles whitter than the lilye flour
And like to the bornysshed gold was his colour
This gentil cok had in his gouernaunce
Seuen hennes for to do al his plesaunce
Which were his sustres and eke his paramours
And wonder lik to him as of colours
Of which the fairest hewed on hire throte
Was cleped fair damysel Partilote
Curteys she was discreet and debonayre
And compaynable and bar hir self so fayre
Syn thilke day that she was seuen nyght olde
That trewly she hath the hert in holde
Of chauntecleer loken in euery lith
He loued hir so that wel was him ther with
But swich a Ioy was it to here hem synge
Whan that the bright sonne gan for to springe
In swete acord my leef is faren in londe
For thilke tyme as I haue vnderstande
Beestes and briddes koude speke and synge
¶ And so bifel that in a dawenynge
As Chauntecleer among his wyue alle
Sat on his perche that was in the halle
And next him sat this faire partilote
This Chauntecleer gan gronen in his throte
As man that in his dreme is drecched soore
¶ And whan that partilote thus herd him rore
She was agast and seyde herte dere
What eyleth yow to grone in this manere
Ye been a verray sleper fy for shame
¶ And he answerd and seide thus madame
I prey yow that ye take it noght agreue
Bi god me met I was in swich meschieue
Ryght now that yit myn hert is soore a fryght
Now god quod he my sweuen recche aright
And kepe my body out of foule pirisoun
Me mette how that I romed vp and doun
With Inne our yeerde wher as I say best
Was like an hound and wolde han maad a reest
Vpon my body and wolde han had me deed
His Colour was bitwix yelow and reed
And tipped was his tayle and both his erys
With blak vnlik the remenant of his heris
His snowte was smal with glowyng eyen tweye
Yit for his look for feer almost I deye
This caused me my gronnyng doutelees
¶ A way qd she fi on yow herteles
Allas quod she for bi that god aboue
Now haue ye loost myn hert and eek my loue
I kan nat loue a coward bi my feith
For certes what so eny womman seith
We alle desiren yif it myght be
To han husbondes hardy wise and fre
And /secree and no nygard ne no fool
Ne him that is agast of euꝰery tool
Ne noon auaunter bi that god aboue
How dorst ye seyn for shame vnto your loue
That eny thing myght make yow a ferde
Haue ye no mannes herte and han a berde
¶ Allas and konne ye been agast of sweuenes
No thing god woot but vanyte in sweues es
Sweuenes engendren of recomplexions
And often of fume and of compleccions
Whan humours ben to habundant in a wight
Certes this dreme which that ye han mette to nyght
Comth of the grete suꝑperfluytee
Of your reed colour pardee
Which causeth folk to dreden in hir dremes
Of arwes and of fire with reed lymes
Of reed bestes that thei wil hem bite
Of contek and of whelpes grete and lite
Ryght as the humor of malencolye
Causeth ful many a man in his sleep to crie
For feere of grete beres and boles blake
Or elles blake deueles wol hem take
¶ Of other humours coude I telle also
That werken many a man in slepe ful wo
But I wol passe as lightly as I can
¶ To Catoun which that was so wise a man
Seide nat thus / ne do no force of dremes
Now syr quod she whan we fle fro the bemes
For goddes loue as take som laxatif
Vp peril of my Soule and my lif .
I counseil yow the best I wol nat lye
That bothe of colour and of Malencolye
Ye purge yow and for ye shal nat tarye
Thogh in this toun is noon apotecarye
I shal my self / to herbes techen yowe
That shullen be for your heele and for your prowe
And in our yeerde the yerbes shal I fynde
The which han of hir ꝓpropretee bi kynde
To purgen yow be nethe and eek aboue
For yet nat this for goddes owne loue
Ye ben ful colerik of complexioun
Ware the sonne in his ascencioun
Ne fynde yow not repleet of humours hote
For if it do I dar wel ley a grote
That ye shal han a feuer terciane
Or an ague that may be your bane
A day or two ye shal haue degestyues
Of wormes er ye take your laxatyues
Of laurial Centaure and fumetere
Or elles of Ellebor that groweth there
Of katapuce or of gait rys berijs
Of herbe yue growyng in our yerde there myry is
Pekke hem vp right as thei growe and ete hem ynne
Be myry husbond for your fader kynne
Dredeth no dreme I can sey yow na more
¶ Madame quod he graunt mercy of your loore
But nathales as touching Daun Catoun
That hath of wisdom swich a gret renoun
Thogh that he bad no dremes for to drede
Bi god men may in olde bokes rede
Of many a man moore of auctorite
Than euer Catoun was so mote I the
That al the reuers seyn of his sentence
And han wel founden bi experience
That dremes ben significacions
As wel of Ioye as tribulacions
That folk enduren in this lif pꝰersent
Ther nedeth make of this non argument
The verrey preef sheweth it in dede
¶ Oon of the grettest auctor that men rede
Seith thus that whilom two felawes wente
On pilgrymage with a ful good entente
And happed so thei comen in a toun
Where as ther was swich congregacioun
Of peple and eke so streite of herbergage
That thei ne founde as moche as a cotage
In which thei bothe myght I logged be
Wherfore the mosten of necessitee
As for that nyght departen companye
And eche of hem goth to his Ostelrye
And took his loggynge as it wolde falle
That on of hem was logged in a stalle
Fer in a yerd with oxen of the plow
That other man was logged wel ynow
As was his auenture or his fortune
That vs gouerneth alle as in comune
¶ And so bifel that longe er it were day
This man mette in his bed ther as he lay
How that his felaw gan vpon him calle
And seide allas for in an oxe stalle
This nyght I shal be mordred there I lye
Now helpe me dere brother or I dye
In al hast come to me he saide
¶ This man out of his slepe for fere abrayde
But whan that he was wakened of his sleep
He turned him and took of this no keep
Him thoght his dreme nas but a vanyte
Thus twies in his slepyng dremed he
And atte thrid yit his felawe
Cam as him thoght and seide I am now slawe
Byholde my blody woundes depe and wide
Aris vp erly in the morwe tyde
And at the westgate of the toun quod he
A Cart ful of dong ther shaltow se
In which my body is hidde ful pryuely
Do thilke carte arest boldely
My golde caused my mordre sooth to seyn
And tolde him euꝰery poynt how he was slayn
With a ful pitous face pale of hewe
And truste wel his dreme he founde ful trew
For on the morwe as sone as it was day
To his felawes In he took the way
And whan that he cam to this Oxen stalle
After his felaw he bigan to calle
¶ The Ostiler answerd him anon
And seide syr your felaw is agoon
As sone as day he went out of the toun
¶ This man gan fallen in suspescioun
Remembrynge on his dremes that he mette
And forth he gooth no lenger wolde he lette
Vnto the Westgate of the toun and fonde
A donge cart wente as it were to donge londe
That was arrayed in that same wise
As ye han herde the dede man deuyse
And with an hardy herte he gan to crie
Vengeance and Iustise of this felonye
Mi felaw mordred is this same nyght
And in this carte here he lieth gapyng vpright
I crie out on the mynystres quod he
That shulden kepe and rulen this Citee
Harrow allas here lieth my felaw slayn
What shold I moore vnto this tale sayn
The peple out sterte and caste the cart to grounde
And in the middel of the donge thei founde
The deedman that mordred was al newe
¶ O blesful god that art so Iuste and trewe
Lo how that thow biwriest mordre alway
Mordre wol oute that se we day bi day
Mordre is so waltsome and abhominable
That god that is so Iuste and resonable
That he ne wol nat suffre it heled be
Thogh it abide a yeer or two or thre
Mordre wol out this my conclusioun
And right anon mynystres of that toun
Han hente the Carter and so soore him pyned
And eek the hostiler so soore engyned
That thei beknew hir wykkednesse anon
And were an hanged by the nekke bon
¶ Here may men se that dremes ben to drede
And certes in the same book I reede
Right in the next Chapitre after this
I gab nat so haue I ioy or blisse
¶ Two men that wolden han passed ouer see
For certeyn causes in to a fer contree
If that the wynde ne hadde ben contrarye
That made hem in a Citee for to tarye
That stood ful myry vpon an hauenes syde
But on a day agay the euen tyde
The wynde gan change and blow right as hem leste
Iolif and glad thei wenten vnto reste
And casten hem ful erly for to Saille
¶ But herkeneth to that o man fil a gret maruaylle
That oon of hem in slepyng as he lay
Hym mette a wonder dreem ageyn the day
Hym thoght a man stood bi his beddes side
And him commaunded that he shulde abide
And seide him thus yif thow to morwe wende
Thow shalt be dreynt my tale is at and ende
¶ He wook and tolde his felaw what he mette
And preide him his viage for to lette
As for that day he preide him to abide
¶ His felaw that lay bi his beddes syde
Gan for to laugh and scorned him ful fast
No dreme quod he may so myn herte agast
That I wol let for to do my thinges
I sette nat a straw bi thi dremynges
For sweuenes been but vanytees and Iapes
Men dreme al day of owles or of Apes
And of many a maze therwith al
Men dreme of thing that neuer was ne shal
But sith I see that thow wolt here abide
And thus forslewthen wilfully thi tyde
God woot it ruweth me and haue good day
And thus he took his leue and went his way
But er that he hadde half cours y seiled
Not I nat whi ne what meschaunce it eiled
But casuelly the shippes botme rente
And ship and man vnder the water wente
In sight of othir shippes hit biside
That with hem seileden at the same tyde
And therfore faire partilote so dere
By ensamples olde maistow leere
That no man sholde been to reccheles
Of dremes for I sey the doutelees
That many a dreme ful soore is for to drede
¶ Loo in the lif of seint kenelm I rede
That was kenelphus sone the noble kyng
Of Mertenrike how kenelm mette a thing
A lite er he was mordred on a day
His mordre in his auysioun he say
His norice him expouned euꝰerydel
His sweuen and bad him for to kepe him wel
For traisoun but he nas but . vij . yeer olde
And therfore litel tale hath he tolde
Of any dreem so hooly was his herte
By god I hadde leuer than my sherte
That ye had red his legend as haue I
Dame partilote I sey yow trewly
Macrobeus that writ the auysioun
In affrik of the worthi Cipioun
Affermeth dremes and seith that thei ben
Warnyng of thinges that men after seen
¶ And forthermore I prey yow loketh wel
In the olde testament of Danyel
If he heelde dremes eny vanytee
¶ Rede eke of Ioseph and there shul ye se
Whether dremes be some tyme I sey nat alle
Warnyng of thinges that shul after falle
Look of Egipte the kyng daun phardio
His baker and his boteler also
Wher thei felt non effect in dremes
Who so wol seke actes of sondry remes
May rede of dremes many a wonder thing
¶ Of cresus which that was of lyde kynge
Mette he nat that he sat vpon a tre
Which signified he shulde an hanged be
¶ Loo heer Andromacha Ectores wif
That day that Ector shulde lese his lif
She dremed on the same nyght biforn
How that the lif of Ector shulde be lorn
If thilke day he wente in to bataille
She warned him but it myght not auaile
He went for to fight nathalees
But he was anon slayn of Achilles
But thilke tale is al to longe to telle
And eek it is ny day I may nat dwelle
Shortly I sey as for conclusioun
That I shal han of this auysioun
Aduersitee and I sey forthermore
That I ne telle of laxatifes no store
For thei ben venymes I woot it wel
I hem deffye I loue hem neuer a del
¶ Now let vs speke of myrthe and stynte al this
Madame partilote so haue I blis
Of o thing god hath sent me large grace
For whan I se the beaute of your face
Ye ben so scarlet reed aboute your eyen
It maketh al my drede for to dyen
For also siker as is In principio
¶ Mulier est hominis confusio
¶ Madame the Sentence of this Latyn is
Womman is mannes ioy and al his blis
For whan I fele a nyght your softe syde
Al be it that I may nat on yow ride
For that our perche is made so narwe allas
I am so ful of ioye and of solas
That I deffye bothe sweuene and dreme
And with that word he flie doun fro the beeme
For it was day and eke his hennes alle
And with a chuk he gan hem for to calle
For he had found a corn lay in the yerde
Royal he was / he was neuer aferde
He fethered partilote twenty tyme
And trade as ofte er it was pryme
He loketh as it were a grym leoun
And on his toos he rometh vp and doun
Hym deyned not to sette his foot to grounde
He chukketh whan he hath a corn yfounde
And to him rennen anon his wyues alle
Thus Royal as a prince is in his halle
Leeue I this Chauntecleer in his pasture
And after wol I telle his auenture
¶ Whan that the monthe in which the world bigan
That hight Marche whan god first maked man
Was completed and passed were also
Syn Marche bigan . xxxtiri . dayes and two
Bifel that Chauntecleer in al his pride
His seuene wyues walkyng bi his side
Caste vp his eyen to the bryght sonne
That in the signe of Taurus had I ronne
Twenty degrees and oon and somwhat more
And knew bi kynde and bi noon other loore
That it was pryme and krew with blisful steuene
The sonne he seide is clomben vp on heuene
Fourty degrees and oon and more I wis
Madame partilote my worldes blis
Herkeneth thise blesfull briddes how thei singe
And se how the fressh floures how thei springe
Ful is myn herte of ioy and of Solas
But sodeynly him fel a sorowful cas
For euer the latter ende of ioy is wo
God woot that wordly ioy is sone ago
And yif a Rethor koude faire endite
He in a cronycle saufly myght it write
As for a souereyne notabilitee
Now euꝰery wyseman lat him herkene me
This stori is also trewe I vndertake
As is the book of launcelote de lake
That wommen holde in ful greete reuerence
Now wol I torne agayn to myn sentence
¶ A Colfox ful of slye Iniquytee
That in the groue had woned yeres three
By Imagynaciouns forncast
The same nyght thurgh out the hegges braste
In to the yerd there Chauntclere the faire
Was wont and eek is hennes to repaire
And in to a bed of wortes stille he lay
Til it was passed vndren of the day
Waytyng his tyme on chauntecleer to falle
As gladdely doon thise homicides alle
That in a wayt liggen to mordre men
O fals morder lurkynge in the den
O new scoriot new genyloun
Fals dissimilour o greek synoun
That broghtest Troye al outrely to sorowe
O chauntecleer . o cursed be that morwe
That thow in to that yeerd flaugh fro the bemes
Thow were ful wel ywarned bi thi dremes
That thilk day was ꝑperilous to the
But what that god fore woot mot nedes be
Aftyr thopynyoun of certeyn clerkes
Witnesse on him that any parfyt clerk is
That in scole is grete altercacioun
In this matere and grete dispitisoun
And hath ben of an hundred Mll . men
But I ne kan nat bulte it to the bren
As can the holy doctour Augustyn
Or boece or the bisshop Bradwardyn
Whether that goddes worthi fo wityng
Streyneth me nedely for to do a thing
Nedely clepe I simple necessite
Or elles if free chois be graunted to me
To do that same thing or to do it noght
Thogh god forwoot it er that I was wroght
Or his wytyng streyneth me neuer adel
But hie necessite condicionel
I wol nat han to do of swich matere
My tale is of a Cok as ye may here
That took his conseil of his wif with sorwe
To walken in the yerde vpon the morwe
That he had mette the dreme that I yow tolde
Wommens counsels ben ful ofte colde
Wommans conseil broght vs first to wo
And made Adam fro paradys to go
Ther as he was ful myry and wel at ese
But for I noot to whom I myght displese
If I counseil of wommen blame
Passe ouer for I seide it in my game
Rede auctours where as thei trete of swich matere
And what thei sey of wommen there may ye here
Thise ben the Cockes wordes and nat myne
I kan noon harm of noo womman dyuyne
¶ Faire in the sand to bathe hire myrily
Lith partilote and al hir sustres by
Ageyn the sonne and chauntecleer so free
Sang merier than the mermeyde in the see
For phisiologus seith sykerly
How that thei syngen wel and myrily
¶ And so bifil that as he cast his eye
A mong the wortes on a boterflye
He was waar of this fox that lay ful lowe
No thing ne list him thanne for to crowe
But cried anon Cok Cok and vp he sterte
As man that was affrayde in his herte
For naturelly a beest desireth flee
Fro his contrarye if he it may see
Thogh he neuer erst hadde sey it with his eye
¶ This Chauntecleer whan he gan him espie
He wolde han fledde but that the fox anon
Seide gentil syr allas where wol ye goon
Be ye affrayed of me that am your frende
Now certes I were wors than a fende
Yif I to yow wold harm or vilenye
I am nat come your conseil for tespie
But truly the cause of my comynge
Was oonly for to herkne how ye singe
For trewly ye han as mery a steuene
As any Aungel hath that is in heuene
Therwith ye han musik more felyng
Than had boece or any that kan synge
Mi lord your fader god his soule blesse
And eek your moder of hir gentilesse
Han in myn hous y ben to my grete ese
And certes sir ful fayn wold I yow plese
¶ But for men speke of syngynge I wol seye
So mote I brouke wel myn eyen tweye
Saue ye I herd neuer man so singe
As did your fader in the mornynge
Certes it was of herte al that he song
And for to make his vois the more strong
He wold so peyne him that with bothe his eyen
He moste wynke so loude wolde he crien
And stonden on his tippetoon ther with al
And strecche forth his nekke longe and smal
And eek he was of swich discrescioun
That ther nas no man in no regioun
That him in Song or wisdom myght passe
I haue wel redde in daun burnel the asse
Among his vers how that ther was a Cokke
For a prestes sone yaf him a knokke
Vpon his leg while he was yonge and nyce
He made him for to lese his benyfice
But certeyn ther nys noon comparisoun
Bitwix the wisdom and discrescioun
Of your fadyr ne of his subtilitee
Now synge syr for seint charitee
Lat se konne ye your fader contrefete
¶ This Chauntecleer hys wynges gan bete
As a man that koude his traisoun nat espie
So was he rauesshed with his flaterye
¶ Allas ye lordes many a fals flatour
Is in your court and many a losengeour
That plesen yow more bi my feith
Than he that sothfastnesse vnto yow seith
Redeth Ecclesiastre of flaterye
Beth war ye lordes of hir treccherie
¶ This chauntecleer stood hie vpon his toos
Strecchyng his nekke and heelde his eyen cloos
And gan to crowe loude for the nones
And daun Russell the fox sturt vp at ones
And bi the gargat hent Chauntcleer
And on his bak toward the wood him beer
For yit ne was ther no man that him sewed
¶ O deestnee that maiste nat been eschued
Allas that Chauntecleer flye fro the beemes
Allas his wif ne roght nat of dremes
And on a friday fil al this meschaunce
¶ O . Venus that art goddesse and plesaunce
Syn that thi seruant was this chauntecleer
And in thi seruise did al his powere
Moore for delit than woold to multeplie
Whi woldestow suffre him on thi day to dye
¶ O . gaufred dere maister souerayn
That whan thi worthi Richard was slayn
With shoot compleyndest his deth so soore
Whi ne hadde I now thi sentence and thi lore
The Friday for to chide as diden ye
For on a friday soothly slayn was he
Thanne wolde I shew how that I coude compleyne
For Chauntecleers drede and for his peyne
¶ Certes swich crie ne lamentacioun
Was neuer of ladies maad whan Ilioun
Was come and pirrus with his streite swerd
Whan he had hent kyng priam bi the berd
And slayn him as seith vs enoydos
As made alle the hennes in the cloos
Whan thei had seyn of Chauntcleer the sight
But souereynly dam partilote shright
Ful louder than dide hasdrubales wif
Whan that hir husbond hadde lost his lif
And that the Romaynes had brent Cartage
So ful he was of pite and of Rage
That wilfully in to the fyr she sterte
And brende hir self with a stedefast herte
¶ O woful hennes right so criden ye
As whan that nero brende the Citee
Of Rome criden the Senatours wyues
For that hir husbondes losten alle hir lyues
With outen gilt this Nero hath hem slayn
Now wol I turne to my tale agayn
¶ The sely widow and hir doughtres two
Herden thise hennes crie and maken wo
And out atte dores sterten thei anon
And seen the fox in to the groue goon
And baar vpon his bakke the Cok away
And cride out harrow and weilawey
Ha ha the fox and after him thei ran
And eek with staues many a nother man
Ran Colle our dogge and talbot and garlond
And Malkyn with a distaf in hir hond
Ran Cow and calf and eek the verrey hogges
So fered for berkyng of the dogges
And shoutyng of the men and wommen eek
Thei ronne so hem thoght hir herte breek
Thei yeleden as feendes doon in helle
The dokes /criden as men wolde hem quelle
The gees for feere flowen ouer the trees
Out of the hyue cam the swarm of bees
So hidous was the noise a benedicitee
Certes he Iakke Strawe and his meyne
Ne made neuer shoutes half so shrille
Whan that thei wolde any flemmyng kille
As thilke day was maad vpon the fox
Of bras thei broghten bemes and of box
Of horn of bon in which thei blew and pouped
And therwith al thei criden and thei houped
It semed as that heuene shulde falle
Now good men I prey yow herkeneth alle
Loo how fortune turneth sodeynly
The hope and pride eek of hir enmy
This Cok that lay vpon the foxes bak
In al his drede vn to the fox he spak
And seyde syr yif that I were as ye
Yit wolde I seyn as wis god helpe me
Turneth ageyn ye proude cherles alle
A verry pestilence vpon yow falle
Now am I come vnto the wodes side
Maugre your heed the Cok shal here abide
I wol him ete in feith and that anon
¶ The fox answerde in feith it shal be don
And as he spak that word al sodeynly
This Cok bak from his mouth delyuerly
And hie vpon a tre he flie anon
And whan the fox say that he was gon
¶ Allas quod he . o . Chauntecleer allas
I haue to yow quod he y doon trespas
In as muche as I maked yow aferd
Whan I yow hente and brought in to this yerd
But syr I did it in no wikke entente
Come doun and I shal telle yow what I mente
I shal sey soth to yow god helpe me so
¶ Nay thanne quod he I shrewe vs bothe two
And first I shrew my self bothe blood and boones
Yif thow bigile me any ofter than ones
Thow shalt no more with thi flaterye
Do me to singe and wynke with myn eye
For he that wynketh whan that he sholde see
Al wilfully god lat him neuer the
¶ Nay quod the fox god yeue him meschaunce
That is so vndescreet of gouernaunce
That Iangleth whan he sholde holde his pees
Loo swich it is for to be recchelees
And neccligent and truste on flaterye
¶ But ye that halden this tale a folye
As of a fox or of a Cok or hen
Taketh the moralitee good men
For seint Poule seith / that al that writen is
To our doctryne is I write I wis
Taketh the fruyt and lat the chaf be stille
Now good god if that it be thi wille
As seith my lord so make vs alle good men
And brynge vs to his hie blis Amen.
¶ Here endeth the nonnes prestes tale

Here bigynneth the prologe of the cookes tale
Tthe Cook of loundoun while the Reue spak
For ioye him thoght he clawed him on the bak
A ha quod he for cristes passioun
This Miller hadde a sharpe conclusioun
Vpon his argumentz of herbergage
Wel seide salamon in his langage
Ne brynge nat euꝰery man in to thin hous
For herberwyng bi nyght is perilous
Wel aught a man auysed for to be
Whom that he brought in to his piriuete
I praye to god so yeue me sorowe and care
If euer sith I hight hogge of ware
Herd I a meller better I set of a Clerk
He hadde a Iape of malice in the derk
But god forbede that I stynte here
And therfore yif ye vouche saf to here
A tale of me that am a pore man
I wil telle as wel as euer I can
A litel Iape that fil in our Citee
¶ Our hoost answerd and seide I graunt it the
Now telle on Rogger loke that it be good
For many a paste hastow late blood
That hath ben twies hoot and twies coold
And many a Iak of douer hastow soold
Of many a pilgryme hastow cristes curs
For of thi parsle yit thei fare the wors
That thei han eten in thi stubbul gos
For in thi shoppe is many a flie loos
Now telle on gentil Rogger bi thi name
But I praye yit the be nat wroth for game
A man may sey ful sooth in game and pleye
Thow seist ful soth quod Rogger bi my feye
Buth sooth pleye quade pleye as the flemmyng seith
And ther fore henry bailly bi thi feith
Be thou noght wroth er we departe here
Thogh that my tale be of an hostelere
But nathales I wil nat tellen it yit
But er we parte I wis thow shalt be quyt
And ther with al he lough and maked chere
And seide his tale as ye shal after here .
Here endeth the prologe .
Here bigynneth the Cookes tale .
A Prentis whilom dwelled in our Citee
And of a crafte of vitailles was he
Gaillard he was as goldefynche in the shawe
Broun as a bery a propre shorte felawe
With lokkes blake I kembid ful fetisly
Dauncen he koude so wel and Iolily
That he was cleped perkyn reuelour
He was as ful of loue and paramour
As is the hyue ful of hony swete
Wel was the wenche with him myght mete
At euꝰery bridale wolde he synge and hoppe
He loued bet the tauerne than the shoppe
For whan ther was any ridyng in the Chepe
Out of the shoppe thider wolde he lepe
Til that he hadde al the sight I seyn
And daunced wel and nold nat come agayn
And gadred him a meynye of his soort
To hoppe and synge and make such desport
And there thei setten steuene for to mete
To pley at dys in such a strete
For in the toun nas ther no prentys
That fairer koude cast apaire of dys
Than perkyn koude and ther to he was fre
Of his despence in place of piriuyte
That his Maister wel in his chaffare
Ful ofte tyme he fonde his box ful bare
For sothly a prentys a reuelour
That haunteth dys ryot and paramour
His maistyr shal in his shoppe abye
Al haue he no part of the menstralcye .
For thefte and Riot thei ben conuertible
Al konne he pleye or giterne or ribible
Reuel and trouth as in a lough degre
Thei ben ful wrothe al day as men may se
¶ This Ioly prentys with his maister bood
Til he was nygh owte of his pꝰerntys hood
Al were he snybbed bothen erly and late
And some tyme lad with reuel to newegate
But atte last his Maister him bithought
Vppon a day whan he his paper sought
Of a prouerbe that seith this same word
Wel bet is Roten appul out of hord
Than that it roty al the remenant
¶ So fareth it bi ariatours seruant
It is ful lasse harme to late him pace
Thanne he shende al the seruantz in the place
Therfore his maistere yaf him acquitaunce
And bad him goo with sorow and with meschaunce
And thus this Ioly prentys had his leue
Now late him Riote al the nyght or leue
And for ther nys no theef with outen a louke
That helpeth him to wasten and to souke
Of that he brybe can or borowe may
Anon he sente his bedde and his array
Vnto a compere of his owne soort
That loued dys and Riot and dispoort
And hadde a wif that heeld for contenance
A shoppe and swyued for hir sustenance
